SECTION: Section 6; Column 3; Magazine Desk; Pg. 15

LENGTH: 994 words

HEADLINE: THE WAY WE LIVE NOW: 2-9-03; 
Destined For Failure

BYLINE:  By A.O. Scott; A.O. Scott is a movie critic for The Times.

 BODY:
On weekday mornings, after a hurried breakfast of frozen waffles and scrambled eggs and a two-block dash through the neighborhood crush of strollers and briefcases, my 6-year-old son slips his backpack over his shoulders, grants me a desultory hug and passes through the double doors of the school bus into the care of the New York City public school system. He is the apple of my eye, my hostage to fortune, every sentimental paternal cliche you can think of and also, like every other child on the bus, a pawn in an endless political chess game. Along with the peanut butter and jelly sandwich and last night's homework, that blue nylon school bag is weighted down with a century's worth of ideological baggage. And my own parochial parental anxieties -- Is he happy? Is he learning? Is he making friends? -- are, whether I like it or not, shrill notes in a cacophony of political contention, along with the thundering of officeholders, the rumbling of bureaucrats and the horn bleats of think-tank intellectuals. 
 One evening last month, my son's backpack carried home a letter from Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Chancellor Joel I. Klein, announcing an ambitious plan to reconfigure the city's educational system. The mayor, having attained the direct control of the system that the state government had withheld from his predecessors, was now explicitly staking his political future on the abolition of the central Board of Education, the drastic redrawing of local school districts and the imposition of a uniform curriculum for all but the very top schools. These measures, he promised, would bring transparency, accountability and -- that most enduring and elusive education goal -- success. 
 Like much else that this mayor has done, his education proposals manifest a certain ideological eclecticism, which is both welcome and a little confusing. In the weeks following the unveiling of the reforms, the parents and teachers I know tried to figure out whether to be appalled or delighted, skeptical or hopeful. A measure of the plan's radicalism may be that wherever you place yourself on the ideological spectrum -- or even if you don't know where to place yourself -- it could produce all of these responses in turn. To take just one example: people who lean toward progressive education, or who envision individual classrooms as laboratories of learning, might look askance at a common citywide curriculum, especially one that includes phonics in the early grades. But alongside phonics are techniques associated with its supposed antagonist, the "whole language" approach to literacy, which emphasizes reading and creative writing and a more or less progressive program called Everyday Math, both of which might alarm those who believe that children are best educated by traditional methods.
The systemic failure of American education is, by now, a very old story. (There is an equally old, but less frequently told, story about the amazingly various local ways our schools have succeeded.) Twenty years ago, when I was finishing high school, we were "A Nation at Risk" menaced by "a rising tide of mediocrity." A generation before that, there was "Why Johnny Can't Read." And every crisis has provoked grand and global solutions, which in turn engender the next crisis. Every self-evident problem in the New York schools today -- from the gerrymandered districts to the hulking buildings -- was once an equally self-evident cure.
The endless crisis has been driven, to some extent, by adult self-interest, and there is no shortage of scapegoats: stubborn unions, greedy corporations, crackpot theorists, pandering politicos. But while those responsible for the failure of American education -- a list that surely includes parents like me -- are divided by interests and ideologies, they (we) are united by sincere good intentions. We want what's best for our children.
Which is the root of the problem. Our schools are political battlefields to an extent that those in other countries are not because they operate under such diverse and contradictory demands -- most deeply, the desire to nurture each child's talent and potential with the imperative to reproduce a competitive, and often unfair, social order. We expect the schools to resolve social problems, the existence of which we otherwise barely acknowledge. Education is imagined to be the great equalizer, the engine of social mobility and the solvent of class division -- even as the schools, public as well as private, maintain and engineer enormous inequities. Schools are meant to bind local communities and foster a vibrant national economy. Even in microcosm, when we think about what we want them to do for our children (and what do we mean, exactly, by "our children"?), the schools are mired in paradox. Debates over the structure and content of schooling present a series of choices: should children learn important information, useful skills or ennobling values? Should they be given the tools of liberation or the habits of obedience to authority? Should schools foster individual growth or responsible membership in society?
But these are not choices at all. We want -- we expect -- all of these things. Never mind that, for these myriad results, we depend on overworked parents and underfinanced institutions. It never seems to occur to us that the demands are fundamentally at cross-purposes -- are, in a word, utopian. The urge to reform the schools goes beyond the necessary, difficult desire to improve the way they function. It is, rather, the last, strongest redoubt of an American tradition of moral perfectionism: the schools are miniature, prototype cities on a hill, models of the enlightened, egalitarian, excellent society we have not yet managed to create. The buzzword among reformers of whatever coloration is success; but with such a goal, failure is guaranteed, as are the future waves of reform. But we wouldn't have it any other way. Our children deserve no less.

GRAPHIC: Photo (Reuben Cox) Chart: "EASY AS A, B, C""The teaching of reading -- all over the United States, in all the schools, in all the textbooks -- is totally wrong and flies in the face of all logic and common sense. . . . We too could have perfect readers in all schools at the end of second grade if we taught our children by the system used in Germany. Now, what is this system? It's very simple. Reading means getting meaning from certain combinations of letters. Teach the child what each letter stands for and he can read. Ah no, you say, it can't be that simple. But it is." From "Why Johnny Can't Read," by Rudolf Flesch, 1955

HEADLINE: MUSIC; 
Today Disney, Tomorrow The Met

BYLINE:  By MATTHEW GUREWITSCH; Matthew Gurewitsch is a journalist, essayist and novelist based in New York.

 BODY:
SOME of the governmental accolades sound intimidating. There's the medal for service to culture from Russia (for a production of Puccini's "Turandot"). There's the title Chevalier des Arts et des Lettres from France. But the American stage director Francesca Zambello takes no very esoteric view of what she does.
 "I'm a populist, an opera evangelist," she says. "I believe in making shows that speak to a broad audience. I'm not afraid of the word 'entertainment.' " 
 So unafraid, in fact, that she recently went to work "for Mickey Mouse," as she phrased it to friends, staging a live adaptation of Disney's animated hit "Aladdin" for Disney's California Adventure, in Anaheim. Running 45 minutes, double cast and playing several shows a day, "Aladdin: A Musical Spectacular" opened last month, and its puppets and magic-carpet ride reportedly have young audiences and those who escort them in raptures. 
But tomorrow night Ms. Zambello, 46, will be taking bows in her more usual environment: that of grand opera for grown-ups, in this case "Les Troyens" ("The Trojans") by Hector Berlioz, at the Metropolitan Opera.
A five-hour extravaganza derived from the "Aeneid," Virgil's tear-streaked Latin epic of Roman empire, "Les Troyens" stands as grand opera's K2, a peak second only to the Everest of Wagner's "Ring" cycle. The decor is by Maria Bjornson, whose proscenium of gilded angels, candle-lit grotto and plummeting chandelier for "Phantom of the Opera" have drawn gasps from Broadway audiences since 1988, and whose sudden death at 53 in December has the theater world in shock.
No matter what Ms. Zambello and her collaborators put on stage, some fierce catcalls may be expected. Certain factions will be waging a vendetta that dates to 1992, when Ms. Zambello, then a rising international star, came before the Met audience for the first time, directing Donizetti's bel canto evergreen "Lucia di Lammermoor." That's the one in which the heroine -- June Anderson back then -- warms up for the most celebrated mad scene in the literature by slaughtering her groom offstage in their bedroom on their wedding night. Ms. Zambello's program note put a perhaps gratuitous feminist spin on the action, but worse from the reactionaries' point of view, the picturesque traditional trappings of Highland Gothic had been jettisoned in favor of a bleak, symbol-heavy heap of rubble. The stage was strewn with coffins, and as far as most of musical New York was concerned, the funeral was Ms. Zambello's.
In the grand trajectory of her career, the "Lucia" fiasco was actually little more than a blip. From her debut in 1984, putting students at the San Francisco Opera through their paces in "La Traviata," to the new "Aladdin" (undisclosed budget reliably put at $8 million), Ms. Zambello has left few corners of the repertory untouched. Since that dark hour at the Met, her productions have been cheered on leading stages across Europe and the United States. With the notable exceptions of Wagner's "Ring" and most standard Mozart, she has practically done it all: a gargantuan "Tosca" at the Earl's Court Arena in London, capacity 12,000; "The Mikado" at the 505-seat Icelandic Opera in Reykjavik. The list continues to grow at a clip of about a half dozen new shows a year.
But so far the sort of mainstream hit scored by other "serious" directors of opera and drama like Trevor Nunn (with "Cats"), Nicholas Hytner ("Miss Saigon") and Julie Taymor ("The Lion King") has eluded Ms. Zambello, and not for lack of trying. Andrew Sabiston and Tim Williams's "Napoleon," mounted in the West End of London in 2000 for the "Les Miz" demographic, ran a respectable but hardly record-breaking six months despite Ms. Zambello's best efforts. No one in the opera world holds this excursion against her. A commercial smash, in fact, could only improve her stock on the global opera exchange.
As for "Aladdin," which sets out to rival Broadway performance and production standards at their best, Ms. Zambello hopes that it will hook tens of thousands of youngsters a week on the matchless thrill of live theater. (On a smaller scale but in the same missionary spirit, she is preparing a children's opera, "The Little Prince," for the Houston Grand Opera. Aptly enough, the new piece, drawn from Antoine de Saint-Exupery's wistful primer in existentialism, has a score by a composer, Rachel Portman, who has won an Oscar, for the score of "Emma.")
To acknowledge Ms. Zambello's healthy respect for the old razzle-dazzle is not to deny either her voracious intellectual appetite or her appreciation of ordinary domesticity. "You have to feed yourself," she said backstage at the Met in mid-January, "and not just with more opera. I need art. I need books. I need the movies. I need nature. My dogs, my friends, my makeshift family."
A big-boned junior Susan Sontag type, known familiarly as Cesca, Ms. Zambello totes a heavy bag, which was just then bulging with fodder like Edward Tripp's "Meridian Handbook of Classical Mythology," the "Aeneid" and a DVD of "Triumph of the Will," Leni Riefenstahl's infamous record of the 1934 Nazi rally at Nuremberg. Ms. Zambello's French, German, Italian and Russian are fluent, thanks largely to an adolescence spent in cities around Europe, and she dresses and talks like the eternal student she is, with frequent smatterings of foreign tongues.
Oh, to have been a fly on the wall last year (or to have tapped the wire) when she picked up the phone of her London apartment and heard the gritty baritone of Joseph Volpe, the Met's street-tough general manager.
"I've got a little piece I'd like you to put together for us," Mr. Volpe said.
"Well," said Ms. Zambello when the other shoe dropped, "let me open a nice bottle of wine, and call me back. That's not such a little piece."
No, indeed, as she well knew, having directed it in Los Angeles in 1991. In fact, "Les Troyens" is so vast that the composer's contemporaries chopped it into two separate operas (and then butchered those). The first deals with the fall of ancient Troy, Trojan horse and all, culminating in a mass suicide led by the prophet Cassandra (at the Met, Deborah Voigt). Part 2 covers the tragic love affair of Dido, queen of Carthage (Lorraine Hunt Lieberson), and Aeneas, leader of Troy's survivors (Ben Heppner), whose destiny is to found Rome, a second Troy, in far-off Italy. This section, too, ends in suicide: that of the abandoned Dido.
Having drained her glass and taken up the gauntlet, Ms. Zambello reported to work at the Met to find the hate mail already waiting. What did her correspondents say? "Oh, you can imagine," she said with a philosopher's detachment. "Strangely scribbled threats about what to expect on opening night because I ruined 'their' 'Lucia' 10 years ago. Ten years!"
Once she might have been amused and flattered, but these days such letters are turned over to security. At the same time, she loves knowing that her work has ignited the passions of opera lovers, both pro and con. "Art doesn't exist without opinions," she said. "One has to grow the skin of a crocodile and the heart of a friendly lion. In this business, a lot of people want you to fail. Critics, because they think it's more fun to write about a fiasco. Reactionaries, who want a real tree onstage, and not the essence of a tree, if the libretto says there's a tree. Some of one's colleagues." Like any other theatrical professional, Ms. Zambello has obliged with the occasional flop. But not often.
Under the fluorescent light of the subterranean bunker known to the Met staff as C-level, the hours were passing quickly, and there was much to do. The call one morning was for soloists only. A visitor's jaw dropped to hear Ms. Zambello address Mr. Heppner, with his lumberjack's physique, as Honey Bunny, but it is an endearment her casts soon grow used to. Dido was slipping deeper into her infatuation with Aeneas, posing a dangerous distraction from his predestined mission. In a remote corner of the studio, Ms. Zambello went into a huddle with Ms. Hunt Lieberson and Mr. Heppner, reciting the relevant passage from Virgil.
In the words of The New Grove Dictionary of Opera, Ms. Zambello's signature is "visual brilliance and fine acting." Curious impresarios can see that judgment triumphantly vindicated in the hourlong videotape of performance clips that is her electronic portfolio.
In collaboration with such master designers as Robert Israel, Richard Hudson, Alison Chitty and Michael Yeargan, Ms. Zambello has developed a vocabulary of the grand scenic gesture. Visually, the work is unabashedly eclectic, running the gamut from sumptuous, Rauschenbergian poster art in "Madama Butterfly" to spare New England Gothic in Tobias Picker's "Emmeline," from Cinerama grandeur in Prokofiev's epic "War and Peace" to juicy film noir in Carlisle Floyd's "Of Mice and Men," from severe abstraction in the shipboard allegory of "Billy Budd" to gaudy celestial circus in "The Bartered Bride."
ON her broad canvas, Ms. Zambello drops bushels of cherry petals and acres of crimson parachute silk to heart-stopping emotional effect. She deploys monumental blocks of built scenery with the majesty of planets in motion. Yet within the spectacle, the human drama is painted with the finest of brushes. Principal or chorister, it always pays to watch the players closely. Thus, at the final curtain of Wagner's "Tristan und Isolde," Mr. Heppner's Tristan -- safely expired, one would have thought, after his interminable agonies -- tenderly reached out his hand an inch for the hand of Jane Eaglen's Isolde. Having exhaled her last F sharp pianissimo, Isolde, too, was by now to be presumed dead. Yet the gesture made total sense: transcendence by stealth.
Reunited with Ms. Zambello for "Les Troyens," Mr. Heppner speaks of her with warmth. "Cesca has a wonderful ability to bring everybody onto the same page," he said between rehearsals. "Her big thrust in 'Troyens' has been to humanize the icons of mythology, within a very epic set that gives the piece the scope it needs, but with the flexibility to bring the personal emotion."
At lunch in the Met canteen, Ms. Zambello defined her job simply. "To tell the story, by whatever means necessary," she said, munching chicken she had brought from the home on the Upper West Side of Manhattan that she shares with Manuela Hoelterhoff, the acerbic, often devastating culture critic and occasional opera librettist. "To tell it clearly and dramatically, as the composer intended."
As a general matter, Ms. Zambello finds it useful forthe performers as well as for audiences to give them points of reference from the world they live in. "A masterpiece transcends the ages," she said. "My intent is to create an environment in which the work can live today. I'm rarely time-specific in my work. I don't 'modernize' by putting a nuclear reactor onstage. But I do try to make an audience think about our world."
Typically, the design of a new show takes a year, with collaboration at the heart of the process. "It begins by just getting to know the material with your team, reading it aloud to each other, listening to recordings, reading the score, studying the sources, exploring visual references, looking for metaphors of our world today. I often think that a designer does half the directing, the same way that directors do half the design."
Back on C-level that afternoon, a cast of thousands (a hundred-plus, anyway) was gathering for the first rehearsal of what Ms. Zambello calls the "Fourth of July/Thanksgiving" scene with chorus, dancers and extras, complete with a pint-size rainbow coalition of eager children, among them a boy named Troy and a girl named Cassandra.
"We're in Carthage now," Ms. Zambello began, addressing the troops from atop a little step. "It's the city founded by Dido, a sort of ideal world society. A kibbutz. Communism before it all went bad. Dido is a visionary. A pacifist. Indira Gandhi meets Hillary Clinton. And if anybody has a better analogy, please tell me. The first thing we see when the curtain rises is a great rush forward. Like a great wave of the Mediterranean crashing on the shore of Carthage. Run or walk quickly. It's pandemonium."
At Ms. Hunt Lieberson's side for Dido's State of the Union address is Ms. Zambello, now in the role of simultaneous interpreter, urging the chorus on to lifelike, individual reactions. "We've been living in this peaceful world. A boom economy. Carthage-dot-com. Now war may be on the horizon. It couldn't be more contemporary. Break. Twenty-five minutes." As others disperse, a studious chorister moves in to engage the approachable Ms. Zambello in shoptalk on the role of gods in Virgil. Then it's back to pandemonium until the stroke of 5:45, laid down by union rules.
The long day's work done, Ms. Zambello stopped at the Met canteen for a last round of inquisition, this time on the subject of her future.
"Every direction you turn, there's something to entice you," she said. "I'd like to do the 'Ring.' I'd like to do 'Lulu.' But more than a piece, I'd eventually like to run an opera company: a director's theater with a high-level ensemble and strong musical director, performing a wide range of styles. A place for an audience that trusts us and will come to the shows no matter what. A place where all of us -- the artists and the public -- can take a long journey together."

Les Troyens
Metropolitan Opera, Lincoln Center.
Opens tomorrow at 6 p.m.

HEADLINE: TELEVISION/RADIO; 
Not Gone With the Wind: Voices of Slavery

BYLINE:  By HENRY LOUIS GATES Jr.; Henry Louis Gates Jr., chairman of the Department of Afro-American Studies at Harvard University, wrote the foreword of "Unchained Memories: Readings From the Slave Narratives," the companion book to the HBO documentary.

 BODY:
My mother's mistress had three boys, one 21, one 19 and one 17. Old mistress had gone away to spend the day one day. Mother always worked in the house. She didn't work on the farm in Missouri. While she was alone, the boys came in and threw her down on the floor and tied her down so she couldn't struggle, and one after the other used her as long as they wanted for the whole afternoon. 
 Mother was sick when her mistress came home. When the old mistress wanted to know whatwas the matter with her, she told her what the boys had done. She whipped them and that's the way I came to be here.
-- Mary Estes Peters, former slave

WILLIAM WELLS BROWN, one of the most famous fugitive slaves on the antislavery lecture circuit before the Civil War and the author of a best-selling slave narrative, once argued that "slavery never can be represented," an ironic claim from someone who spent his professional life trying to do just that.
Brown was not arguing against the use of literary forms to protest the horrors of the "peculiar institution"; rather, he was arguing that there could be no more telling mode of bearing witness against slavery than the unmediated voices of the slaves themselves. You had to go there to know there, Zora Neale Hurston said, and Brown would have agreed. But the question underlying Brown's assertion was: Who could, or should, represent slavery?
"Unchained Memories," an HBO documentary that makes its debut tomorrow night, provides a powerful answer to that question. It gives us, through the faces and voices of African-American actors, an introduction to a vast undertaking that took place in the 1930's: the collection and preservation of the testimonies of thousands of aged former slaves in an archive known as the Slave Narrative Collection of the Federal Writers' Project. This archive unlocked the brutal secrets of slavery by using the voices of average slaves as the key, exposing the everyday life of the slave community. Rosa Starke, a slave from South Carolina, for example, told of how class divisions among the slaves were quite pronounced:
"Dere was just two classes to de white folks, buckra slave owners and poor white folks dat didn't own no slaves. Dere was more classes 'mongst de slaves. De fust class was de house servants. Dese was de butler, de maids, de nurses, chambermaids, and de cooks. De nex' class was de carriage drivers and de gardeners, de carpenters, de barber and de stable men. Then come de nex' class, de wheelwright, wagoners, blacksmiths and slave foremen. De nex' class I members was de cow men and de niggers dat have care of de dogs. All dese have good houses and never have to work hard or git a beatin'. Then come de cradlers of de wheat, de threshers and de millers of de corn and de wheat, and de feeders of de cotton gin. De lowest class was de common field niggers."
Voices like hers had waited more than 70 years to be heard, and why they were silent for so long is itself, in part, a story of class tensions within the black community.
Fugitive African-American slaves enjoy a rare distinction in the long and bloody history of human slavery: they alone created a genre of literature about their bondage and freedom, as Frederick Douglass put it in the title of his second autobiography. The slave narratives, which came of age with the publication of Douglass's best-selling "Narrative" in 1845, were extraordinarily popular, the thrillers of antebellum America.
Encouraged by white abolitionists, more than 100 fugitive slaves wrote or dictated book-length accounts from 1760 to 1865. About as many people born into slavery published autobiographies between the end of the Civil War and the Harlem Renaissance of the 1920's. Slavery -- or rather, its transcendence -- made for good reading. In the first few decades after the Civil War, as slavery receded into memory, rooting one's origins in that putrid soil served as a sort of legitimizing ritual for black men and women establishing themselves as authors and public figures.
If the printed word was no adequate substitute for actual experience, slavery could nonetheless be both represented and remembered -- analyzed, critiqued, contained -- through the written testimonies of the articulate, literate few who had broken their chains, escaped to the North, and mastered literacy, ostensibly speaking for the slaves left behind. William Wells Brown, who devoted his career as an author to depicting slavery in novels, plays, histories and autobiographies, knew this: "I stand here as the representative of the slave," he said in a speech in 1854," to speak for those who cannot speak for themselves."
By the turn of the century, however, slavery had become something of an embarrassment to an aspiring black elite desperate to integrate into a gilded American age. Booker T. Washington himself led the charge by calling for a New Negro, one who would cease complaining about slavery. Even in his classic "Up From Slavery" (1901), he urged his black readers to obliterate their memory of hurt and wrongs, bragging that he had completely rid himself of "any ill feeling toward the Southern white man for any wrong that he may have inflicted upon my race." As his contemporary Benjamin Tanner put it, "The very remembrance of our experience is hideous." Sarah Debro, an ex-slave, told an interviewer in North Carolina in 1937: "My folks don't want me to talk about slavery. They's shame niggers ever was slaves." Slavery? Forget about it.
WASHINGTON'S blueprint for a New Negro was actually a call for a full embrace of white, bourgeois values, complete with his insistence on the importance of "a toothbrush and a bar of soap." Even by then, class tensions had had a long history among African-Americans, and they had also troubled the abolitionist movement. Douglass complained in 1856, "Opposing slavery and hating its victims has come to be a very common form of abolitionism." In the slave narratives, the noble, aspiring fugitive often established his nobility, implicitly, at the expense of the average, illiterate, less adventurous slaves left behind -- whose spoken language even black authors often rendered in a harsh, humorous dialect.
Nowhere are these class tensions depicted more baldly than in "The Bondwoman's Narrative," written by a mulatto house servant, Hannah Crafts, in the 1850's. Crafts describes field hands as the "vile, foul, filthy inhabitants of the huts." By the Harlem Renaissance, Crafts's view had become something of the norm, even if rendered less harshly. As Alain Locke put it in "The New Negro" (1925), "Uncle Tom and Sambo have passed on." Uneducated blacks were not "presentable" to a white American public that stereotyped all blacks as inferior and uneducable, and their voices had to be repressed, both by the fugitive slave authors and by revisionist historians of the Old South, the moonbeam and magnolia blossom school of Confederate apologists.
Slavery lost its romance, and its usefulness. (By 1954, the year of Brown v. Board of Education, only one slave narrative would be in print.) For many black intellectuals, it seems, slavery had been represented all too much, at least as a salient shaping force in the history of Negro citizens seeking to end legal segregation.
The majority of slaves, those who worked in the fields, would gain their voice, oddly enough, only in the Great Depression, initially through the under-financed efforts of a small group of black historians. For them, too, the question was not whether slavery could be represented; the question was, represented by whom? This time, the answer was different. As the historian Lawrence Reddick put itin 1937, "There is not yet a picture of the institution as seen through the eyes of the bondsman himself."
Reddick's impulse indirectly gave rise to interviews with more than 2,000 former slaves, the field hands who had been rendered silent in the printed narratives and in standard histories of slavery. (To understand the project's import, imagine if 2,000 interviews of Greek or Roman slaves suddenly became available to classical historians.) Little could have alarmed Booker T. Washington more than hundreds of interviewers, most of them white, fanning out all over the South, armed with a list of questions and writing down testimonies about life under slavery.
Why turn to the slave so very many years after the abolition of slavery, especially when so many black intellectuals were skittish? There are several reasons, but the most important is the emergence of black historians who were intent on refuting the rosy, and often racist, depictions of slavery propagated by scholars who were little more than apologists for the Confederacy. Chief among these was the Yale historian Ulrich B. Phillips, whose "American Negro Slavery" (1918) portrayed the slave as happy and content, his treatment by his master generous, "civilizing" and humane. Even many black people accepted these stereotypical notions. What more effective way to counter these claims than with the words of former slaves themselves?
Charles S. Johnson, the great black sociologist, had begun a project at Fisk University in Nashville in 1929 to interview former slaves in Tennessee and Kentucky, and later in Alabama. The historian John B. Cade at Southern University embarked on a similar course of interviews the same year. Reddick, at Kentucky State College, proposed in 1934 that the Federal Emergency Relief Fund systematically interview former slaves, in part to give employment to "unemployed Negro college graduates." Reddick's project yielded 250 interviews, gathered in Indiana and Kentucky in 1934 and 1935.
At the urging of John A. Lomax, a seminal figure in the collection of American folklore (and the father of the folk music archivist Alan Lomax), and Sterling A. Brown, a poet, critic and Howard University professor who was director of the Office of Negro Affairs within the Federal Writers' Project, the writers' project began gathering oral narratives of former slaves in 1937. Brown argued the case for black interviewers in as many Southern states as he could. (Zora Neale Hurston actually recorded former slaves in Florida.) Nevertheless, most units of the Writers' Project remained segregated, according to the Jim Crow practices of the time. The project's financing ended by 1939, but not before previously silenced slaves had finally had their say.
The archive that was gathered consisted of 2,300 interviews conducted in 17 states. (Some 1,200 or so more interviews have been unearthed in other archives.) The former slaves had been 1 to 30-something years old when the Civil War ended seven decades before, but most were from 6 to 20; they represented about 2 percent of the total former-slave population.
All sorts of colorful characters in the drama of slavery, relegated to cameo appearances in the earlier narratives, take center stage in these oral histories, from cooks and chambermaids to gardeners, barbers and carpenters. Perhaps the most important contribution the oral narratives make to our understanding of slavery is the registering of the thoughts and feelings of women. Only six slave narratives were published by women before the end of the Civil War, roughly 5 percent of the total. Here, by contrast, about half of the interviews were with women. And they provide details of daily life not generally stressed in the printed narratives, especially about the sexual exploitation of female slaves.
Mary Estes Peters's account of rape, at the beginning of this article, had no counterpart in the printed narratives. Rose Williams, of Texas, even discussed her feelings about her forced marriage to another slave, an institutionalized form of rape commonly practiced on the plantation:
"Dere am one thing Massa Hawkins does to me what I can't shunt from my mind. I know he don't do it for meanness, but I allus holds it 'gainst him. What he done am force me to live with dat nigger, Rufus, 'gainst my wants."
Even the Rev. Ishrael Massie's account of rape is much more direct than anything found in the narratives of Douglass, Brown and their contemporaries:
"Lord chile, dat wuz common. Marsters an' overseers use to make slaves dat wuz wid deir husbands git up, do as dey say. Send husband out on de farm, milkin' cows or cuttin' wood. Den he gits in bed wid slave himself. Some women would fight an tussel. Others would be 'umble -- feared of dat beatin'. What we saw, couldn't do nothing 'bout it.."
Just like Booker T. Washington and Alain Locke, American society has long been haunted by the ghost of slavery past, as if silence about its horrors -- and its significance to American prosperity and the shaping of our institutions -- would make it go away. But the past can't be ignored; it can only be processed, digested and represented, again and again. The Writer's Project archive began to be systematically published in the 70's, under the editorial direction of the historian George P. Rawick, and today no fewer than 40 volumes (10,000 pages totaling 3.5 million words) of these fascinating interviews are available in print under the title "The American Slave: A Composite Autobiography" (Greenwood Publishing Group). Recordings of a number of the actual interviews are also available in "Remembering Slavery," a book-and-tape set published by the New Press. And the original typescripts, as well as 500 photographs, can be viewed on the Web site of the Library of Congress, at http://memory.loc.gov/ammem/snhtml/snhome.html.
HBO's "Unchained Memories" gives voice to the lives of the slaves in a form both accessible and dramatic, two qualities necessary for an event to become part of our national memory. (Even scholars have complained about the readability of the dialect in the interviews, a vice transformed into a virtue through the renderings of actors like Samuel L. Jackson, Ossie Davis and Ruby Dee, Angela Bassett, Vanessa L. Williams and Oprah Winfrey.)
Through the power of these re-creations, the slaves left behind claim the right to represent -- and speak -- themselves into the heart of our national memory, a memory that should be as richly various as the American experience itself.

Unchained Memories
HBO
Tomorrow at 8 p.m., Eastern time.

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT; 
Rebels in Nepal Drive Down Tourism

BYLINE:  By PHILIP SHENON

DATELINE: KATMANDU, Nepal 

 BODY:
A HALF-CENTURY after this Himalayan kingdom captured the world's attention in May 1953 with the bulletin that Sir Edmund Hillary had conquered Mount Everest, the news is mostly grim for a nation that still depends on mountaineers and other travelers from abroad for its economic vitality.
 The tourism industry in Nepal, a nation towered over by some of the world's highest mountains and revered as the birthplace of Buddha, has virtually collapsed as a result of the Maoist insurgency that now controls more than a third of the countryside and is seeking to abolish the monarchy. 
 Although the insurgents have said that foreign travelers and major tourism sites will be spared from violence, clashes between the rebels and government forces have left nearly 8,000 Nepalese dead since the guerrillas took up arms in 1996.
In November, the State Department said Americans "should consider deferring nonessential travel" to Nepal after the Maoists claimed responsibility for murdering a pair of Nepalese security guards who worked at the United States Embassy here. 
At the end of last month, a surprise cease-fire spurred hopes for an end to the violence. Even before that, Nepalese government officials said that the nation's most important tourism areas, including the popular trekking routes in the foothills of the Himalayas, remained safe. 
They insisted that they would go forward with celebrations this spring to mark the golden anniversary of the ascent of Everest by Sir Edmund and the Sherpa mountaineer Tenzing Norgay. But the officials are not optimistic that the anniversary will signal any sort of turnaround for tourism. 
According to figures from the official Nepal Tourism Board, the number of foreign visitors fell nearly 28 percent last year, as measured by airline passenger arrivals, after dropping 20 percent the year before.
The number of travelers arriving by air in 2002 was 215,900, compared with 298,900 in 2001. Although the board offered no exact nation-by-nation breakdown, it said that the number of American visitors fell by nearly half last year.
"It's very sad, because we've been operating there for 25 years and think Nepal remains a very safe destination," said James Faubel, president of Himalayan Travel of Danbury, Conn. "We certainly wouldn't advise our clients to go into areas that have been problematic in western Nepal, but tourists never went there anyway."
He said that his agency had sent an average of 300 Americans a year to Nepal before the insurgency, but that the number fell to under 100 last year, a result of the rebel threat and the turmoil that resulted from the June 2001 massacre of much of the Nepalese royal family by Crown Prince Dipendra, who then shot himself; many Nepalese say the motivations for the killings remain a mystery.
Mr. Faubel said that despite the recent chaos, none of his clients had ever found themselves in danger -- or reported any other problem. "Not a single problem for a single client," he said.
For foreign visitors willing to take the risk, there are remarkable bargains to be found, especially among the major hotels in the Katmandu Valley, which have slashed rates. The Hyatt Regency, a palatial structure that dominates the capital's skyline and is arguably the most luxurious hotel in the country, is offering a basic nightly rate of $80 for two this month, down from $105 when the hotel opened in 2000.
Apart from a notable lack of foreigners, there is little in Katmandu to suggest the chaos found elsewhere in the country; the capital's narrow, temple-clogged streets remain calm, and its residents are eager to make visitors feel welcome -- and safe.
"The drop in tourism is affecting every one of us," said Sunil Chitrakar, executive director of Mahaguthi, a charitable group that runs one of the city's most popular stores for traditional Nepalese crafts, including handmade paper, ceramics and jewelry.
Because of the drop in tourism, the group, which provides vocational training for hundreds of impoverished women around the country, has had to delay expansion plans that included housing and training dozens more destitute women. "Luckily, we haven't had to lay off anyone," he said.
The insurgents, who call themselves the People's Army and are believed to number about 5,000, have said repeatedly in public pronouncements that they do not intend to undermine tourism and that they will not attack foreign visitors, apparently in recognition of the fact that tourism provides jobs to the Nepalese masses whose support they seek. 
Nonetheless, a handful of foreign trekkers who have passed through Maoist-controlled areas in recent months have been stopped by armed rebels and asked, apparently politely, to pay "taxes" -- equivalent to a few dollars per person -- for the right to pass through.

HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER; 
Gathering The Family Tree

BYLINE:  By MARTHA STEVENSON OLSON; MARTHA STEVENSON OLSON is a freelance writer.

 BODY:
AS Mary Ferrell tells it, the idea of a family get-together had come up regularly over the years in talks with her mother, Katie Ferrell, who is now 82. So finally, in late 2001, Ms. Ferrell decided to take the initiative. She and her mother sent a letter to the surviving relatives of her father's four siblings. 
 "Basically it said, 'Let's come and be family,"' Ms. Ferrell, director of the Fairmount Park Conservancy in Philadelphia, recently said by telephone. As a gathering place, they picked the town where her forebears had homesteaded, Mountain View, Mo., and chose the weekend of July 4, 2002. Her mother's advancing years were more a motivating force than the events of Sept. 11, Ms. Ferrell said, although both, she believes, were factors in the high turnout -- 20 of the 35 invited. 
 One good source on reunions is Reunions Magazine, which been in business for 14 years and has had a Web site, www.reunionsmag.com, since 1995. "The feeling I get from my readers is, they're not going to be affected by the economy and not by terrorism," said Edith Wagner, the editor. "Reunions are important to them." 
For those who are considering initiating a family reunion, lots of help is available. The Internet has been a boon to those hoping to reconnect: One can look for long-lost relatives via sites like www.geneaology.com, www.classmates.com or at www.whowhere.com, as well as find online articles and checklists, timetables, advice and links to reunion-friendly resorts and travel agents. 
One agency, Trump Travel in Baldwin, N.Y., has made a specialty of reunions over the last six years. "I did one for my own family," said the owner, Claudia Rabin-Manning, "and it sort of blossomed out from there." Depending on what the reunion organizers want, she said, she will collect and disburse money, locate a hotel or cruise ship for the participants, arrange meals, and book tickets for shows, theme parks and tours. The agency charges $250 for all the planning, and will make up and mail fliers to up to 100 recipients for $100. Recent reunions have ranged from a resort in Lake George to a dude ranch in Utah. The agency can be reached at (800) 937-3878 or by visiting www.familyreunionbiz.com.
Convention and visitors bureaus around the country can often help reunion planners. For links to them, visit www.officialtravelguide.com, affiliated with the International Association of Convention and Visitors Bureaus, (800) 208-8661. 

Books and Other Sources
Several books have recently been published on the subject. Ms. Wagner has written "The Family Reunion Sourcebook" (Lowell House, $16.95), and there are several others including "Family Reunion: Everything You Need to Know to Plan Unforgettable Get-Togethers," by Jennifer Crichton (Workman Publishing, 1998, $13.95); "The Family Reunion Planner," by Donna Beasley (1997, MacMillan, $9.95); "Your Family Reunion: How to Plan It, Organize It, and Enjoy It," by George G. Morgan (2001, Ancestry Publishing, $16.95); and the "Family Reunion Planning Kit for Dummies," a book and CD-ROM by Cheryl Fall (2001, John Wiley & Sons, $24.99).
A subscription to Reunions Magazine, at $17.99 a year, also brings a reunion workbook and catalog ($10 if ordered separately) that provides lots of information in a step-by-step format, along with advertisements from resorts and travel companies. The magazine and workbook can be ordered online or at (800) 373-7933.
Ms. Wagner offered some advice. "Start early enough," was first. Many reunion planners suggest 18 months to two years as the right amount of lead time, especially for a large group. Second, Ms. Wagner said, "Don't do it alone -- get other people to help right from the start." A big gathering might require an organizing committee, regional managers and delegates for specific meals and responsibilities. Third, make sure everyone can afford it. Finally, have something going on for everyone and every age, especially children. 
All-inclusive cruises and resorts may carry a daunting price tag initially, but can be a bargain if you price the components individually, she said, and the range of options and meals eliminates many of the most common bones of contention.
Some families choose a time and place with a special meaning, say, the old homestead and the birthday of the family patriarch or matriarch. Others take the path of least resistance, for instance a holiday weekend at a location convenient to the largest number of relatives. Others pass the baton: one year on the East Coast, another on the West Coast, or one year with one side of the family, the next with the other side. 

Discovering Roots
The greatest reward, say reunion veterans, is discovering and exploring the family's roots and connecting with relatives who otherwise wouldn't be familiar. The activities during a family reunion might include videotaped storytelling, designing and creating a family tree, visiting the graves of family members or gathering family photos or recipes for a scrapbook or cookbook. A group photo is usually obligatory, of course. In addition, some families use the occasion to set up a family association to endow scholarships or finance historic or charitable organizations. 
After the popularity of the 1976 book "Roots" by Alex Haley and then the television series, which explored the African-American diaspora, many African-American families started family reunion traditions. The Family Reunion Institute, founded 13 years ago by Dr. Ione Vargas of Temple University, originally focused on inspiring African Americans to seek their kin, but has grown so successful that its annual AfricanAmerican Family Reunion Conference, which now draws participants and speakers of many ethnicities, has been renamed the Family Reunion Conference, (215) 204-6244 or visit www.pathfinderstravel.com/famreunion02.html. This year it is March 21 to 23 in Columbia, Md. 
Some places have become so popular with reunion groups, they are booked solid through the summer and most long weekends a couple of years in advance. One of these is the Estes Park, Colo., branch of the Y.M.C.A. of the Rockies, (800) 777-9622, www.ymcarockies.org, which bills itself as "America's leading host for family reunions," with more than 600 booked last year. To ease travel burdens, many reunions are sited roughly in the center of the country, and near a hub airport, so areas around Denver, Houston and Chicago are obvious choices.
As for whom to invite, the experts suggest casting as generous a net as possible, despite family feuds and cantankerous uncles. This could be an opportunity to mend fences and strengthen family ties. 
That doesn't mean everything will go completely smoothly, though. Asked if she would organize a second Ferrell family reunion, Ms. Ferrell paused, then quoted one of the participants: "Trying to organize Ferrells is like trying to herd cats." Nevertheless, she said, a couple of other relatives are talking about taking over the reins this year.

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY; 
California Indians Turn Casino Into Full Resort

BYLINE:  By MARTHA STEVENSON OLSON

 BODY:
The Barona Band of Mission Indians, based about 30 miles east of San Diego, has in the last 70 years made an economic transition from cattle ranching to bingo parlor to a small casino. The newest expansion on the tribe's 7,000-acre reservation is the $260 million Barona Valley Ranch Resort and Casino, opened Jan. 1. 
 Its design by Bergman, Walls & Associates, architects of the Paris, Mirage and Caesars Palace casino hotels in Las Vegas, harks back to the ranching days of the 1930's, with dark wood and stone facades, a functioning old-mill water wheel and a restored barn. 
 The centerpiece of the resort is a new 300,000-square-foot casino with 2,000 slot machines, video poker, keno machines, an 11-table poker room and an off-track betting area. A 20,000-square-foot room, Founder's Hall, will have bingo as well as special events, concerts and meetings. 
The two-year-old Barona Creek Golf Club, designed by Gary Roger Baird, is a par 72 course that was named among the top 10 new national courses by Golf Magazine last year. The resort features eight restaurants and a lakefront Victorian-style wedding chapel with catering facilities nearby; the resort is awaiting a liquor license. 
The 397 guest rooms and suites start from $79 on weekdays and from $129 on weekends, with the 33 suites going for $250 to $1,000. Reserve at (877) 287-2624 or www.barona.com. MARTHA STEVENSON OLSON

HEADLINE: In the Region/Westchester; 
In 2002, a Jump in Sales Of Million-Dollar Homes

BYLINE:  By ELSA BRENNER

 BODY:
NOTWITHSTANDING a noticeable softening at the end of the year, Westchester's luxury home market -- residences selling for $1 million and more -- thrived in 2002. 
 In all, 814 single-family luxury homes -- out of 1,575 on the market for $1 million and more -- sold in 2002. That was 250, or 44 percent, more than in 2001, when there were 1,102 homes listed at $1 million or more and 564 of them sold. 
Dollar volume also jumped in the luxury home category in 2002 -- to $1.4 billion, compared with $951 million the previous year. The median list price in the luxury category in 2002 was $1.55 million, somewhat more than the $1.525 median in 2002. 
So, despite a weak national economy, fears of an impending war and worries about terrorism at home -- or perhaps because of those factors, some real estate brokers said -- the luxury housing market flourished.
The economic and political worries, however, may have factored into a downturn late last year, when, as Billie Prizio, a sales associate for Julia B. Fee in Rye, said, "things were lethally slow."
Demand was weak in the fourth quarter, according to Greg Rand, a co-owner of Prudential Rand, which has offices in Westchester, Rockland and Orange Counties. "There was a heavy dose of caution, a lot of concern about the bubble bursting," he said, "and then everything changed."
After "the slowdown at the end of the year when demand dried up," Mr. Rand said, the new year brought a distinct change. "Buyers are back now," he said.
David Sacarny, the owner of Everest Estate Homes, builders in Bronxville, said the market for brand new luxury homes also experienced an upswing in January after a temporary downturn in the last quarter of 2002. "It's my sense is that people got so disgusted with stock market that they sought the stability of real estate," said Mr. Sacarny, who is building four homes in Purchase selling for $2.65 million and above. "For us, it was very quiet in October, November and early December, and then all of a sudden, things got crazy busy."
Houlihan/Lawrence reported a similar trend. It recorded 21 properties listed for $1 million and above going to contract in December and 58 such properties going to contract in January.
Low interest rates are also said to be drawing buyers to real estate, despite concerns about the economy in general. Mr. Sacarny observed that more buyers are able to afford the monthly payments on expensive homes when the rates are low. The prevailing rates for a five-year adjustable rate mortgage in the week that ended on Jan. 31, according to American Home Mortgage in White Plains, was between 3.875 and 4.875 percent.
Houlihan/Lawrence reported that in 2002 Scarsdale remained the top community for sales in the luxury category, followed by Rye, Larchmont, Bedford, Bronxville, Armonk, Chappaqua and Briarcliff.
But the $1 million-plus market has widened in Westchester, according to representatives at Prudential Rand, Houlihan/Lawrence and Julia B. Fee, with sales at that level being seen in places where they rarely were before, like Yorktown, Croton, Irvington, Dobbs Ferry and White Plains.
The most expensive home for sale in 2002 was a $23.5 million 20-room contemporary in Chappaqua, listed by Houlihan/Lawrence. It is still on the market. Others listed in 2002 that have not sold include a $17 million turn-of-the-century residence on the Long Island Sound in Mamaroneck and a $15.5 million 1858 Victorian on 117 acres in North Salem. 
AMONG those that did sell was a $6.5 million 11,000-square-foot mansion on 12 acres in Bedford Corners, a $7.25 million 1950's Georgian colonial along Larchmont Harbor and a $5 million Tudor manor, built by George Jay Gould, the son of the railroad tycoon Jay Gould, that overlooks Manursing Harbor in Rye.
Noteworthy houses now on the market at somewhat lower prices include a 1906 Tudor manor in Bedford Corners on a 4.6-acre hilltop setting with an asking price of $4.1 million. In Pound Ridge, a 15-acre property being offered at $3.5 million includes a main residence with a section dating back to 1775, a guest house, a caretaker's cottage, a barn and paddocks and a pool house.
Realtors said that in general houses selling for more than $4.5 million are taking much longer to sell than those listed for $1 million to $4.5 million.
According to figures for all of Westchester supplied by George Stone, an owner of Julia B. Fee, which has offices in Larchmont, Scarsdale and Rye, the inventory of homes on the market at $1 million and above was 1,575 homes in 2002 compared with 1,102 in 2001.
The jump did not appear to be connected to "any particular outside influence," nor did it contribute to a decrease in prices on luxury properties, according to Anthony P. Cutugno, director of Houlihan/Lawrence's Luxury Country Properties division. "People list their homes for sale for a myriad of personal, family and career reasons," he said, "National or international events don't appear to have anything to do it."
Buyers of luxury homes are benefiting from the increased inventory in that they have more to choose from, with sellers not adversely affected either. "Essentially, we now have a far more balanced market in the luxury sector than we have seen over the last several years when inventories were extremely low," Mr. Cutugno said. "Supply and demand are now far more in synch." 
By contrast, other sectors of the housing market were held back by a severe shortage of listings, with inventory at one-third to one-half of normal levels, according to the fourth-quarter report of the Westchester-Putnam Multiple Listing Service.
While the rest of the nation enjoyed record-high home sales in 2002, according to the report, the Westchester-Putnam area was held back by the relative shortage of homes listed at less than $1 million. Over all, the number of sales in Westchester last year was up only 1.8 percent over 2001. In the fourth quarter the number of sales, 1,194, was down 3.6 percent from the corresponding quarter a year earlier, when 1,239 homes were sold. Dollar volume of sales, however, was up 20.3 percent in the latest quarter.
"The consequences of low inventory are the reduced sales rates and the higher prices that we have experienced since 1999 and 2000," the report said. The median sale priceof a single-family home in Westchester during the fourth quarter was $520,000 -- down from the median price in the third quarter, $570,750, but up about 22 percent from the end of the fourth quarter of 2001, when the median price was $428,000.
Over all, the housing inventory in each quarter of 2002 was higher than that of the corresponding quarter in 2001. By year-end 2002 there were 3,700 units available for sale in Westchester County; that was 47 percent greater than 2001's year-end count. But the percentage increases are exaggerated because they were calculated against a very low base, the report said. The recent inventory is far below the levels of 6,000 or more units available in 1998 and 10,000 or more in the early 1990's and earlier. 
Looking ahead, the county is starting the year with more inventory than at the start of 2002, and this may pave the high for a higher rate of sales by a few percentage points, the Board of Realtors predicted. In the high-end sector, the marketing slowdown reported in the fourth quarter of 2002 may be reflected in fewer closings and lower prices in the first quarter of 2003. That circumstance may pull down the overall mean sale prices for the quarter but is not likely to affect median sale prices much, the report said.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property; 
New Jersey Shipping Hubs Add Buildings

BYLINE:  By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
CRATE & BARREL, the home furnishings retail chain, recently signed up to be the sole user of a soon-to-be-built 675,000-square-foot warehouse and distribution center near Exit 8A of the New Jersey Turnpike and said it wanted to expand it to nearly 1 million square feet.
 In the New Jersey Meadowlands, Orix Real Estate Equities, a subsidiary of a Japanese financial services company, is constructing an industrial building of almost 370,000 square feet on speculation. 
 And even closer to New York, in Jersey City, Keystone Property Trust, a Philadelphia-area real estate investment trust, is building two distribution centers totaling about 524,000 square feet. As is the case with the Orix building in the Meadowlands, no tenants have been signed up for Keystone's properties, according to brokers.
At a time when lots of older industrial buildings have plenty of space available, both retailers and developers appear to think that steady consumer demand and a rising surge of imports will provide demand for the newest and most modern buildings that process and handle goods. 
And virtually all of the action is in New Jersey, rather than being spread more evenly throughout the metropolitan area. Real estate executives say the state's ideal location west of the Hudson River but close to New York City, its good road, rail and air connections and the availability of flat land make it a natural site for the handling and distribution of consumer and industrial goods.
"New Jersey is the third largest industrial hub in the nation, after Los Angeles and Chicago," said Stanley B. Danzig, an executive director in the New Jersey office of Cushman & Wakefield, the brokerage and services company. He said land is too expensive in Westchester and Fairfield Counties for industrial development, Long Island is too isolated, and flat land is hard to come by in rugged Rockland Country. Former industrial sites in eastern Pennsylvania are also being marketed, but they are that much farther away from the metropolitan New York consumer core.
The need for distribution centers is likely to increase steadily as the volume of imports grows at Port Newark and Port Elizabeth and as some Asian-made cargo that is now shipped to West Coast ports is diverted to the East Coast to avoid the cost of shipping by rail across the country. According to a study done for the North Jersey Transportation Planning Authority, about 6 percent of the cargo now coming into the New York port originates in Asia. That is projected to grow to 13 percent by 2020, according to the study.
The industrial properties are needed, planners said, to unpack goods, like apparel, that arrive in large shipping containers and quickly sort them for shipment to retail stores in the region. "You have to be able to deliver in one or two days," said Joseph Monahan, the director of financial services for Liz Claiborne Inc., at a recent conference on industrial real estate. "Even if your manufacturing base is overseas, you have to be able to deliver in one or two days to meet last minute promotional events."
Indeed, the ability to swiftly ship to stores in New York City or to support the broader Northeast regional market defines the two major industrial areas of the state: the close-in areas in Hudson, Bergen and Essex Counties, including the Meadowlands, and the former farming regions in the middle of the state near Turnpike Exits 8A and 7A. The Meadowlands are New York oriented, while distributors in central New Jersey are generally serving the wider region.
Proximity to the city is why Orix and Rreef, a division of Deutsche Bank, are building on 18.4 acres of land in Carlstadt in the Meadowlands, said Scott Coopchik, a senior vice president of Orix. Distribution centers there are tailored to handle small, expensive goods intended for retailers who like having their warehouse within five miles of the city.
"Firms that have goods that have to be shipped into the city don't want to go to 8A," about 30 miles to the southeast, said Mr. Coopchik. "We are talking about things like pharmaceuticals, eyeglasses and fashions."
Retailers pay for this proximity, Mr. Danzig said. Rental rates in Jersey City or the Meadowlands are $7.50 to $8 a square foot annually compared with $4.50 to $5 a square foot at Exit 8A.
LIKE most new industrial buildings, the Orix structure, to be called the Meadowlands Distribution Center, will be bigger, stronger and taller than most of the existing buildings in the area. Many of these range in size from 50,000 to 75,000 square feet and have ceiling heights of 18 or 20 feet.
"Most buildings are 300,000 to 400,000 square feet now, and we hear of requirements for 1 million square foot buildings," said Eugene A. Preston, vice president for development of the Rockefeller Group Development Corporation. "The 100,000 to 200,000 square foot buildings are on the sublet market."
The new "high cube" Orix building will have 32 feet of clear height below the roof trusses for more efficient storage. The higher roof increases the number of cubic feet of storage space available over the floor, a more efficient layout. The floor itself will be capable of supporting 750 pounds a square foot compared with 250 to 300 pounds per square foot in older structures.
Since it is assumed the building will be operated on three shifts round the clock and employ 600 people to sort and process goods, the parking areas for employees' cars and shippers' trucks are on opposite sides of the building and have separate entrances.
Real estate executives say efforts of New Jersey's state government to limit the sprawl of housing, retail properties, offices and industrial developments in rural areas may force developers to focus on somewhat contaminated sites, known as brownfields, near older urban areas. "If sprawl is restricted, the developers will look at brownfields," said Andrew J. Merrin, an executive vice president of Cushman & Wakefield's financial services group.
Even now, building sites in places like the Meadowlands are scarce enough that brownfield redevelopment is already taking place. "The site was a clay pit in the 1950's," Mr. Coopchik said, speaking of the Orix property. "In the 1960's it was filled with construction debris and then it sat fallow. When we got it, it was still an open landfill."
In recent years, though, technology has been developed to deal with sites of this sort. At the Orix site, the old dumped material was compacted to provide a base suitable to build on, permits and approvals were obtained and foundations are being poured.
Mr. Coopchik said his company was encouraged to build on speculation by the success of local developers like Hartz Mountain Industries and Russo Development that have built warehouses in the area. "These companies put up high cube buildings on spec, and most were leased to one big credit tenant during construction," he said.
He said the company will build the wall and roof of the structure, but will not pour the floor until a tenant is signed, so that piping and conduits to be built into the floor can be custom tailored to the tenant.
Suitable as the location might be to some tenants, the Meadowlands did not appeal to John J. Ling, the vice president for logistics of Crate & Barrel, an upscale furniture and home furnishings retailer. "The Meadowlands are not price competitive if you want to build a big box," he said, "and there are issues involving pilings and floor flatness" related to the marshy land. 
Mr. Ling said the company looked at sites in New York, Pennsylvania and elsewhere in New Jersey before settling on the Rockefeller Group's Foreign Trade Zone in Cranbury near Exit 8A. The new distribution center will consolidate operations from a multilevel furniture warehouse in Elizabeth and a smaller operation in Dayton, N.J., in the 8A area.
Staying in central New Jersey means that the company will be able to hold on to most of its experienced employees, Mr. Ling said. 
The initial 675,000 square feet of development will consist of two buildings: a 300,000-square-foot structure for furniture and a separate 375,000-square-foot building for housewares that will include a 9,000-square-foot retail outlet. The center will handle distribution to retail stores and ship furniture to customers, Mr. Ling said.
The deal includes an option to add 275,000 square feet of additional space, which Mr. Ling said he expected to exercise within two years to bring the complex to 950,000 square feet. The additional space will probably be used to support Internet sales, he said.
Another large structure recently completed in the Exit 8A area, although outside the trade zone, is a 928,000-square-foot distribution center operated by the automaker Volkswagen.
Being in a foreign trade zone is important, Mr. Ling said, to a company that imports 70 to 80 percent of the products it sells. The company currently brings most of its imports through the Chicago area because of Crate & Barrel's roots in the Old Town section of the city, but will shift to New Jersey and West Coast ports in the future, Mr. Ling said.
Being in such a zone allows goods to get off the docks more quickly, simplifies customs paperwork and can result in lower overall tariffs, Rockefeller Group officials say. Their company has operated a similar operation, the International Trade Center in Mount Olive, N.J., near Interstate 80, for 20 years, although that site is oriented more toward manufacturers than distributors.
Foreign trade zones are places where imported goods are treated as if they had not actually come into the country, for purpose of collecting tariffs, Rockefeller Group executives said. They were originally established near ports to facilitate commerce, but have since spread to remote locations.
"We realized that with containerization and interstate highways, there was no need to be near the port," said Leslie E. Smith Jr., senior vice president of Rockefeller Group Development. "Many companies preferred the suburban locations and the good labor force in those locations." The Mount Olive zone is about 50 miles west of the port.
There are more than 200 such zones operating now in the country, with at least one in each state, according to Brandi Hanback of TradeStar Advisory Services, a consultant to the Rockefeller Group. Some $200 billion in merchandise is shipped to trade zones each year, she added.
With much manufacturing having been relocated to foreign countries, many domestic companies have increased the attention they pay to their supply chains, seeking to move goods faster, with as little handling as possible, to control costs. 
F OREIGN trade zones are an opportunity for U.S.-based companies to compete by reducing their costs by deferring or eliminating duty payments and expediting the flow of goods," Ms. Hanback said. "Companies operating in trade zones are well known to Customs, which usually clears containers for shipment without the delays associated with shipments thought to be of higher risk."
Mr. Smith added, "This is a biggie for importers, who have horror stories to tell about delayed shipments."
Once in a zone, goods can be sorted and shipped out within hours, without waiting for documents to be filled out first. "You can file an entry summary at the end of the week, rather than as the shipments arrive," Ms. Hanback said. "This lowers the administrative burden and can save an importer several hundred thousand dollars a year."
Manufacturers in trade zones can take advantage of rules under which finished goods are sometimes charged a lower rate than would have been imposed on the imported components, Mr. Smith said. Distributors can also take advantage of the duty-deferred imports. "If the pink ribbons are not selling, it might be better to destroy them than pay the tariff," he said.
Besides the Mount Olive and 8A zones, the Rockefeller Group operates two foreign trade zones in Florida and one in the St. Louis area and expects to open more in the Chicago area and California. "We have paid a lot of attention to this niche and want to be in most major markets," Mr. Smith said.
Although there is speculative building in the northeast corner of the state, activity in the central portion is dedicated to specific tenants: the Crate & Barrel development at 8A and a building being constructed by Matrix Development for the electrical parts distributor W. W. Grainger at 7A.
"There is no talk of speculative building at 8A and 7A at this time," said Paul D. Cohen, an executive vice president of SBWE, a New Jersey brokerage company, and a specialist in industrial property in the state's midsection. "It's not like it was two and a half years ago, when the buildings were all coming out of the ground."
There are vacancies, he said, but the problem is not so bad that developers are losing control of their buildings to creditors. The major developers, he added, are acquiring building sites and working on planning and permitting so they will be ready to move fast with new projects when the current space is absorbed.
"The strong developers are planning now," he said, "because the New Jersey industrial market is going to be one of the strongest in the country as long as New York City is just across the river."
Orix's decision to follow local developers into the Meadowlands is unusual, real estate executives say, because institutional investors have generally preferred the central part of the state.
"Central New Jersey has been a focus for national REIT's," said Frank V. Caccavo, Jr. an executive director of Cushman & Wakefield, referring to real estate investment trusts. "It gave them access to the population and the work force, and the roads are pretty good."
Howard Freeman, a senior investment officer with First Industrial Realty Trust, a REIT, said, "We are bullish on New Jersey. It is one of our core markets and we want to be active here." He said the company currently owns 3 million square feet of industrial space in the state and is interested in finding opportunities to redevelop older properties if prices are right.
The development of the warehouse and distribution sector reflects changes in the state's overall economic structure, Mr. Merrin said. "In the 1960's and 1970's New Jersey was an industrial state with a mix of manufacturing and distribution," he said. "Then manufacturing shrunk and the office sector grew to the third or fourth largest in the country"
The availability of jobs in those offices spurred the growth of housing and an increasingly affluent population. "The driver of distribution growth is access to the region's population," he said.

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: Pension Group in $176.5 Million Deal; 
U.N. Fund Buys 41st St. Tower

 BODY:
A new 25-story, granite and teal-colored office tower at 222 East 41st Street was bought last week by the United Nations Pension Fund for $176.5 million, according to people with direct knowledge of the deal. 
 The site of the 371,814-square-foot building, which had been a parking lot near an exit to the Queens-Midtown Tunnel, was owned by the Travelers Insurance Company until three years ago. 
Travelers then went into partnership with Tishman Speyer Properties on the construction project. 
 The original deal was viewed as something of a rarity because the building was put up on spec -- with no tenants signed before construction -- and the recession of the early 1990's had left lenders loath to finance any building that did not already have a tenant. But by September 2000, with excavation just beginning, the New York branch of a Cleveland law firm, Jones, Day, Reavis & Pogue, had leased 210,000 square feet, with an Internet company renting about 162,000 square feet, at an annual rent of $55 a square foot. The Internet company later backed out of the deal.
Last year the pension fund entered into negotiations to buy the building. With the law firm in place, U.N. offices will occupy most of the remaining space. Henry Ouma, the fund's investment director, said, "We don't comment on our investments."

HEADLINE: HOME FRONT; 
At Tax Time, a Hidden Silver Lining

BYLINE:  By Terry Pristin 

 BODY:
PROMPTED by a flier that was distributed in his building, Orlando Fonseca went to a Harlem storefront last year to have his 2001 tax returns prepared free of charge through a program sponsored by Community Food Resource Center, a nonprofit organization. To his amazement, he discovered that he was entitled to $2,400 in state and federal earned-income tax credits.
 Mr. Fonseca, who works in a Deutsche Bank mailroom, paid $80 the year before to a commercial tax preparer but was never told about the tax credit, a benefit for low-wage workers. "It helped me catch up on my bills," said Mr. Fonseca, who struggles to support a family on an annual income of $19,000, "and my daughter is getting ready to graduate from high school and wants to go to college." (This year, Mr. Fonseca said, he will get $2,100 back.) 
 About 230,000 low-income New Yorkers who are eligible for earned-income tax credits do not claim them, city officials say. These wage earners forfeit a total of $465 million a year, money that could be poured back into the city's economy. Many of them simply do not file returns, said Amy Brown, the director of social justice for the resource center. "The average person thinks of taxes as something you have to pay, not something where you get money back," she said. There is no civil penalty for failing to file a return if no money is owed. 
This year, city officials say, people like Mr. Fonseca are likely to be bombarded with mailings, fliers and public service announcements built around the image of a waitress holding a tray of $10 and $20 bills and a catchy slogan: "It's your money, come and get it." The publicity is part of a citywide effort to help people take advantage of the tax credits without falling prey to the unscrupulous practices of some commercial tax preparers. Storefronts with volunteer tax preparers offering free services have been set up around the city. Locations can be obtained by calling (212) 487-4444.
Millions of pieces of literature relating to the tax credit, known as E.I.T.C., are being handed out in nine languages, including Albanian and Urdu, that are spoken in the communities where the need is greatest, said Gretchen Dykstra, the commissioner of consumer affairs. "By April 15," she said, "if you don't know what E.I.T.C. is, you've had your head in the sand."
Approved by Congress in 1975 and increased under the Clinton administration, the tax credits are based on income and the number of children living at home. A married couple with two qualifying children, for example, is eligible for the credits if the family income is $34,178 or less. 
The city's campaign has been financed in part with some of the proceeds from a recent settlement obtained by the Department of Consumer Affairs against H & R Block, the tax preparation company. In its lawsuit, the department had accused the company of charging customers exorbitant rates to lend them money in anticipation of refunds and tax credits. The tax-anticipation loans are unnecessary, officials say, because refunds can be obtained in 10 days if the return is filed electronically and the deposit is made directly to a bank account.
The advantages offered by direct deposit have provided an opening for four credit unions operating in poor neighborhoods to take the tax credit campaign one step further. They are sending representatives to the tax centers in the hope of enrolling thousands of new members and teaching them how to save the money they get back from the government. "We are using the E.I.T.C. as an excuse to reach out to the community," said Pablo DeFilippi, the chief executive of Lower East Side People's Federal Credit Union. 
Even though April 15 is more than two months away, the tax-preparation centers are already attracting working people eager to get a refund, Ms. Brown said. "People who hear the message will come out to get their taxes done more quickly," she said.
One person who showed up at the Harlem storefront one evening early in the tax season was Latunji Ceesay, a maintenance worker who earns $18,000 a year. Ms. Ceesay, 31, said she used to rely on a family member to get her taxes done, but then a friend told her she might be able to recover some money. Ms. Ceesay, who has no children, was happy to learn she will receive $700. While at the storefront, she also took opened her first bank account.
"I got two things done," she said, smiling.
