HEADLINE: The View/From North Canaan; 
Restoring a Landmark, A Rail (and Wish) at a Time

BYLINE:  By JEFFREY COHEN 

 BODY:
MORE than a year after the town's social and historic centerpiece was nearly burned down, residents in North Canaan are now hoping to focus on what can be, instead of what used to be. 
 On the grounds of the charred Canaan Union Depot, which was partly destroyed after four boys set fire to it on Oct. 13, 2001, the "for sale" signs are finally out of sight. 
 Last month, the Connecticut Railroad Historical Association bought the building for $325,000.
"It's been too negative for too long," Lyle Kloke, the association's secretary, said as he and members of the group toured the building with an architect on a cold Saturday just days after the official closing. "The thing now is to turn around and turn it into a positive experience." 
Words like "devastating" and "tragedy" peppered a conversation about the downtown station, which was built in 1872 and had been the home to several businesses as well as a main tourist attraction.
Although residents are trying to put the past behind them, it is the past that has made the depot with its two rail lines so special.
"It's still the talk, of how much the town is missing out on the people that used to stop here," said John Humes, whose father, First Selectman Douglas E. Humes, is working on the project. "Now they just pass through.
"I think the sooner the construction starts, the sooner they'll forget about how everything happened."
Douglas Humes put it simply.
"It burned on Oct. 13," he said of the building that is on the state and national registers of historic places. "We would like to put it back the way it was on Oct. 12."
To do that, the association will need to raise $2 million or more, Mr. Humes said, adding that he expects the money to come from fund-raising and grants.
"It has to work, and it will work," he said. "It's very important for the whole community economically."
The events that left less than half of the Victorian station standing has been described by some as a prank gone wrong. 
Four boys, all under age 15, set fire to the depot, said John Foley, the assistant volunteer fire chief and the fire marshal who inspected the blaze. 
"We knew it had a little help, because it was burning from the outside in, and not the inside out," said Mr. Foley. "The strategy was to cut the fire off at the middle and save this half."
Two of the boys, Andrew Anderson and Devin Lyman, were convicted of arson and received a combination of jail time and restitution. The other two boys involved in the fire were tried as juveniles and their cases were sealed.
Besides his fire department work, Mr. Foley, as might be expected in a town of 3,400, balances several other roles, including being treasurer of the railroad historical association, and treasurer of one of the three banks that loaned the association the money to buy the building . 
First Selectman Humes, who is also the vice president of the association, is overseeing the project along with Leroy Riva and Robert Gandolfo. 
The organization hopes to restore the building to what it was with the help of architects from Lee W. Cable, AIA. Plans include a retail store, office space, a railroad museum, a restaurant and a lounge, Mr. Humes said.
"It's gone now, but we knew what was there, and there was a lot of memories there," he said.
Aiden T. Keilty, owner of the burned-out Keilty's Depot, has been interested in moving his restaurant into the station's salvaged section since Day 1, but only now does the possibility of reopening the dining spot that anchored the depot seem like a reality.
"It's been an ordeal," Mr. Keilty said, adding that the fire devastated a business that supported the two families that ran it. "The one thing my wife and I have taken from this whole mess is that things we don't have any control over we don't really get upset at anymore."
After the fire, the building's owners, Paul Ramunni and Ross Grannan, first tried to raise money to restore half of the building. In early 2002, Mr. Ramunni bought out his partner. 
Mr. Ramunni said he faced three main problems: he was underinsured; he could not find contractors willing to work for what he could afford; and he did not have nonprofit status, making him ineligible for grant money or low-interest loans.
With the money Mr. Ramunni got from the insurance, he demolished the burned wing and the tower that united it and the north-south wing, which all cost about $200,000. But even after architects drew up restoration plans, it just came time to sell, he said.
"I just realized that I was trying to jam a round peg into a square hole and I wasn't able to do it," Mr. Ramunni said.
As for the depot, Mr. Kloke recalled what is was like having another restaurant within walking distance in town.
"It was nice to be able to walk down on a snowy evening, have an after-dinner drink and a cup of coffee, and walk home in the snow," he said. "I can't do that anymore."
William Adam, a retired surgeon who is on the association's board, grew up here, like his father and grandfather.
For Mr. Adam, memories of the station include his neighbor Victor Coe, a ticketmaster and telegraph operator, and the July4 fireworks he ordered as a child that arrived by rail. 
"Canaan is not a very vocal town like a lot of these other towns, but we have a lot of pride," he said.
Mr. Adam also owns the town's only winery, the Land of Nod, and has pledged to make a new label with the depot on it. He said he hopes to give 10 percent of the proceeds from the label to the restoration effort. But at $12 a bottle, the association will have to look to more than wine sales to raise enough money to restore the building.
"Hopefully, with the change in ownership, people will be a little more forthcoming with donations," Mr. Kloke said, adding that people may have been less likely to donate money to a commercial project for which they would not get a tax deduction.
Mr. Adam agreed.
"It wasn't a good arrangement for anybody," he said.

HEADLINE: Catch a Movie, or Maybe 50 

BYLINE:  By GARY SANTANIELLO 

 BODY:
DESPITE a difficult economic environment for many arts organizations, the Director's View Film Festival is offering an ambitious new documentary program this week in addition to its full schedule of film screenings, awards, panel discussions, receptions and galas.
 Founded in 1999 by Robert Kesten, a former actor and documentary producer, the film festival honors and celebrates directors' contributions to filmmaking, while seeking to create a permanent film presence in the region through its program of screenings, conferences, seminars and educational programs in local schools. 
 Mr. Kesten, who lives in South Salem, N.Y., said he hoped that attendance, which reached 10,000 in 2002, would grow again this year over the five days of events, from Thursday through Monday, in Greenwich, Stamford, South Norwalk, New Canaan and Westport. 
"It has been tough economically all around, but we hope the community support will be there again this year," he said. "We think we're offering something special."
The studio premiere of "Daredevil" will open the festival Thursday night at the Crown Regent Theater in South Norwalk. The movie stars Ben Affleck and
Joe Pantoliano, a Weston resident and festival board member. Tickets are available at various locations in South Norwalk.
One of the festival's honorees this year is Arthur Penn, who will receive the Joseph L. Mankiewicz Award for artistic integrity and excellence. Estelle Parson, who won an Oscar for her performance in Mr. Penn's 1967 classic "Bonnie and Clyde," will introduce Mr. Penn Friday night at a screening of his 1975 film noir "Night Moves" starring Gene Hackman. Mr. Penn, 80, will be honored at a black-tie dinner later that night at the Stamford Marriott. 
On Saturday night, Lisa Cholodenko will be given the Dorothy Arzner Prize for women who are filmmakers after a screening of her new film "Laurel Canyon" at the Crown Theater in Greenwich. The movie is about the relationship of a mother (Frances McDormand) with her conservative son and his bride-to-be (Kate Beckinsale). It will be released nationally in March by Sony Picture Classics. Other festival programs include one featuring new films by first-time directors from around the world; one called the International Student Film Festival, which presents the work of filmmakers 19 years old and under; and the Community Film Project, which will unveil two locally produced films, one based on the play "Our Town" and the other on the short story "The Lottery."
The documentary division, initiated by the Weston resident and documentary filmmaker Amy van Daalen, attracted 150 entries from around the world and will showcase more than 20 documentaries over the final two days. Albert Maysles, a documentary pioneer, will be honored on Monday night.
Mr. Kesten said he was surprised not only by the number of documentaries entered, but by "the outrageous quality of the work. So many of them were so good."
"For many filmmakers, documentaries are a real important way of entering the industry," he added, "and it's an area that's growing by leaps and bounds. Many cable channels, for example, are looking for the work of documentarians."
Ms. Van Daalen, whose documentaries have appeared on PBS and National Geographic television, said her vision "was to show the versatility of the documentary form --historical, investigative, humorous, experimental. " About 20 documentaries will be shown during the festival, running the gamut from "Nine Good Teeth," about the filmmaker's 102-year-old Italian-American grandmother to the Finnish film "Cleaning Up!", which follows the rock band Cleaning Women as it tours Eastern Europe, playing instruments made of old cleaning equipment. "The music is quite wonderful, actually," Ms. van Daalen said.
The directors of all but a few of the documentaries will be on hand for question and answer sessions after the screenings. 
Films by women, in particular, are a programming priority at the festival, particularly through the Women In Film series. 
"My feeling is that women are being left out of the industry mix, to a large degree," said Mr. Kesten. "Per capita, more women were directing in the silent era than today, but they bring a unique sensibility to their art."
One other goal of the festival is to secure a permanent site, but until then, it will continue to spread across towns in Fairfield County. As Mr. Kesten put it, "If people won't come to Muhammad, Muhammad will come to the people." 
To order tickets for the festival, call (914) 533-0270 or visit www.dvff.org. Information may also be obtained by sending an e-mail message to info@thedirectorsview.com. There will be approximately 130 films shown, including independent, student films, documentaries, premieres and the films of Arthur Penn. Ticket prices range from free to $20 (for the opening-night premiere of "Daredevil." Prices for the various seminars, receptions and galas vary widely.

Arthur Penn, left, will also be honored during the festival. He will receive the Joseph L. Mankiewicz Award for artistic integrity and excellence. HEADLINE: In Newtown, A Master Plan Creates a Stir 

BYLINE:  By NANCY DONIGER 

 BODY:
IT has been a long debate. 
 In 2001, Newtown negotiated an agreement with the state to purchase 186 acres and associated buildings that belonged to the now defunct Fairfield Hills mental hospital and has since been trying to figure out what to do with the property. 
 Now, the town has come up with a plan, which will be presented to the Board of Selectmen on March 3 for approval. 
Taxpayers will also have an opportunity to vote on the plan at a public meeting, although no date has been set. But no one expects the debate to end even after the voting. 
The centerpiece of the town's master plan for the property -- and one of its controversial elements -- is a new $8.5 million, 40,000-square-foot Town Hall overlooking a town green. The plan also calls for the construction of seven ball fields, preservation of buildings deemed worthy for economic development and demolition of the most severely deteriorated buildings. 
The eight buildings earmarked for economic development would be used for town purposes or leased or sold to private industry. 
The town's Fairfield Hills Master Plan Committee spent 10 months and held 24 meetings to develop the plan for the property, which the town will take ownership of in June. The committee invited 45 community groups to make presentations, held two workshops, played host to a tour and produced a video for broadcast on local access television. 
Still, a group called the Friends of Fairfield Hills does not care for the plan. The members oppose the sale of any buildings, and go even further: they want the entire property retained for town use, with very limited commercial use.
Robert Geckle, chairman of the master plan committee, grew up in Fairfield Hills. His father, George Geckle, was the hospital's chief administrative officer for 30 years when it was at its peak, with 4,000 patients and 2,000 staff members.
"When I was growing up I never dreamed the hospital would some day shut down," he said. "We aren't trying to decide everything now. We're going ahead with the playing fields, Town Hall and purchase, but will leave other decisions to the future." 
First Selectman Herb Rosenthal said: "I feel the committee has done a great job listening to the public and incorporating flexibility for the future. Where we are almost parallels what the Friends of Fairfield Hills outlined. We're also taking into account other people who are concerned about the tax base. We're not recommending factories or light industrial uses. We're recommending offices that would offer services that are desirable to have."
Earlier versions of the master plan contained residential development that has since been eliminated in response to a negative reaction fromtaxpayers.
"We had strong feedback against including any housing," Mr. Geckle said. "People also were vehemently opposed to selling any of the land to assure the town keeps control of it."
Although the master plan does not recommend housing, it is permitted under the town's zoning regulations for Fairfield Hills.
Also eliminated from the draft was an idea to build an office park on the campus's west meadow.
"We will leave the high meadow as open space, although future generations will have options to use it if the need arises," Mr. Geckle said.
Fairfield Hills originally comprised 800 acres the state purchased in 1929. A community unto itself, the hospital was designed to look like a college campus rather than an institution. 
After closing the hospital in 1995, state officials determined that the buildings and grounds were surplus and offered them for sale, giving the town the first right of refusal. Residents voted in June 2001 to purchase 186 acres and associated buildings for $3.9 million. The purchase was part of an overall $48.7 million bonding package that contained two related resolutions. 
The first, for $21.7 million, includes the $3.9 million purchase price, plus financing for the master plan, playing fields, asbestos removal, building renovation and demolition and environmental insurance. Another $27 million resolution was approved for a new intermediate school, which opened on the campus in January. 
Ruby Johnson, who heads the Friends of Fairfield Hills, and has been a resident of Newtown for 36 years, was a driving force behind the town purchase. The town already owns 100 acres of the former hospital land, which was acquired by State Representative Julia Wasserman and her 1994 Task Force to Study the Re-Use of Fairfield Hills State, bringing the town's holdings to about 300 acres, in addition to 300 acres deeded to the Department of Agriculture. 
Harrall-Michalowski Associates Inc. of Hamden prepared the master plan for the committee, emphasizing a philosophy of flexibility, leaving 72 percent of the acreage as open space, recreation fields or land banked for future use, while preserving the architectural and design characteristics of the campus.
Ms. Johnson does not believe the master plan committee listened closely enough to what residents had to say when they addressed the group. The Friends of Fairfield Hills want Mr. Rosenthal to form a cultural arts commission to solicit grants and do its own fund-raising.
Although the bond issue does not include funds to renovate any of the buildings for recreational or arts purposes, Ms. Johnson is confident that the artists, dancers, potters, woodworkers, sports enthusiasts and thespians in town who want space will make it happen.
"We see this land in the heart of town that should be used for the desires of the people," she said. "Democracy works from the bottom up, not from the top down. People who care should have the freedom to take their ideas and make them work." 
A private citizen has already offered to contribute $500,000 toward a recreational center, she said. The Friends of Booth Library have been holding their annual book sale at Bridgeport Hall, a building earmarked in the master plan for private development and town use. Ms. Johnson would like to see the building retained for the book sale, cultural arts and for the growing senior citizen population, which has outgrown the present senior center. 
"People have been led to believe that we can make a lot of money out of Fairfield Hills, but they've fallen for a false expectation," she said. "It takes $1.6 million of tax revenue just to reduce taxes by one mill. The tax revenue that could be generated is not enough to affect the needs of the town. If we don't save the land, where will we be able to build another new school when we need one?"
The Friends of Fairfield Hills disagree with the proposal to build a new town hall. They want to see an existing building, either Shelton or Canaan House, renovated at lower cost than new construction, as approved through the bond issue. 
Mr. Geckle said the master plan would accommodate either renovating an existing building or constructing a new one.
Ms. Wasserman said she would like to see the whole process slow down for a time.
"The state budget is in dire straits," she said. "Newtown as the 12th wealthiest community in Connecticut and can expect to get a minimum amount of state aid -- even less than in the past. We shouldn't spend the money in the bonding package now. This isn't the year to do it."
Mr. Rosenthal disagreed.
"The money has already been approved," he said. "The good news is that since we don't get much state money. I'm unhappy that we lose any, but it's not significant."
Robert Hennessey, who moved to Newtown five years ago, said he supports the group's initiative to retain the campus for town use.
"Decisions are being made too quickly," he said. "The voices of residents are not always heard. The consultant is presenting choices based on what the first selectman wants. This is an election year, and he is looking to rush this through, to leave a legacy."
Meanwhile, Mr. Rosenthal has voiced displeasure with the criticism that has been directed at the committee and its master plan.
"The vast majority of the people are happy with the plan," he said. "Attempts have been made by certain individuals who are not getting 100 percent of what they want to try to undermine the good work the committee has done.
Ms. Johnson said: "We have a motto that we say at the end of all our meetings: Keep Newtown rural. Keep Fairfield Hills green."

Ruby Johnson, below, heads a group that is opposed to some of the town's redevelopment plans. (Photographs by Joseph Kugielsky for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: RELIGION; 
The Archbishop Speaks

BYLINE:  By JILL P. CAPUZZO 

 BODY:
WITH liturgical music playing in the background, the archbishop of Newark assured about a million Catholics last Sunday that their contributions to his annual fund appeal would not be used to defend priests accused of sexual abuse or to suppress their accusers.
 "Let me once again assure you that not a penny of our ordinary income has ever been used to silence victims of abuse by our priests," Archbishop John J. Myers said in his appeal for donations, which was distributed by videotape to the 235 Catholic churches in the Newark Archdiocese and played by most of them at Sunday services. 
The decision to include such a direct statement in the message had been recommended by members of the archdiocese development group because of the concerns of many churchgoers about where their pledge dollars were going, said Jim Goodness, a spokesman for the archdiocese. He said four dozen to five dozen parishioners had written letters saying they were rethinking their commitment to the church after the sexual abuse scandal broke last year. 
"A number of donors have raised that issue: how much of what has been raised is going toward settlements?" he said. "We felt it was necessary to give reassurance that the money is used wisely, providently, and for the ministries of the people."
The annual drive is intended to benefit programs like bereavement ministry and marriage preparation classes, as well as for training seminarians and for general administration of the archdiocese, Mr. Goodness said. The archdiocese's insurance policy pays for settlements or for defending priests accused of sexual abuse, he said but acknowledged that premiums for that are part of general administration costs. 
Ben Cotton, leader of the New Jersey chapter of the Survivors Network of Those Abused by Priests, a national group based in Chicago, said it did not surprise him that the archbishop would address the abuse issue directly in his annual appeal.
"Every diocese across the country has been hurt financially by the scandal, and one of the reasons is that the parishioners don't want to pay for the cover-up of priests," Mr. Cotton said. "I don't know if it's in the mind-set of the parishioners to begrudge the survivors their settlements. But apparently whoever is advising the archdiocese on collection policy priorities thought that this would appeal to the flock."
In 2002, about 60,000 people pledged donations in response to the archbishop's appeal, raising $12 million, said Deacon Joe Dwyer, executive director of development for the archdiocese. (This does not include millions of dollars donated in weekly collections at the parishes of Essex, Union, Hudson and Bergen counties, some of which is turned over to the archdiocese.) Over the last couple years, pledge donations have dropped 3 percent to 5 percent, Mr. Dwyer said. 
"Our goal for 2003 is to achieve 10 percent more than last year, but we'd like to at least hold the line in terms of our donor base and the dollars raised," Mr. Dwyer said.
After a conference of bishops last summer in Dallas, Archbishop Myers also issued a videotaped message to the parishes addressing the sexual abuse issue and detailing the church's plans for handling it. But that tape reached a small percentage of the 1.3 million Catholics in the Newark Archdiocese, church officials said. 
At St. Helen's Church in Bogota, the post-conference tape was shown on a weeknight to about 45 people. The annual appeal tape was shown at all six services last Sunday, reaching 3,200 parishioners, said Msgr. William Harms, who called it "a good move."
"We've had letters galore, visits and angry people on the subject," he said. "People are still very interested, and the church is trying to assure them that their contributions are going to be put to good use."
Between the weakened economy and the abuse scandal, Monsignor Harms said, church attendance and giving have declined at St. Helen's, which serves 3,600 families. From the fall of 2001 to last fall, the church lost about 300 churchgoers and $1,000 to $1,200 in weekly donations, he said.
Msgr. Tom Ivory at the Church of the Presentation in Upper Saddle River agreed that it was a good idea for the archbishop to address the abuse issue directly. He said about 200 people showed up last fall for an open forum on the subject at his church.
"It's still in people's minds," he said. "I think it was wise to let people know where the money is not going as well as where it is going." 
Being upfront about how funds are spent has always been the policy of the Paterson Diocese, according to Marianna Thompson, the director of communications there. As spelled out in its financial report, published in a newsletter last week, the diocese has spent $2.4 million over the last 40 years in settlements, legal fees, therapy and support services for priests accused of sexual abuse.
"Our position has been to answer any question someone might have, and that applies to financial statements as well," she said. "Openness should lead to affirmation and restoring the faith of our people."

CORRECTION-DATE: February 16, 2003

 CORRECTION:
An article last Sunday about assurances from the archbishop of Newark that contributions would not go toward the defense of priests accused of sexual abuse misstated the location of St. Helen's Church, one of those where the videotaped appeal was shown. It is in Westfield, not Bogota.

HEADLINE: ON POLITICS; 
The Prisoner of the State House

BYLINE:  By Laura Mansnerus 

 BODY:
AS he sat in one of those paneled rooms in the governor's inner office the other morning, James E. McGreevey looked like a sergeant who had just been forced to gun down civilians. In fact, the previous day he had just been forced to deliver the budget address.
 "We did what was necessary," the governor said, when asked how he felt about what should have been the worst day -- among many dreadful ones -- of his 13 months in office. It was also a day, as it happened, when about 4,000 doctors lined the street beneath his State House window, shouting about malpractice insurance rates. 
 What was necessary, in his opinion, was telling the people who elected him -- union members, retirees in trailer parks, marginally employed sick people, lovers of art and culture -- that the state cannot do much for them anymore. 
Mr. McGreevey had made his choice. Rather than raise sales or income taxes, a move that cost Jim Florio re-election 10 years ago, he would, he said over and over, exercise fiscal discipline.
But Mr. McGreevey, running a state where taxpayers give a lot and expect a lot, faces a fact that few predecessors have had to give serious thought to: fiscal discipline can get a governor thrown out, too.
When he talks about axing his constituencies, Mr. McGreevey is indignant, even stirring, at least for a man who almost never leaves the house without a stiffly starched white shirt, red rep tie and three-pointed handkerchief in the breast pocket of his dark suit. Ending grants for the arts is "incredibly painful," he said. The cuts in health care for poor adults are "atrocious."
But he cannot help pleading about the severity of economic conditions, which are truly difficult and overwhelming, but boring. The tax increases needed to close the 50 states' collective deficits, he said, "can exacerbate the contractionary tendencies in the economy and have a negative impact upwards of $150 billion on the gross domestic product." Next came Keynesian models and intergovernmental transfers. 
A few chairs down from the governor was John McCormac, the state treasurer. Mr. McCormac, who has done much to keep this government stitched together, seems to wear an expression of faint incredulity, as if he cannot quite believe he let anybody pitch him into this sinkhole.
"The executive branch has been cut two years in a row," Mr. McCormac said. "It's been a long time since anybody's seen the cost of running the government itself down two years in a row."
Mr. McGreevey interjected, ""It may go back to Governor Meyner," he said, referring to Robert B. Meyner, who was New Jersey's governor from 1954 to 1962.
There was more. The two of them volunteered that next year may not be any better, and the year after that does not look good.
Which leaves Mr. McGreevey, in 2005, to campaign on a record of lopping the near-poor from health insurance rolls, freezing nursing home payments, starving small theater groups and historical societies and pledging away the proceeds that the state was to get from tobacco companies over 30 years. 
Property taxes will have risen, and the governor will have cut property-tax relief, too, canceling the scheduled increases in people's yearly checks and eliminating the rebates altogether for those making more $100,000 a year. (There you have a good portion of the state's McMansion population, which has been surprisingly friendly to Democrats recently.)
Except for Gray Davis, who has to find an additional $35 billion for California, Mr. McGreevey may have the worst job in state government anywhere.
So what else is he supposed to do?
The easiest answer is what is being called the "millionaire's tax," which would raise marginal income-tax rates on high incomes. A liberal research organization in Trenton, New Jersey Policy Perspective, proposes to raise the top tax rate, now 6.37 percent, to 7 percent on incomes over $500,000 and 8 percent on incomes over $1 million.
The plan would raise a few hundred million dollars a year, far too little to balance the budget, and like any tax increase it would put a bit of a drag on the economy. But most economists say it is relatively harmless because it takes money that would probably not be usefully spent anyway. 
For a hypothetical couple earning $800,000 a year, the increase would be $1,890 --or about the difference between a new BMW X5 with a navigation system and a new BMW X5 with a seat pocket for maps.
When asked what there is not to like about this, a healthy majority of voters, at least when polled, support the notion. Some legislators support it, too, most notably the Assembly speaker, Albio Sires, from West New York, in a largely BMW-free district. 
But taxing rich people is not easy, says Senator Wayne Bryant, a Democrat from Camden who is co-chairman of the budget committee. As he put it, it is one thing to look at polls, and another to face the power of the well-heeled and their representatives.
Governor Florio's income-tax increase affected 15 percent of the population, Mr. Bryant said, but after enough wailing the increase "drove the other 85 percent crazy." 
Back in the governor's office, Mr. McGreevey sighed when asked if he favored any redistribution of the tax burden.
"Our perspective is not so much a grandiose discussion as to the equitable nature of tax policy," he said. "Our focus is a much more mundane, and basic requirement, that is, to balance the budget."All right. Some people say that when enough pain registers, the public will demand higher taxes --on someone --and Mr. McGreevey will capitulate. Some people say that has been his strategy all along.
What does Mr. McGreevey make of that? 
"Fundamentally," he answered, "we have to become fiscally disciplined."

HEADLINE: A Costly Battle Whose End May Be Near 

BYLINE:  By GEORGE JAMES 

DATELINE: EAST RUTHERFORD 

 BODY:
THE clock is running out on a high-stakes contest in the Meadowlands Sports Complex, one that has often seemed like a good old-fashioned New Jersey street brawl -- complete with boasts and taunts. 
 Come Wednesday, the long-running battleto redevelop the 106-acre Continental Airlines Arena site -- current home of the New Jersey Nets basketball and Devils hockey teams, which are expected to move to a new arena in Newark by 2005 -- may be over. 
 That is the day the commissioners of the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority are expected to announce the selection of what they consider the best of three proposals for the site, ending the warring by two of the developers as well as the stream of endorsements by any number of civic organizations and countless politicians.
To some observers, the lineup of prominent Democrats gathering behind a plan offered up by Mills Corporation of Arlington, Va., and the Mack Cali Realty Corporation in Cranford is as good an indication as any of which way the authority, led by George Zoffinger, its president and chief executive, is leaning. 
At stake is tens of millions of dollars in contracts, at least 20,000 construction jobs and perhaps as many permanent positions once the project is completed by 2011. Regardless of which one of three elaborate plans is chosen, hundreds of millions of dollars in income and sales taxes will be generated during construction over the next 10 years. In addition, 13 surrounding towns will get tens of millions of dollars in payments in lieu of taxes during that period, and millions more every year. 
"We think we have enough information to make a sound decision," said Mr. Zoffinger. 
Will the winner be Meadowlands Xanadu, a $1.3 billion pleasure dome rendered by Mills even though its competitor,-- Hartz Mountain Industries of Secaucus, claims the proposed project of offices, hotel and entertainment center, including indoor skiing and a minor league ball park, is nothing more than a mega-mall in disguise? 
Will it be Expo Park, the $815 million plan by Hartz Mountain and its partner, Forest City Ratner Companies, of Cleveland, with its mix of convention space, hotels, offices, stores and an indoor Formula One-style race track?
Or will it go to Arena Place -- the $989 million complex of offices, hotels, and refurbished arena that would hold, among other things, a 6,200-seat performing center -- proposed by the Westfield Group of Los Angeles? 
As Mr. Zoffinger scurried from one meeting to another last week, conferring with members of a citizens advisory committee, environmental and labor groups and a gathering of about 80 elected officials ranging from mayors and council members to state legislators, Mr. Zoffinger was careful not to reveal which project had the edge.
But regardless of which plan was chosen, he said, "It will have a tremendous economic impact on this region."
"I expect the state is not only going to get significant payment for the use of its land, which will go to pay off the accumulated debt that's choked the sports authority," he added, referring to the $160 million debt on the arena. "But there will also be a significant amount of property tax reduction in each of the surrounding communities."' 
Mr. Zoffinger's circumspection did nothing to discourage speculation over which developer would land the lucrative contract. Hartz -- because it is the biggest private landowner in the Meadowlands and is a major Democratic contributor -- would appear to have the inside track. But Mills, which had been seen as being closely aligned with the previous Republican administration in Trenton -- has spent a great deal of money on public relations efforts and newspaper advertisements extolling Xanadu. 
Moreover, Mills, in the competition to secure the most endorsements, has received the nodfrom such Democrats as Albio Sires, the Assembly speaker, and Bernard F. Kenny, Jr., co-majority leader in the state Senate, both of Hudson County, and Dennis McNerney, the new Bergen County executive.
Bob Sommer, a Mills spokesman, said that officials from the company made it a point to meet with everyone they could to extol the virtues of Xanadu, and added, "So it was relatively easy to get endorsements when political leaders saw their suggestions included in our plans."
Mills undoubtedly got some some bounce by teaming up with the Giants football organization, the primary tenant in the sports complex, which has endorsed the Xanadu plan.
Another seeming Mills advantage is its offer to deed to the state a 600-acre environmentally sensitive swath of land in the Meadowlands called the Empire Tract, where Mills had wanted to build a mall. That offer is contingent on whether Mills gets the contract for the arena site. 
To offset the momentum that Mills has been building, Hartz has recently run a series of advertisements in New Jersey newspapers criticizing the Mills plan as nothing more than a glorified mall. One ad, for instance, asked, "Will this mall be 1.5 million square feet of true entertainment and if so, what are the attractions?" 
To mitigate the advantage Mills might have with its negotiable tract of swamp, Hartz has offered to donate 93 acres of wetlands that it owns. 
Whichever bidder comes up with the contract, some fear that the resulting bitterness could be challenged in the courts. It is just those kinds of concerns that have led to talk of the authority choosing more than one developer for the project -- a shot-gun wedding of the two noisiest combatants, Mills and Hartz, or even a threesome with Westfield.
But Mr. Zoffinger insists that will not happen. 
"I have always said that this is a large enough project to satisfy a lot of companies, and it would be best if they came together and worked out some joint solution," said Mr. Zoffinger. "So far that has not happened. And frankly, we will just move forward in choosing one developer."'
No matter which developer is chosen, this project will hardly appear overnight. In fact, a completion date of of 2011 is the one most commonly cited. To get to that point, Mr. Zoffinger said he wanted to have "a shovel in the ground by late spring." 
Once the authority makes its selection, the commissioners will meet with the developer to make certain that the financial guarantees are accurate, and negotiations on the final agreement will begin. 
Of course, that is just one aspect of this two-carom shot. Discussions about the proposed arena in Newark for the Nets and Devils -- whose fate has been wedded to whatever happened up in Bergen County -- have been continuing. Most recently, Mayor Sharpe James of Newark boasted that YankeeNets, the organization that owns the Nets and Devils, was about a month from announcing an agreement to build the $355 million arena.
Still, Mr. Zoffinger emphasized that even if an an arena in Newark never gets built, the future of those two franchises will not affect the development in the Meadowlands; the teams will only be playing in the Continental Arena through 2005. The New Jersey Legislature debated the Newark arena for almost two years before turning it down last June. Bergen officials had fought against it, contending that there could be no deal until there was a workable plan for the Continental Arena. 
The impasse ended in August when Newark got a $165 million cash settlement from the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey that would gotoward the arena's cost in return for an extended lease at the Newark Liberty International Airport.
Since then there have been few details about the Newark plan as Mayor James and officials of YankeeNets have been meeting to negotiate details. 
Even before the deal between Newark and the Port Authority, the New Jersey Sport and Exposition Authority had been seeking proposals for the Meadowlands arena site. And on Sept. 19, it announced that six had submitted proposals. After oral arguments in mid-October, the number was cut to three in late November. Since then the authority has asked for further refinements of the plans, including more information on the financing of the project, the income the authority could expect and rail and road improvements to the site. 
Westfield, which has silently stayed above the fray involving Hartz and Mills, describes its 4-million-square-foot Arena Place project as "an urban entertainment concept" complete with a town square. 
As for the existing arena, it would be refurbished to create a 250,000-square-foot structure that could house a performing area able to seat up to 6,200 and feature entertainment like Cirque du Soleil or concerts 120 days a year. The space could also be used for business seminars. 
The plan calls for 2.2-million square feet of office space -- three 10-story office buildings, two 8-story office buildings, a 15-story office building and an 18-story office building. There would also be a 500-room conference hotel, a 300-room business hotel and a 200-room extended-stay hotel. 
In addition, there would be a 76,000-square-foot multiplex cinema, 100,000 square feet of restaurants and 260,000 square feet of retail space.
As an enticement to those concerned about the effects on the environment, Westfield has said that Arena Place would be the only project that would not require a tidal wetland of eight acres east of the current arena to be covered and filled. As a result, company officials said, they would be able to build the project that much more quickly. On top of that, the company would contribute $7 million toward wetlands protection.
"We have the best environmental solution because we're maintaining the wetlands on the arena site as well as contributing substantial funds to the authority so they can best determine what surrounding wetlands to acquire and protect," said John Goodwin, Westfield's vice president for development.
William Sheehan, the Hackensack Riverkeeper, said environmentalists would pay close attention to how the winning developer dealt with the eight-acre wetland.
"Our concern is that the redevelopment of the land near the arena has to be done in an environmentally sensitive way," Mr. Sheehan said. 
Under the Hartz-Forest Ratner plan, called Expo Park, the arena would become a 500,000-square-foot convention center geared to attract visitors from across the country, said Emanuel Stern, the president of Hartz.
According to Mr. Stern, surrounding the center would sit four office buildings, each eight or nine stories, and two four-star hotels, also eight or nine stories, for a total of 1,200 rooms. Of the total 4.1 million square feet in the project, 2 million square feet would be given over to offices and 700,000 square feet to hotels.
About 478,000 square feet would go to entertainment and include a Formula One-style racing center (with cars slightly larger than go-carts), a skating park with a restaurant service that catered to skateboarders and roller-bladers, an arcade with games and a restaurant/pub and a movie complex. The 75,000 square feet of restaurants and 356,000 square feet of retail would be tied to a sports theme.
Mr. Stern sees his company as the home team that "understands the local and regional landscape," with more than a dozen properties in New York and New Jersey, such as the Soho Grand and Tribeca Grand in Manhattan and office buildings in the Meadowlands, including One Harmon Tower and Harmon Meadow Office Complex. 
And he said that his company was the only bidder that strictly followed the criteria that the authority set up in its requests for proposals. As to whether that would be the basis for a suit if Hartz doesn't get the contract, he said, "I'm not crossing that bridge until I come to it, and I hope I never have to think about it."
To date, Hartz's Expo Park has been endorsed by the New Jersey Thoroughbred Horsemen's Association and the Standardbred Breeders and Owners Association of New Jersey, two groups that Mr. Stern said had extra clout because the racetrack was the top revenue producer in the sports complex. 
But from the company's standpoint, the main selling point is the convention hall. 
"Family entertainment centers and office parks are not traditionally complementary," said Mr. Stern. "And the best chance of getting absorption of the office product rests on there being a business catalyst, and that's what the convention center is."
Then there is Xanadu from the Mills Corporation and Mack-Cali, a 4.76-million square-foot project that consists of four office buildings, each 11 or 12 stories, and a 520-room hotel occupying 1.76 million square feet and 500,000 square feet respectively.
The developers say that more than half the space of the project --2.5 million square feet -- is a "family entertainment component," although 700,000 feet of that is mostly devoted to retail use by high end stores like the British department store Harrods.. 
There would be a sports and recreation zone and a "kids" zone, says Michael Luchkiw, a land use lawyer with DeCotiis, Fitzpatrick & Gluck, an influential law firm in Teaneck.
Among 20 recreational and entertainment sites are an indoor ski slope, an aquarium in the shape of a tunnel, an indoor city for children in which they take on adult occupations roles like bakers and actually bake, an indoor wave surfing facility, a museum of the state's wildlife and the Meadowlands YMCA.
In addition, Mills has also proposed a minor league baseball stadium to seat 6,000 to 8,000 people despite the fact that there already is a minor league team, the Newark Bears, nearby.
As for the Continental Arena, the developers said they would leave it intact should the Nets and Devils decide to stay, but could retrofit it if necessary for conversion to a convention hall. 
As for the Empire tract, Mr. Luchkiw said Mills would again try to build a mall on the site, as it originally intended, if Xanadu was not selected by the authority.
According to figures released last week by the authority, Xanadu would generate nearly twice as much in taxes in the first 10 years as the other two, about $860.7 million, as against $467.8 million by Arena Place and $429 million by Expo Park.
In terms of the economic impact once the businesses are up and running, Xanadu would generate $2.29 billion a year beginning in 2012; Arena Place $958.4 million a year by 2011; and Expo Park $867.6 million a year by 2012.
Arena Place, however, would produce the most full-time jobs by 2011, a total of 22,418, compared with 19,498 by Xanadu and 15,250 by Expo Park in 2012.
Municipalities around the site will share $85 million to $126 million in the first 10 years of construction and operation -- payment in lieu of taxes -- and $12 million to $16.5 million in the 11th year with an escalating sum thereafter.
Mr. Zoffinger said the battling advertisements and the endorsements created a climate that made the selection job more difficult but in the end had no effect on the authority's decision.
"We based our decision on only four things: the economic benefit to the region; the actual amount the sports authority will get for leasing the land, the environmental impact on the region and the number of jobs construction and permanent jobs," he said.
David Listokin, an expert in land use regulation and co-director of the Center for Urban Policy Research at Rutgers University, said that the selection process, despite its drawbacks, seemed "reasonable."
"These are not easy choices," Professor Listokin said. "You have something there now that was kind of conventional when it was developed 15 or 20 year ago, but the world has changed; how we use space has changed." 
He added, "It's a big project with big impact, and this is the process by which we select and evaluate big projects in the United States."
After all is said and done, Mr. Zoffinger, a former developer himself, said he hoped that the winning project would be evaluated as "a job generator, an economic boon to the area."
"I hope," he said, "some 25 years from now that people will look back and say, 'You know, they did the right thing for the state."'

HEADLINE: IN BUSINESS; 
Wall Street North

BYLINE:  By MAREK FUCHS 

 BODY:
STOCKS were first traded underneath a buttonwood tree on Wall Street in 1792, and for a long time afterward, the financial industry was centered within the narrow canyons of Lower Manhattan.
 In the past half century, however, because of a need for more space, the flexibility afforded by computerization and, more recently, Sept. 11, Wall Street began to spread wider. The industry first went north -- to Midtown -- but soon trading desks, retail brokerage branches and back offices took root in New Jersey, Long Island and Westchester. 
 For Westchester, the growth in the financial sector in the last 15 years has been steady, and includes what officials describe as their prize catch: 2,000 jobs coming from Morgan Stanley, which lost 1.2 million square feet of space and 13 employees in the World Trade Center attack. In March 2002, the company bought the former Texaco world headquarters in Harrison, which it is upgrading. The four-story, O-shaped building, with a courtyard that will be turned into a trading desk, was built in 1977 and is 27 miles north of Morgan Stanley's headquarters at 1585 Broadway in New York City. About 20 Morgan Stanley employees are now at the site, working on transition issues, and the company expects 750 employees to arrive in the fall. 
"The financial industry is a mainstay of our economy and the Morgan Stanley purchase was a very important economic development," said Marsha Gordon, the president of the Westchester County Chamber of Commerce. "That is one of our prime properties." 
The building, which is 725,000 square feet, sits on 107 acres. Texaco left the site in 2001, after merging Chevron. 
Morgan Stanley will move senior management and support staff from its individual investor group into the retrofitted building, as well as 700 institutional traders, salespeople and support staff. Mindful of the terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center, the company may keep some seats open in case of an emergency at another location. 
The company had originally intended to use a one million square-foot office tower t it built at 745 Seventh Avenue. But the 32-story building was only a block from Morgan Stanly's existing headquarters and the company thought that such a concentration of space would be too big of a risk. They sold the building to Lehman Brothers a month after the terrorist attacks. 
Sal Carrera, the county's director of economic development and real estate, said that since Morgan Stanley's purchase, up to half of the businesses that contact his office about moving to the county are financial firms. "Westchester can become a mini-New York City," he said. "We don't intend for it to take the place of the city, which will always be the center," but Westchester can provide a lower-cost alternative and serve as a backup location, he said. "If God forbid, there is another terrorist attack, you can still be up and running," he added.
But becoming even more of a financial hub by providing an alternative to New York City in the aftermath of Sept. 11 is a touchy subject for local officials.
"We never poach," Mr. Carrera said. "We just wait for phone calls." 
When the phone does ring, the county is ready with a bag of goodies. This can include mortgage tax forgiveness, low-cost electricity, sales tax abatement on equipment, access to grants, funds for training and help with commuting. The Westchester County Industrial Development Agency awarded Morgan Stanley $8.4 million in sales tax exemptions. 
Other financial service offices in the county are smaller in scale than Morgan Stanley. Merrill Lynch, for example, has a longstanding presence in the county, with three offices of stockbrokers in White Plains, Mount. Kisco and Scarsdale for a total of about 150 employees. 
But officials see the presence of corporations of various sizes as an important element in economic stability, and a break with the past when the county relied on several large companies, like I.B.M. 
"I.B.M. used to account for half the county's office square footage," Mr. Carrera said. 
Now, Mrs. Gordon added: "We're not a one-industry town. The strength of the Westchester economy has become its diversity."
New York Life Insurance Company is also considering moving 1,000 employees to the county. "We have a two-building home office complex in Manhattan and the bulk of the company is exposed there," said William Werfelman, the company's spokesman. The company began searching for space outside the city for part of its employees. "At this point we've narrowed our potential locations to within Westchester and New Jersey. We should have a decision within 30 days," Mr. Werfelman said. Last week the county's Industrial Development Agency offered the company incentives worth $1.7 million.
Within the financial sector there is diversity, which has allowed for areas of strength even during a weak stock market. 
Though equity markets have had it tough since the dot-com implosion began in March 2000, the residential mortgage market has been extremely strong, especially locally. "Many mortgage companies that are here are growing and others are moving here," Mrs. Gordon said. 
Financial services have been one of the industries compensating for the manufacturing jobs that were a big part of the county's employment picture a generation ago, but have since been lost.
Though companies like General Motors, which used to be in Tarrytown, are gone, the county's unemployment rate remains low. Westchester's unemployment rate was 3.7 percent in December, which was unchanged from December 2001. The rate compares favorably with the unemployment rate in New York State as a whole, which was 6.1 percent in December, up from 5.5 percent a year earlier, and the city rate of 8.2 percent, up from 7.1. 
With about 110 employees, Gabelli Asset Management moved from Midtown to Rye a decade ago. It now has 180 employees and the company says its home suits it well. 
"The Wall Street area itself doesn't matter anymore," a spokesman said. "Our sales team works on the phone anyway. And it's as easy to get to La Guardia from Rye as Manhattan. Our research staff does go to Midtown for company presentations, so there's a lot of Rye to Midtown movement." 
He complained, though, about taxes in Westchester and New York State compared with Connecticut, where the firm has offices. "When you sharpen the pencils" to compare costs, he said, the company would have to take a serious look at moving more operations to Connecticut.

The four-story building, left, has a courtyard that will be turned into a trading desk. (Photographs by John W. Wheeler for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET; 
Anger Flares Over Sales Tax

BYLINE:  By YILU ZHAO 

 BODY:
AFTER Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky and seven other of the 12 state legislators from Westchester rejected County Executive Andrew J. Spano's proposal to increase the county sales tax by one cent last week, most likely dooming the proposal, rancor flared between Mr. Spano and Mr. Brodsky, a Democrat representing Greenburgh 
 Mr. Spano and members of his staff warned that the rejection of the proposal would mean adopting a contingency budget passed in December entailing a double-digit increase in property tax collected by the county, layoffs of 30 police officers and 17 assistant district attorneys, reduced county aid to nonprofit organizations, and cuts of 300 day-care slots for low-income families. 
 "There is some kind of game going on here," said Larry Schwartz, deputy county executive, "and the losers here will be the property taxpayers in Westchester."
But Mr. Brodsky accused Mr. Spano, also a Democrat, of using nonprofit organizations as political pawns and of "not telling the public the true county budget."
Mr. Spano and the county Board of Legislators had counted on the extra revenue from the raised sales tax, valued at $67 million for the rest of the year, when they released the 2003 county budget in December that didn't raise property tax at all. 
The county needs approval from both the State Senate and Assembly to impose the additional one cent. Without the support of the county delegation in Albany, it is unlikely that other legislators will vote for the bill.
The county Board of Legislators unanimously supported the sales tax proposal in December. 
"There is still a slim hope" that the bill will pass the State Legislature, said Lois T. Bronz, chairwoman of the board, on Thursday. "Nobody said to me that the bill will not be submitted, so we assume it's still alive."
Mr. Schwartz said that the county government had already been "cut to the bone" by leaving more than 300 county positions vacant, eliminating pay raises for county employees, reducing travel and equipment budgets, lowering aid to neighborhood health centers and decreasing financing for antitobacco campaigns.
So far, no public employee has been laid off, but that will change without the additional sales tax, he said.
In addition, county property tax will need to be raised by as much as 22 percent in some places --Harrison was given as an example -- to balance the budget, Mr. Schwartz said. On average, he estimated the increase to be 15 percent.
Mr. Brodsky, who leads Westchester's Assembly delegation, said he favored a property tax increase because "a sales tax increase hurts poor people more." 
"This tax proposal is unfair," he said. He argued that since Westchester businesses, which don't pay large amounts of sales tax to the county, were big beneficiaries when property taxes were cut in flush times that it's time for them to give back.
He said the sales tax would not be imposed in Yonkers, Mount Vernon, New Rochelle and White Plains, where the sales tax has reached or is near its constitutional limit. 
According to Mr. Brodsky's calculation, total property taxes would need to be increased by only 1.8 percent to save the county budget, translating to between $100 and $200 each year per family. 
Since the county gets only 20 percent of the total property tax a family pays -- the rest goes to towns, villages and school districts -- total property tax will go up by 3 to 4 percent with Mr. Spano's projections if towns and villages hold their shares constant.
According to the 2000 Census, the median property tax bill for single-family homes is $8,826 in Westchester, and a 3 to 4 percent increase will mean around $300 a year. 
Alternatively, for a two-income household that spends $30,000 a year in Westchester, an average amount according to some economists in the county, a 1 percent sales tax increase would translate to $300 a year, about the same as the projected property tax increase.
But Mr. Schwartz pointed out that many kinds of food and medication are tax exempt in the county, thus providing relief to low-income families and the elderly.
"Sales tax is discretionary while property tax is mandatory," Mr. Schwartz said. "If you cannot pay your property tax, you lose your house. If you cannot afford the sales tax, you just don't go to Macy's."
The county has also pledged to return 25 percent of the revenue collected on the increased sales tax to the towns and villages to help keep local property taxes down. 
"Sales tax is a tax you don't think about," said Susan Tolchin, Mr. Spano's chief adviser, explaining that people don't usually fuss over 1 cent of sales tax when they shop.
But a significant increase in a property tax bill is something taxpayers will notice. Mr. Spano was reelected with 72 percent of the vote partly because he had lowered taxes.
"Andy Spano got himself into this mess," Mr. Brodsky said, pointing out that Mr. Spano chose to spend the county's income from tobacco settlements all at once. "He did a lot of tax cuts before the last election funded by borrowing and gimmicks." 
"Mr. Spano is not interested in going tit-for-tat with Richard Brodsky," said Ms. Tolchin. "He is only interested in avoiding a double-digit increase in property tax."

HEADLINE: Business; 
R.V.'s and Tourism Help Areas Buck the Economic Tide

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT 

 BODY:
ELKHART and Goshen, two small cities in northern Indiana, are a hotbed of job creation. How could it be? 
 The metropolitan area they anchor seems about the least likely place to have boomed in 2002. It says it has the nation's highest concentration of manufacturing, and this is a time when manufacturers are mired in a deep downturn. 
 But a comeback in the recreational-vehicle industry after a slump in 2001 helped give Elkhart-Goshen greater job growth than any other metropolitan area last year: -- 4.6 percent. With the Sept. 11 attacks still limiting foreign travel, sales of R.V.'s have jumped, and Monaco Coach, Keystone RV and Dutchmen are all adding workers in the area, which is near the Michigan border.
Across the country, employment rolls fell 0.2 percent last year, but some areas managed to do well. Almost 140 of the 316 metropolitan areas added jobs; among the biggest gainers were centers for tourism or the military, according to Economy.com, a research company that follows regional trends. 
Of course, job growth doesn't always mean that an area is booming. Elkhart-Goshen's work force at the end of 2002 totaled 122,500 people, still about 5 percent below the level three years ago. 
"It's making its way back," said Mark Zandi, chief economist at Economy.com, "but it's coming off a very low bottom."
Several areas are posting record employment numbers, thanks to strong job growth last year. Like Elkhart-Goshen, at least three other metropolitan areas -- Biloxi, Miss. (second on the Economy.com list), Las Vegas (eighth) and Atlantic City (ninth) -- are benefiting from the gain in domestic tourism. Each of the three is drawing people to its casinos.
Biloxi has also been helped by another reaction to Sept. 11: the increase in military and security spending. Employment is up at its Air Force base, just as it has grown at the border security office in McAllen, Tex. (fourth on the list); at Los Alamos National Laboratory near Santa Fe, N.M. (fifth); and at the Army base in Tacoma, Wash. (seventh).
Completing the top 10 were Fayetteville, Ark. (third), where Wal-Mart and its suppliers continue to expand; Chico, Calif. (sixth), where affordable housing is wooing new residents; and Madison, Wis., where financial services are growing. 
At the other end of the spectrum, the bottom 10 areas highlight the surprising nature of Elkhart-Goshen's growth. The list of areas with the biggest employment declines is filled with manufacturing hubs, including Florence, Ala., and Flint, Mich., not for from Elkhart-Goshen. Technology centers like San Jose, Calif., are also still shrinking.
The economy began growing again in late 2001, but companies kept eliminating jobs. About 100 metropolitan areas remain in recession, according to Economy.com. 
"They're everywhere," Mr. Zandi said. "They're not just in one region. They're not just in one corner of the country. They're coast to coast."

HEADLINE: For Power Lunchers, an Entree of Malaise 

BYLINE:  By MIREYA NAVARRO 

 BODY:
ANNETTE OSNOS, who entertains frequently as an advertising sales manager for Business Week magazine, has not been explicitly told to cut back on costs, but in this economy "it's somewhat implied," she said. So while Ms. Osnos still takes clients to lunch every day, she does it with the practiced eye of a Costco bargain shopper.
 If wine must be served, she orders a bottle rather than one glass at a time, which is costlier. Steakhouses are avoided: they are too expensive because everything on the menu is a la carte. 
 And in a telling sign of a cultural shift in that sacrosanct ritual, the expense-account meal, Ms. Osnos said she favored places like Blue Smoke, a -- gulp -- barbecue restaurant, where it was almost impossible to spend more than $50 on food for two at lunch, but that still offered a trendy name. 
"I don't want anyone to think that I'm chintzing out on them," she said. 
The business lunch, a deep-rooted New York institution that oils the gears of publishing, finance, advertising and other industries, is an unfailing indicator of economic stress, and lately it has grown lean as poached halibut, hold the sauce. Suddenly people will declare that something light, very light, will do. Tabs are being watched closely. Tips are less generous. 
"The business lunch still exists -- some businesses can't do without it," said Marco Maccioni, a co-owner of Osteria del Circo in Midtown. "But all that bonus money at lunchtime disappeared or spread out," he said. "People are much more diligent getting their receipts. You see this instinctual behavior."
At Gabriel's, near Columbus Circle, Gabriel Aiello, the owner, said he had not seen such an erosion in corporate spending at lunchtime since the stock market crash of 1987. Regulars from neighboring media companies like ABC, CBS and Newsweek now come twice a month rather than once a week, but they often spend more on those rarer visits, Mr. Aiello said. "It's weird."
Restaurateurs all over town report dwindling crowds of businesspeople at lunch, while customers from corporations say that they feel like victims of an epidemic of budgetary self-control.
These are times of layoffs and hiring slumps, of an impending war and looming billion-dollar deficits, so who feels like plunking down big dollars for three scallops?
Rob Gregory, the publisher of Rolling Stone, said that in flusher times he often went out to lunch five days a week and spent $200 for two. But two years into a severe advertising downturn in the magazine industry, Mr. Gregory goes out perhaps three times weekly and tries to keep the check at $100 or so, partly to prevent his guests from getting ideas that lavish spending might mean that the magazine's advertising rates are too high.
"There are some things you can't help," Mr. Gregory said. "When you take out a big advertiser and they start eyeing the $400 bottle of wine you have to go along. What I try to do is grab the wine list first."
A couple of years ago, Rolling Stone put out a three-page policy memorandum for employees that downgraded the restaurants suitable for entertaining, specified the amounts that could be spent on meals and prohibited employees from entertaining each other, Mr. Gregory said.
"Some of the expenses take care of themselves in really tough times because about a third of my business lunches are canceled anyway because people are crazed working," he said.
The Manhattan business lunch long ago ceased to be a fabled three-martini social occasion. Concerns over diet and time forced the shift away from a long, social, high-octane drinking lunch, said Kathryn S. Wylde, president of the Partnership for New York City, a business leadership group that works at improving the city's economic climate.
"Senior executives don't have the discretion to spend social time during the workday," Ms. Wylde said, citing the volatile economy and the increasing demands of business and travel as reasons.
Ms. Wylde remembers when she was taken to lunch quite a bit by chief executives. Now she is lucky to get a 15-minute meeting "on the fly," she said.
Senior and midlevel executives selling an idea or a product say that nothing beats breaking bread at lunch to impress, to create good will and to make the sale, without interruptions and in a more relaxed environment than the office can provide. And in a bad economy, some executives said, lunch becomes even more crucial in generating revenue, so some have stepped up their entertaining.
But the growing mind-set at many companies seems to be "Why do lunch when there's the telephone?"
"Our staff figured out a long time ago that the 20 minutes of business over a two-hour lunch can be done on the phone," said Adam Rothberg, a spokesman for Simon & Schuster, the publisher.
He said that editors, publishers and publicists did lunch "for the relationships and entertainment factor" but that many employees found it more efficient to spend the lunch hour at the gym.
With a white-tablecloth lunch dwindling in importance for business meetings, what is taking its place? 
For some, the after-work Heineken or the one-egg breakfast have assumed greater importance.
Mr. Gregory of Rolling Stone can exploit his ties to the music industry. Even while cutting back on dining, he is not skimping on great concert seats for advertisers -- fifth row center at a U2 show, "they remember that for years," he said.
Frugal habits have intensified over the last two years or so, especially during the recession and after Sept. 11.
The latest retrenching, however, has more to do with an atmosphere of caution, many of those interviewed said.
Usually, there is no specific policy or directive curtailing expense-account meals. Instead, said Ian Kaufman, managing partner at the patent law firm Ladas & Parry in Manhattan: "This is all subliminal. It's self-recognition rather than an edict."
Mr. Kaufman said that his firm had experienced "some diminution" in business, losing some clients to bankruptcy, but that the partners still took clients out. Their internal compass, however, is more likely to lead them to Jean Georges's cafe, Nougatine, rather than to the more expensive part of the restaurant, on Columbus Circle.
One printing company owner downtown said that some clients had tried to save him money by choosing less-expensive items on the menu. One even chose a diner, he said, with a resulting total tab of $30 for two. The client said he was in the mood for a sandwich. 
"I spent $300 on him once," said the businessman, who asked to remain anonymous because he took clients to lunch almost every day but wanted each to feel that he was getting special treatment. 
"I see people be more conscientious about the money I spend on them," he said. "They'll get the prix fixe, too. People are cutting back and not even realizing it."
Customers are indeed spending less, confirmed E. Charles Hunt, executive vice president of the Greater New York City Chapter of the New York State Restaurant Association, which has 2,500 membersin the city generating more than $10 billion in revenue a year. The decline of expense-account spending is one reason, he said, although such a drop is difficult to measure.
To fight back, Mr. Hunt said, restaurant owners nationwide were lobbying in Washington for the return of the fully deductible expense-account meal, which is only 50 percent deductible now.
"It's one of the things that would help," Mr. Hunt said.
Danny Meyer, who owns five restaurants in New York City, said his places had never been as packed for the twice yearly Restaurant Week promotion as they were last month. 
Among the usual Restaurant Week customers -- older people from Long Island and Connecticut taking advantage of three-course lunches for $20 -- Mr. Meyer noticed for the first time more youngish, working types. 
"This year, there were all kinds of people who were also doing business," he said. "It was another way to use your expense account wisely."
Tim Zagat, the restaurant-guide entrepreneur, said that the downturn in expense-account lunches had affected some restaurants more than others, and that it was hard to quantify the situation without a survey. But overall, he said, the drop seems to be significant.
Mr. Zagat said that for many Manhattan restaurants the cutbacks were compounded by the post-9/11 drop in traffic from business and recreational visitors. One indication that the restaurant industry is hurting, he said, was the decision by many restaurants this year to offer Restaurant Week discounts at both lunch and dinner, and some have preserved the low prices indefinitely. Another is that even the most in-demand restaurants are now eager to please.
"They are polite when they pick up the phone, and they're glad to hear from you," Mr. Zagat said.
Ms. Osnos of Business Week said she was pleasantly surprised last December when one of her lunch hangouts took 10 percent off a bill without prompting.
"I'm a fairly good customer for them, and maybe that was a way to say thank you," she said.
In a way, many restaurants are trying to offer plain good service. Mr. Meyer, whose restaurants are known for hospitality and good value in good and bad times, said the good will he had nurtured was paying off and that his restaurants were, for the most part, making the cut among corporate customers, who he said accounted for 75 percent of his lunch business.
Mr. Meyer said he was emphasizing quality even more to give him an edge. Like many other restaurateurs, he keeps a database of the tastes, table preferences and birthdays of regular customers in order to personalize service. 
"I don't know any restaurant in the city that is full at 2 p.m.," Mr. Meyer said. "The business and international travelers who were here on vacation are gone."
With no end in sight to economic woes and the threat of war, the prospects for the expense-account lunch look dim, some restaurateurs said. 
"When you're uncertain, how's your appetite?" Mr. Maccioni asked. "Are you hungry?"

The main article in Sunday Styles this week reported that business lunches had grown fewer and smaller in the economic squeeze since 9/11. In fairness, The Times should have chosen a more representative photo, or should at least have specified the time.

HEADLINE: PORTFOLIOS, ETC.; 
A War Rally for the Dollar Could Be Short-Lived

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
THE outlook for the dollar has been deteriorating rapidly, but a quick start to a war with Iraq would be a short-term fix. War would lift the veil of uncertainty and give the dollar a boost. 
 Since the beginning of December, the dollar is off 8.2 percent against the euro and 1.9 percent against the Japanese yen. Against a broad index of America's trading partners and adjusted for inflation, the dollar is off 1 percent from December to January, according to Federal Reserve data. 
 But even a war rally is unlikely to get the dollar back on its feet for a sustained period. 
A look back to the Persian Gulf war of 1991 offers some insight into what the dollar may face in coming months.
After the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait in August 1990, the dollar fell 9.3 percent against the German mark, then the dominant European currency, and 15.1 percent against the yen. But once the ground war began in February 1991, the dollar took off, rising 30 percent against the mark and 13.5 percent against the yen by summer.
That is the lesson that most people remember. But what happened during the rest of 1991 is instructive. Although the 1990-91 recession was officially over in March and a recovery had technically begun, the economy showed few signs of life; the lift from the gulf war faded and the dollar sank. By the end of 1991, the broad trade-weighted dollar was almost back to its February low and was down 1.1 percent for the year.
History may repeat itself. Even though Europe and Japan are in worse shape economically than the United States, there are few positives for the dollar now.
Yianos Kontopoulos, chief global foreign exchange strategist at Merrill Lynch, estimates that about 2.5 cents of the current value of the euro against the dollar, which finished the week at $1.083, is a risk premium, which includes the threat of a war. He said that a war rally could push up the dollar almost 3 percent, to $1.05 to the euro, by the end of March, assuming that a war goes well.
David Gilmore, a partner in Foreign Exchange Analytics in Essex, Conn., added, "There will be a victory lap for the dollar following a victory by the United States."
But while a successful war with Iraq would cause much of the current global uncertainty to dissipate, Ashraf Laidi, chief currency analyst at the MG Financial Group in New York, said, "there is an inherent risk of an explosion of retaliation in the region."
There are also economic considerations. James McCormick, global head of foreign exchange strategy at Lehman Brothers in London, said that the dollar could not begin a sustained comeback until there were at least two back-to-back quarters of at least 3.5 percent economic growth in the United States.
In Lehman Brothers' current economic forecast, that won't occur until the end of the year, and by then Mr. McCormick is predicting that the dollar will have fallen to a value of $1.12 against the euro.
Laurie A. Cameron, global currency strategist at the J. P. Morgan Private Bank, says she thinks that oil prices will not come down as much as hoped after a war. That would be a negative for the American economy and for the dollar.
Then there are the twin deficits: the American current account deficit and the federal budget deficit, a duo that has not been a worry since the late 1980's. The budget deficit raises concerns about the performance of the government and, therefore, the economy. The current account deficit requires a continuous inflow of foreign capital to be offset. If this flow just slows a bit, the dollar will fall.
THAT should be a comfort to investors who have made bets in foreign markets and can bring home bigger profits, or at least mitigate their losses, as long as the dollar is weak this year.
A weaker dollar should also be a boon to investors who stayed at home and are still waiting for the economy and the stock market to revive. A lower dollar increases growth by making American exports less expensive abroad and by making domestic products, like autos, more competitive against foreign imports.

'91 -- U.S. air raids mark the beginning of the gulf war. (Source: Federal Reserve Board)
