HEADLINE: A Clarion Call, a Warning Siren 

BYLINE:  By JOHN RATHER 

 BODY:
MARY ALFANO has been going to Long Island Rail Road stations since November to pass out literature opposing war on Iraq. The morning commuters rushing past, she said, have been getting friendlier as the time for war draws near. 
 "People pat you on the back and say, 'Good work lady, somebody has to do it,"' said Ms. Alfano, 74, of Bohemia, who stood with a small group of generally middle-aged to elderly people at the Ronkonkoma station on a recent weekday morning, handing out leaflets. 
 She carried a sign that said, "Peace Is Patriotic." The leaflets asked, "Are you safer now than you were a year ago?" 
Most of the commuters boarding trains bound for the empire city of a nation poised for a pre-emptive strike against Iraq accepted or politely declined the leaflets, and the question was left hanging.
But a few stopped to debate. "I watched the Twin Towers fall down, and these people did not," said Greg Merkle, 43, a computer service support manager from Manorville catching the 7:04 to Manhattan. "Whether or not Iraq was in on 9/11, they are part of the axis of evil, like the president says." 
No polls have focused on Long Islanders' opinions on the war. But it is clear that local sentiment runs the gamut from emphatic opposition to a war against Iraq to enthusiastic support of President Bush's invasion threats, bookending a broad middle of highly nuanced views. 
The Island's college campuses are hardly hotbeds of dissent or support, though some faculty members opposed to the war said that might be changing. "My sense is that there has been a massive shift against the war in the last month," said Martin Melkonian, a professor of economics at Hofstra University and a peace activist. But he conceded that only a small minority was active.
Others said support for the Bush administration's policy was not only predominant but also presumptive. "No sane person wants war, but I believe a solid majority will support the president if he believes war is necessary," said Representative Peter T. King, a Republican from Seaford. "When I talk to people in the deli or in a diner, that's what they tell me."
While generalizations are risky, the most active opponents of the war tended to be older than 50 and many were part of the civil rights and peace movements of the 1960's. Others dated their activism to anti-nuclear campaigns of the 1980's. 
Most were part of religious groups such as Pax Christi, a Catholic group that has mounted motorcades to bring to Long Island parishes a statement by Catholic bishops calling the war unjust, or organized peace groups such as the Long Island Alliance for Peaceful Alternatives, a coalition formed in the mid-1980's to support a freeze on nuclear weapons. 
Maurice Brooks of Great Neck, 80, a member of Great Neck SANE/Peace Action, summed up the opponents' view about a pre-emptive strike against Iraq. "It would result in the death of thousands of innocent Iraqi people, risk the lives of American troops, cost billions of dollars needed for health care, housing, the environment and education, violate international law and destabilize the Middle East," said Mr. Brooks, a World War II veteran.
Supporters of Mr. Bush's assertion that Iraq must be disarmed by force if necessary were equally fervent in their support.
"We can't appease this man," said John J. Taft, a Vietnam veteran from North Merrick who lost both legs when he stepped on a mine. "The last time we let someonelike him do what they wanted there was Hitler and World War II," he said.
But if feelings, once solicited, were running high, the public mood seemed civil, subdued and tolerant of differing views. Mr. Merkle, who debated war opponents at the Ronkonkoma railroad station, said he felt no rancor toward them. "They didn't change my mind, and I didn't change theirs," he said. "But we could still have a cup of coffee together at Dunkin' Donuts."
Nina Friedberg, 78, of Patchogue, a retired nurse and teacher and a peace movement veteran, said commuters she had leafleted at several stations were almost unfailing polite.
"I have never been in anything where there is so much positive response," she said. "Bush can say whatever he wants, but these people are wondering, and they are saying wait a minute."
Officials at Long Island colleges say students seem quiescent, if curious and perhaps apprehensive. A scattering of antiwar campus rallies have been held, but there were few posters or signs opposing or supporting war with Iraq, and no tables in commons areas with students handing out literature.
At the State University at Stony Brook, posters on a kiosk near the student union advertised a Feb. 15 antiwar rally in New York City. Inside the student union building, of five students who spoke of their feelings about the war, one had plans to attend the rally. Others were noncommittal or lightly leaning one way or the other. 
Nelson Dovale, 21, a math and philosophy major from Mineola, was concerned about friends in the military who could be placed in harm's way. "I don't know if war is the answer, and I am never for violence," he said. "But we have to do something." 
Daniel Nagler, 20, sociology major from Malverne who sat with Mr. Dovale over lunch on a recent afternoon, wondered about President Bush's assertions that Iraq was hiding weapons of mass destruction that posed a grave threat. "I don't necessarily know where he is coming from," Mr. Nagler said. "He may know there is something there, or he may know that there's not. But you have to accept it unless you want to become a politician."
Neither student had plans to attend the rally in Manhattan, and both said the issue was not a topic among friends or other students they knew. "It really doesn't come up in conversation," Mr. Dovale said.
At another table, Suad Yaghmour-Shapiro, 18, a freshman from Manhattan studying biochemistry, said she would most definitely be going to the Manhattan march. "Iraq is not the only country with destructive weapons, and they haven't really threatened anybody," said Ms. Yaghmour-Shapiro, who said her father was Palestinian and her mother Jewish. 
"Saddam has killed millions of people," interjected Raheel Mahmed, 18, a freshman from Omaha studying psychology, who said his pacifism had given way to a feeling the Iraqi dictator is "not the kind of person you can talk to using diplomacy." 
"I can kind of see why war is the only option now," said Mr. Mahmed, whose parents are Pakistani. 
Nadia Pretto, 19, a health sciences major from Glen Cove, said she saw both sides but leaned against war. "What will we accomplish with a war except we'll have a lot of people against us," she said. "We are just going to hurt ourselves and our economy."
Four students waiting out halftime at a basketball game at Suffolk Community College in Selden said they were ready to serve in the war.
"The peace people say we should wait," said Gary Schor, 20, of Ronkonkoma. "What are we going to do, wait for a million people to die and then retaliate? If there's a draft, I'd go."
"He's a threat to our security," added Thomas Bobka, 20, of Bayport, referring to Mr. Hussein.
"It's us or them," said Christopher Canale, 21, of Ronkonkoma. 
"We have to stop them before they stop us," said Anthony Canale, his twin brother.
The four men said they knew of no campus rallies and had heard little discussion among students and friends about the war they thought was coming. 
At Nassau County Community College in Garden City, Reginald Tuggle, the director of college relations, said there had been one campus rally before the Christmas break where antiwar speakers addressed about 150 students. But except for as few antiwar flyers, the issue had since been in the background, he said.
"I've got to tell you, people are generally not focused on that," Mr. Tuggle said. "Most of them are focused on their own lives, and just trying to get by, day by day."Michael B. DeLuise, a Hofstra spokesman, described students as "nervous, questioning, and looking at where things might be going."
"They were listening to the State of the Union address," he said, referring to President Bush's recent appearance before Congress. "And for I don't know how many years people never listened."
Mr. DeLuise said he was struck by the age of people protesting the war outside the Long Island Association annual meeting and luncheon on Jan. 28, featuring former President George H.W. Bush and his wife, Barbara. "I honestly don't think I saw anybody under 50 in that crowd," Mr. DeLuise said of the protesters.
Sheila Croke, 74, a Pax Christi member from Greenlawn who was at the protest, said the age of the protesters was not surprising because the event was held during school and working hours on a Tuesday.
Ms. Croke spoke of a group of more than 100 high school students who rallied against the war earlier this month at the intersection of Routes 25A and 110. "We have both ends of the spectrum now," she said.
The offices of the Island's congressional delegation said calls and letters were running against the war. "But it's not necessarily who you hear from, it's can you count on it to be a representative opinion?" said Doug Dodson, the chief of staff for Representative Timothy Bishop, a Democrat from Southampton. "You have silent majorities and vocal minorities," he said. 
Mitchell H. Pally, the vice president of government affairs for the Long Island Association, said opinions in the business community were muted. "It's not really something people think about unless they are personally involved, unless they know someone in the reserves," he said. "There seems to be hope that the Iraq issue can be solved diplomatically rather than militarily, but it's not the first thing anybody brings up."
The Rev. Thomas W. Goodhue, the executive director of the Long Island Council of Churches, a Protestant group, said the war was a frequent topic from the pulpit. "It's very much on people's minds, especially when they are preaching, and it has been for a long time," he said. "What I sense among many clergy is that the case has not yet been made that a pre-emptive strike could possibly be a just war."
Some clergymen said they found no support for the war among their parishioners. "Frankly, I don't known anyone at First Parish Church who favors war with Iraq," said the Rev. Robert Palin, the pastor of the United Church of Christ congregation in Riverhead. "In fact, all are adamantly opposed."
In Massapequa, Timothy J. Gang, whose stepson Timothy Nolan, 18, is a new marine, said he was proud of his stepson but also apprehensive. "Nobody wants a family member to go to war," said Mr. Gang, a Marine Corps veteran. "But the general opinion among my friends is we just want to get this over with."
"We should have done the job years ago when the father was in office and we had the troops there," he said. 
Others have been called into the military from civilian jobs. "I am enthusiastic about performing my duties, it's what I have been trained to do," said James DuPont of Garden City, a Nassau County police officer activated as a gunnery sergeant in 2nd Battalion, 25th Marines. "If people want to have different points of view, that's their right. Don't hold us responsible for the policies of it. We are just following orders."
The battalion spent 11 months of training at Camp Lejeune, N.C. "Right now we are just standing by," Sergeant DuPont said.

HEADLINE: Young Americans, Dashed Hopes 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Young, Jobless, Hopeless," by Bob Herbert (column, Feb. 6): 
 As a retired New York City high school teacher, I have known many poor young people who became hopeless, frustrated and defeated because they could find neither a niche nor a job in this society. 
 I was shocked to receive an e-mail message from a former student last week who wrote that he would do anything, "even singing telegrams," if he could find employment. 
Unlike the undereducated young people Mr. Herbert writes about, this young man, born in poverty in Georgia and raised from the age of 13 in Harlem by his father, graduated from Brandeis High School and then the University of Rochester last year. 
He has put himself in debt and struggled against all odds at a university that was neither diverse nor inclusive, and where he was mostly unhappy and isolated, to get the degree that promised entree to the mainstream of society.
He started out as a premed student but by senior year decided he could not incur any more debt and chose to look for a teaching job for the time being. 
Is this the American dream? Shame on us.

ELAINE KENZER-KOLLEGGER
New York, Feb. 6, 2003

HEADLINE: Costly Questions Arise on Legal Opinions for Tax Shelters 

BYLINE:  By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
Like sellers of treasure maps, promoters of tax shelters promise that for a large fee one can navigate a secret route. What clinches these deals is not the chart itself but a second document that appears to warrant that the map is as good as gold.
 That document is called an opinion letter and it blesses the tax shelter as a legitimate way to reduce taxes. Written by tax lawyers using the embossed stationery of their firms, the letters typically cost $50,000, $75,000 or more, and require a signed promise to keep the contents secret, like the treasure map, lest the Internal Revenue Service discover where untaxed fortunes lie. 
 But as top executives at the Sprint Corporation are discovering, opinion letters may not be worth the paper they are written on. William T. Esrey, the chief executive, and Ronald T. LeMay, the president, bought Ernst & Young tax shelters hoping to escape $114 million in federal income taxes on the exercise of their stock options. The executives paid Ernst & Young, the firm that audits Sprint's books, about $8.7 million for the shelters, according to Ernst's confidential pricing guide, assuming all their 1999 and 2000 stock options went into the shelters.
Neither Sprint nor Ernst & Young would say which law firm wrote the opinion letter for that shelter. But whichever firm it was, the letter may be of little value, because the I.R.S. is moving to disallow the shelter as illegitimate.
If the taxes must be paid now, Mr. Esrey disclosed Wednesday, he may lose his entire fortune because all of his Sprint shares are worth millions less than the taxes he avoided on those shares in the shelter.
What even sophisticated tax shelter buyers often fail toappreciate is that "it's just an opinion, it's not an insurance policy," said David P. Hariton, a partner at Sullivan & Cromwell in New York who does not write such letters. He said promoters try to imbue opinion letters with great significance, even implying that there is some standard for grading the quality of the assurances, but this is not true. 
Larry A. DiMatteo, an associate professor of legal studies at the Warrington College of Business at the University of Florida who has written extensively on opinion letters, said that even financially smart people "treat opinion letters as if they were binding, when under American law they generally have no legal consequence."
Opinion letters often run to 100 pages. The cover page offers comforting assurances, typically saying that even if the I.R.S. finds out about the shelter it is "more likely than not" that taxes will never come due. The rest of these letters are economic and legal analysis heavy with caveats.
The letters can be quite lucrative for law firms, because the same opinion can be sold over and over to buyers of an identical shelter simply by changing the name on the opinion. 
A number of tax lawyers and professors, none of whom draft tax shelter opinion letters, said opinion letters all boiled down to this: A tax shelter works unless the government says it does not.
Lately the I.R.S. has been busy notifying people that their tax shelters do not work, with disastrous results for some of those who relied on the opinion letters. In New York, North Carolina and Florida, a few wealthy Americans are already suing two big accounting firms, Ernst & Young and KPMG, that sold failed tax shelters, as well as the lawyers who wrote the opinion letters. More litigation is expected. The accounting firms say their advice was sound and they and the law firms they worked with will defend the shelters before the I.R.S.
Blair C. Fensterstock, a New York lawyer representing four Indiana men who bought an Ernst & Young tax shelter to avoid taxes on $70 million from selling their business, said the promises in an opinion letter were crucial to resolving doubts and closing the deal to set up the shelter. Yet, he said, the letter itself was not delivered until after the shelter was set up.
Even if his clients had received the letter ahead of time, Mr. Fensterstock said, they would not have understood all the subtle disclaimers in it. 
"Even for people who are sophisticated, it doesn't mean they understand anything about the complexities of tax shelters," Mr. Fensterstock said.
Two decades ago, the Treasury Department tried to rein in the use of opinion letters to sell tax shelters, but under protests from various lawyer organizations it backed down, according to Ann Southworth, a professor of tax law at Case Western Reserve University who wrote a law review article about opinion letters.
The real value of opinion letters is as a shield from government penalties for not paying taxes when they were due. Penalties are usually waived when a taxpayer relied on professional advice that the I.R.S. regards as reasonable and given in good faith.
John P. Freeman, a University of South Carolina law professor, wrote in the Columbia Business Law Review that court rulings "strongly suggest that courts today are willing to go to considerable lengths to protect lawyers" whose opinion letters encourage misconduct. That was in 1989, and Professor Freeman and others said the trend had only grown. 
A leading opponent of tax shelters, Representative Lloyd Doggett, Democrat of Texas, said Congress should pass a law mandating penalties if the opinion letter a taxpayer relied on was written by a lawyer picked by the shelter promoters.
In many recent cases, the opinion letters were written by lawyers the sellers had selected and they barred an independent legal review, according to court papers. Ernst & Young even gave clients a pricing sheet on what the opinion letters would cost.
Mr. Doggett, a former Texas Supreme Court justice, said "the opinion letter is essentially a get-out-of-jail-free card because penalties are waived."
In turn, he said, "that makes tax shelters a no-risk strategy because your chances of getting caught in the audit lottery are low," and if one is caught, all that is due are the taxes plus interest.

HEADLINE: THREATS AND RESPONSES: GULF ALLIES; 
SAUDIS PLAN END TO U.S. PRESENCE

BYLINE:  By PATRICK E. TYLER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 

 BODY:
Saudi Arabia's leaders have made far-reaching decisions to prepare for an era of military disengagement from the United States, to enact what Saudi officials call the first significant democratic reforms at home, and to rein in the conservative clergy that has shared power in the kingdom.
 Senior members of the royal family say the decisions, reached in the last month, are a result of a continuing debate over Saudi Arabia's future and have not yet been publicly announced. But these princes say Crown Prince Abdullah will ask President Bush to withdraw all American armed forces from the kingdom as soon as the campaign to disarm Iraq has concluded. A spokesman for the royal family said he could not comment. 
 Pentagon officials asked about the Saudi decisions said they had not heard of any plan so specific as a complete American withdrawal. Since the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, in which 15 of the 19 hijackers involved were Saudis, members of both parties in Congress have urged broad reform in the conservative kingdom. 
Until Abdullah actually issues the decrees, it remains to be seen whether he will be the first son of Saudi Arabia's modern unifier, King Abdul Aziz ibn Saud, to undertake significant political change.
The presence of foreign -- especially American -- forces since the Persian Gulf war of 1991 has been a contentious issue in Saudi Arabia and has spurred the terrorism of Osama bin Laden, the now disowned scion of one of the kingdom's wealthiest families, and his followers in Al Qaeda.
Saudi officials said the departure of American soldiers would set the stage for an announcement that Saudis -- but probably not women, at least initially -- would begin electing representatives to provincial assemblies and then to a national assembly, Saudi officials said.
The goal would be the gradual expansion, over six years, of democratic writ until a fully democratic national assembly emerged, a senior official said.
The debate over the need for reform is described by Saudi royal family members as part of the post-Sept. 11 reckoning to head off foreign and domestic pressures that threaten the royal family and its dominion over the oil-rich Arabian Peninsula.
As the United States prepares for what could be a long military occupation of Iraq, the Saudi royal family does not want to appear as if it was pressured into reform, according to Saudis familiar with the debate. To be seen as acting under American sway might undermine the monarchy's credibility before a population that is increasingly young, unemployed, pious and anti-American.
Still, the departure of all American military forces from Saudi Arabia would be a potentially troubling milestone in the history of the relationship that dates to World War II.
Since the Persian Gulf war, when the United States sent 500,000 troops to the Saudi desert, a security pact has endured to confront and contain Saddam Hussein in Iraq. Thousands of American engineers have built supply depots, air bases and a state-of-the-art air operations headquarters south of Riyadh that were intended to join the two countries in long-lasting military collaboration.
Even if American troops did leave, Saudi and American officials said, security cooperation would probably continue, and they noted that the soldiers could return if the Saudi rulers faced a new threat.
The Saudi reform debate, according to one participant, has taken place in an atmosphere of opposition from senior princes, including Prince Nayef bin Abdul Aziz, the minister of interior, and to a lesser extent, Prince Sultan bin Abdul Aziz, the minister of defense.
Prince Sultan, who family members say has been privately designated as the next crown prince by Abdullah, was described by a family member as "moderately against it or, stating it another way, very reluctantly for it."
One royal family member said that despite opposing views, senior princes "will support the decisions of Prince Abdullah when he makes them" because "the royal family will always stick together, especially in times of crisis."
The reported decisions have enthusiastic support from Saudi Arabia's influential business sector and from the second tier of senior princes in their 50's and 60's who have had the most contact with the West. Among those family members are Prince Saud al-Faisal, the Princeton-educated foreign minister, and Prince Bandar bin Sultan, son of the defense minister and a former F-15 fighter pilot who has been ambassador to the United States since 1983.
For now, a senior prince said, Crown Prince Abdullah, the day-to-day ruler since King Fahd fell ill in 1995, has overcome resistance with the admonition, "Isn't it better if I do this now before I have to do it later?"
The senior prince added, "After the last shot is fired in Iraq, it will be a good time to say that we have won, and that we both agree there is no longer any need for American forces." But he said that "the real politics of this is to win the hearts and minds of a majority of the people" in Saudi Arabia, adding, "That is the way to really fight terrorism and the bad guys." 
Another senior prince said, "The fact is, reform is imperative and not a choice, so is participatory government." There will always be opponents to reform, this prince said, though the family is capable of facing opposition "with resolve, but with understanding for the other view."
If he issues the decrees, Abdullah will have to contend with those religious authorities who will resist reforms and a change in the fundamentalist contract that has empowered a clergy who practice one of Islam's most conservative interpretations, It is based on the teachings of Sheik Muhammad bin Abd al-Wahhab and sometimes referred to as Wahhabism. 
American specialists on Saudi Arabia said it appeared that Abdullah was seeking a national consensus to maneuver around the most conservative elements of the clergy by appealing to the influential Saudi business establishment, the military and tribal leaders. The aim, Saudi officials said, is to create an Islamic parliament that would be able to wrest some control over social policy -- even basic questions like whether women can drive -- away from the puritanical religious establishment.
Richard N. Murphy, a leading Arabist who served as President Reagan's assistant secretary of state for the Middle East, said that "if this turns out to be solid, it is a dramatic demonstration of leadership, which people have been worried about" since Abdullah took over day-to-day rule from King Fahd. "It also shows that they are capable of generating movement from within, which is where it had to come from if they are going to survive as a ruling family," he added. 
One royal family member said there was a great deal of frustration among younger princes who feel that the older generation, most in their 70's and 80's, have been unwilling to take on the religious establishment.
"There is nothing in the Koran that says that women cannot drive," one prince said. "But we never tested the theory that women could drive," he added, explaining that the royal family simply subordinated itself to clerical rulings because that was the historical bargain under which the House of Saud came to power.
"As it stands now, one religious leader can veto anything that you want to do," one prince said. "Eventually, we became the culprits under this system," he added. "And now, we have exhausted every inch of that coalition. It is time to move on to the next generation."
The last time Saudi Arabia purged itself of foreign military forces was 1963, when King Faisal ordered the Strategic Air Command squadron of nuclear-armed bombers to evacuate the base they had maintained at Dhahran since the 1950's.
The reason at that time was a streak of Arab nationalism coursing through the region with the rise of Gamal Abdel Nasser in Egypt, said David E. Long, a longtime State Department specialist on the Saudis. He said that "our presence in a military base became a liability" for the Saudis, "and we were asked to leave."
Saudi Arabia's dalliance with democratic process also dates to the early 1960's. King Faisal told President John F. Kennedy that he would create an assembly whose appointed deputies would advise the throne, but not make laws. But nothing came of the proposal until 1992, when King Fahd finally carried it out after the Persian Gulf war.
Whether Abdullah can push through the deeper change now apparently envisioned is unclear. The decision by some family members to air the debate seemed in part intended to nudge the Saudi leader forward.
"Doing political reform in Saudi Arabia is like publishing the Kama Sutra in the Victorian Age," said a royal family member, referring to the Hindu encyclopedia of erotica. But, he added, "the changes that Abdullah is doing show that he is willing to proceed with only a slim majority of religious support" and a significant amount of opposition.
In doing so, Abdullah has apparently concluded that he will need to put distance between himself and the United States.
"I think they will step away from us, and I think it is healthy for both sides," Mr. Long said. "The median age in Saudi Arabia is now 15, and within this demography, there is an ideological justification for getting mad at American troops on your soil."
"But over and over again, we have given them the umbrella of our security, and our interest in them is that they own one quarter of the world's oil and can export a higher percentage of it than anyone else," Mr. Long said. "That has created a very strong relationship that is under a lot of strain, but I think it will survive."

HEADLINE: Reagan's Son 

 BODY:
With the perspective of history, those who so choose can now, with some credibility, see Ronald Reagan as a master communicator and politician who revitalized our nation's spirit and its economy. 
We can also realistically choose to credit him with boldly exposing the frailty of the Soviet Union and accelerating its demise. 
 What, exactly, has George W. Bush accomplished to even begin to merit comparison? He has pledged to bring Osama bin Laden to justice and to eliminate the threat from Al Qaeda -- so far without success. Under Bush's watch the economy has weakened. And his policy toward Iraq threatens increased global conflict at the philosophical, political and physical levels. 

Dave Batista
Brookline, Mass.

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW; 
EmbracingDeficits To Deter Spending

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: PALO ALTO, Calif. 

 BODY:
AT the Hoover Institution, a bastion of conservative Republican economists on the Stanford campus, it is an article of faith that deep tax cuts are the best tonic for the nation's economy.
 No news in that. 
 What is surprising is the consensus here that budget deficits are not only acceptable but the preferred state of fiscal affairs, a view that President Bush seems to have adopted without explicitly saying so.
And what was really striking in a week spent at Hoover talking to the scholars, many of whom have held top positions in previous Republican administrations, was how unenthusiastic most of these Republican stalwarts are about the president's proposal to eliminate the income tax that individuals pay on stock dividends. 
Here is the Hoover take on budget deficits:
Back in the 1980's and early 90's, when red ink flowed as far as the eye could see, conservatives could safely rail about the wisdom of a balanced budget. There seemed to be no hope of getting there. So any movement toward balance was bound to lead to less government spending, which is the main conservative goal.
But when surpluses began to appear late in the Clinton administration, conservative economists -- and Republican politicians, though most are reluctant to say so -- decided that deficits were best after all, because they restrained spending.
John F. Cogan, a Hoover fellow, was a top official in the Office of Management and Budget in the Reagan and first Bush administrations and probably could have been the current president's budget director if he had wanted the job. He put the case this way: "It is wrong to allow surpluses because these surpluses invariably lead to higher spending. Governments simply cannot hang onto money."
On the exclusion of stock dividends from individual taxation, the centerpiece of the president's tax plan, everyone who was interviewed here agreed that it was generally good tax policy. Double taxation of dividends, once as corporate profits and again after the same money has been distributed to shareholders as dividends, is a serious distortion in the tax code that encourages companies to borrow money and not issue stock, the scholars said.
"It is good tax reform, something we need to do," said Michael J. Boskin, who was chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers under the first President George Bush.
But Mr. Boskin and most of his colleagues said that there were better ways to use the $364 billion in lost revenue over 10 years -- about half of the total proposed tax cut -- that Mr. Bush would allot for the dividend exclusion.
Mr. Boskin would rather use the money for what he called traditional investment incentives, like allowing companies to depreciate investments in plants and equipment more rapidly. 
Martin Anderson, who was a senior economic adviser in Ronald Reagan's White House, and his wife, Annelise G. Anderson, a budget official for Mr. Reagan, said that as much as they liked the idea of scrapping the tax on dividends, they would rather see deeper across-the-board cuts in tax rates. 
"In terms of what will get the economy going, reducing tax rates is what's key," Mr. Anderson said.
ALVIN RABUSHKA, one of the leading academic proponents of a flat tax on all income, said he would also favor using all the money for rate cuts. But rather than cutting rates for all taxpayers, he would reduce only the top rates.
Charles E. McLure Jr., a top tax official in the Reagan administration, wrote a book in the 1970's advocating the elimination of the double tax on dividends. Mr. McLure said he still believed it would be good tax policy.
But he said it would not be his first choice now as the best way to lower taxes. "I certainly wouldn't characterize it as a stimulus," he said. "It would be a tax break mostly for fat cats, who are just going to save the money. And it would not do much for the stock market." 
Mr. McLure recalled that when he was in the Reagan Treasury Department, he and his colleagues favored taxing corporate profits only once. But every proposal they looked at proved to be expensive.
Under instructions in 1984 to prepare a tax reform plan for the president that, over all, neither increased nor decreased revenue, the Treasury tax writers kept paring the dividend exclusion until they proposed a 10 percent exemption. 
When Mr. Reagan submitted his plan to Congress, the exemption had been whittled to 1 percent. When the bill became law, it had no dividendexclusion. "It was too little bang for the buck," Mr. McLure said.

HEADLINE: Personal Business; 
New Savings Plans Wouldn't Be for Everybody

BYLINE:  By MARY WILLIAMS WALSH 

 BODY:
THE Bush administration's proposed "tax free" savings plans are supposed to be all about simplicity, and for many young adults that may be true. Most people starting marriages and careers don't have a lot of financial assets yet, so they won't face many confusing choices about whether to move their money if Congress approves the new accounts.
 But the older you are, and the more money you have stockpiled in 401(k)'s, 529 accounts, individual retirement accounts, Roth I.R.A.'s and other vehicles that now dot the financial landscape, the more complex the decisions will be. 
 Hank Madden, chief executive of Madden Advisory Services, a fee-only financial planning firm in Jacksonville, Fla., that caters to affluent customers, says he has some reservations about the new savings plans. He fears that they could bring on a storm of advertising, sending false signals that they are better for everyone. People who would be better off leaving their money in the old accounts may be persuaded to move it, Mr. Madden said, enriching money managers and the Treasury, but hurting themselves. 
"When you look at these tax-free plans, you have got to get beyond the smoke and mirrors," he said. "Think about the time value of money, because that's not what's being presented to the average person out there."
That means keeping in mind a basic financial principle: a dollar in hand today is worth more than a dollar that will show up in the future. And some of the current tax-advantaged plans do offer that dollar now, when it's worth more.
The 401(k), for example, offers a tax break at the beginning, when contributions are made, using pretax dollars. The pretax dollars form a larger base to generate investment income for the life of the account. The traditional I.R.A. can have the same upfront advantage, at least for people who can deduct their contributions. For both accounts, the money is taxed in the future, when withdrawals are taken.
The proposed new individual savings accounts, by contrast, have their tax advantages built into the future, as tax-free withdrawals. The contributions themselves are to be made with after-tax dollars and offer no tax break. So, while the idea of tax-free future income is appealing, the 401(k)'s upfront tax advantage gives it a hidden power that could offset the new accounts' benefits for some people.
Which people? That depends on many factors, some hard to gauge: the saver's age, income, current tax bracket, expected future tax bracket, current investments, whether the saver has a retirement plan at work and how generous it is, and other circumstances.
For Deborah Darrell and Rhod Williams of Manhattan, the tradeoffs in the old and new savings instruments are relatively straightforward. They are expecting their first baby in April and want to set up a tax-advantaged account for future tuition; until now, they have been investing in real estate and in their 401(k) plans at work. 
The two new individual savings plans -- the Lifetime Savings Account and Retirement Savings Account -- look attractive to them for precisely the reasons Treasury officials say they should: they remove many of the current restrictions on when tax-advantaged money can be withdrawn and for what purposes.
"The idea of having a savings plan that you could take money out of at any time with no penalties is a good thing," said Ms. Darrell, 37, a senior vice president at LaForce & Stevens, a marketing and public relations firm. She agrees that if the rules are relaxed, she will save more.
EVEN so, the couple intend to keep their current savings strategy in place, even if the new vehicles appear. They won't cash out their existing 401(k) accounts, pay taxes due and put the money into the new accounts. Nor will they stop making annual contributions to their 401(k)'s, which would get a new name -- Employer Retirement Savings Accounts. "I like the idea of the tax benefits now, on an investment I'm making for the future," Ms. Darrell said.
Mr. Williams, 36, who left Citigroup last year to start a small, specialized investment bank, said he and his three partners expected to set up an employer-sponsored retirement savings account at their firm. Besides having a front-loaded tax break, as in a 401(k), the program would give the option of providing "free" matching contributions, which some employers now pay. And it would offer the simplicity of automatic payroll deductions at work.
These advantages are more clear-cut for savers who are somewhat closer to the time they'll want to withdraw the money. Marcus Weaver, 45, a branch manager for an industrial cleaning company in Jacksonville, Fla., said he could see no sense in removing money from his traditional I.R.A. or his 401(k), paying taxes and diverting the rest to one of the new savings vehicles.
"I haven't done the math, but we all understand the value of compounding interest," he said, noting that if he transferred his savings to the new plans, paying taxes along the way, his interest would compound from a smaller base.
Mr. Madden, who is Mr. Weaver's planner, asked, "Why would you take a tax-deferred investment and put it into a tax-free investment? The person who benefits from this is the broker or agent who sold it to you, with a high commission."
For Ms. Darrell and Mr. Williams, there are even more reasons to stick with the old vehicles. They are planning to set up a college fund for their child, and while Ms. Darrell said the Lifetime Savings Account sounded fabulous, they are leaning toward the current college savings instrument, a 529 plan.
"The thing I like about the 529 plan is, it's singularly focused," Mr. Williams said. "It's an education plan."
Indeed, the 529 plan requires that savers use withdrawals only for education expenses; if they don't, they pay a penalty. The proposed Lifetime Savings Account allows people to take tax-free withdrawals at any time and for any purpose.
The couple's financial planner, Melissa Levine, said that ever since the Lifetime Savings Accounts were unveiled, she has been urging clients to keep financing 529 plans if they have them, restrictions and all, in part because of the discipline they instill. 
"When they brought out these 529 plans, people were saying, 'Let's really focus on college,' " said Ms. Levine, who has a solo practice in Manhattan. "With the Lifetime Savings Account, I don't think you're going to see that. People are going to focus on the house, the boat and when they get to college they'll say: 'Oops! What went wrong?' "
The 529 plan has yet another advantage for a couple like Ms. Darrell and Mr. Williams because of the way they have handled their investments thus far. For the last seven years, they have been active investors in real estate, buying properties to rent or improve for resale. 
One of their investments is a multifamily dwelling under construction in Newark. It is scheduled to be completed and ready to sell in April, the same month their baby is due. Ms. Levine has devised a tuition plan for the couple, which projects that if they put $55,000 into a 529 plan now, and inflation and investment returns follow certain trends, they should have enough to cover their child's tuition in 18 years.
So the profit from the Newark building project will finance a 529 account -- not a Lifetime Savings Account. For a couple with a large windfall or bonus to work with, the old 529 plans turn out to be the more advantageous tool. The 529's permit large, lump-sum contributions in a single year; the Lifetime Savings Accounts limit annual contributions to $7,500, or $15,000 a couple.
Not that all prosperous savers will have no use for the new accounts. Ms. Levine said that for people with the resources, they might work best as supplements to existing accounts. "I think you really need to have a retirement account for retirement, a college account for college, and if you have anything left over, good for you," she said.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH; 
Yet Another Persecuted Architect of the Tech Bubble

BYLINE:  By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
DURING the technobubble, Frank P. Quattrone was the man to see if you were a new-economy entrepreneur looking for other people's money to pocket. In the technobust, Mr. Quattrone, an investment banker at Credit Suisse First Boston, is facing questions over his advice to colleagues that they shred documents about the faltering companies he helped finance.
 Mr. Quattrone was suspended by his firm last week while it determines whether he is right in saying he has done nothing wrong. 
 But even as this beleaguered banker and former technology stock research director participated in a Pro-Am golf tournament in Pebble Beach, Calif., last week -- the sumptuous course that abuts one of his homes -- securities regulators were preparing a suit against Mr. Quattrone. According to people briefed on the case, it will contend that Mr. Quattrone failed to supervise his subordinates. Regulators may say, for example, that he failed to rein in his enthusiastic analysts who recommended chancy stocks that the firm had underwritten to unsuspecting investors.
It is entirely predictable that Mr. Quattrone would be a target. Looking for fame, regulators often attack productive members of society. Doesn't the NASD realize that Mr. Quattrone cannot have been expected to supervise his 260 bankers and 100 analysts? Not when he had real work to do.
Supervising, after all, is unbearably boring. It may be fine for government work, but Mr. Quattrone was in the real world, creating wealth for entrepreneurs, for his firm, for himself. The man was busy.
From 1998 to 2001, Credit Suisse brought 186 companies public, more than any other firm. Besides arranging these deals, Mr. Quattrone had the generosity of spirit to keep investors alert to the fine values these stocks represented. His analysts helped there, of course. So what if the companies' insiders were selling? So what if many of the companies later failed?
A true 24/7 guy, Mr. Quattrone shouldered other duties as well. He gamely volunteered to manage with two other executives Merchant Capital, a venture capital fund in which Credit Suisse First Boston executives, including himself, had invested. Wearing this hat, Mr. Quattrone spent valuable time selecting companies for the fund to buy. He also had to make sure that he could sell the stakes before they crashed. For instance, Merchant sold 115,119 shares of Sonus Networks in March 2001 for $2.4 million, or around $21 a share. Sonus's stock now trades at $1.33.
Mr. Quattrone also toiled to ensure that he and his family could sell their stakes in companies that his firm and others later brought public. As one test of his organizational skills, Mr. Quattrone had to navigate pesky lockup periods that restrict sales by pre-offering investors, who typically pay far less for their shares than the public does.
The man was up to the task. From late 2000 to early 2001, Mr. Quattrone sold stock worth $1.05 million in three companies in which he had invested before their public offerings: Interwoven and the Riverdeep Group, both software makers, and Sonus Networks, a communications concern. All are trading for a small fraction of what he received on his sales.
And the Quattrone Family Trust sold stock worth $1 million in 14 companies during the bubble. As trustee, along with his wife, Mr. Quattrone devoted time to the trust's many real estate transactions in Pebble Beach, Carmel and Los Altos, Calif.
Clearly, Mr. Quattrone had a lot on his plate. And the sooner securities regulators recognize this and stop harassing a highly productive executive, the quicker we can return to the good old days. Remember them, when no one asked questions and stocks only went up?

HEADLINE: Second Acts; 
Mike Dukakis Rides Again

BYLINE:  By MARK KATZ; Mark Katz, speechwriter and humorist, was a member of the Dukakis presidential campaign's rapid-response team.

 BODY:
MEMO to Governor Mike Dukakis 
From: Mark Katz 
 Subject: Thoughts on 2004 
 Now that your old rivals Gary Hart and Dick Gephardt have once again tossed their hats into the ring, it is only natural for people to recall the 1988 campaign and the Democratic Party's nominee for president. That was you. 
Here are some thoughts on why the time is so right for Mike Dukakis to run again. 
* Today, President Mike Dukakis could negotiate with Mikhail Gorbachev from a position of real strength. 
* The state you once governed so well is ripe for another "Massachusetts miracle." In fact, your slogan, "good jobs at good wages," resonates now more than ever! 
* Boston Harbor is clean. No problem there. 
* No one has given more speeches on "deja voodoo economics" -- humongous tax cuts and enormous defense spending -- than you. Suggested warmed-over sound bite: Bushonomics is deja-voodoo economics all over again again!
* Your killer stuff on the Strategic Defense Initiative -- "we need star schools, not Star Wars"-- still works for me. 
* Your running mate, Lloyd Bentsen, was vindicated by time: Dan Quayle was no Jack Kennedy. 
Governor, perhaps the most compelling case to be made for a new campaign is your track record against a similar-looking field of candidates. 
In 1988, you vanquished all rivals: an attractive Southern moderate, Al Gore (attention, John Edwards!); the spoiler, Jesse Jackson (Al Sharpton, look out!); an avuncular nerd, Paul Simon (Joe Lieberman's ears are burning); as well as a populist Congressman, Dick Gephardt (Dick Gephardt beware!). As for John Kerry, certainly your former lieutenant governor will have no choice but to endorse you like the good soldier and mensch that he is. Gary Hart? Go ahead and watch him campaign. You'll be bored. 
You may not know that your 1988 campaign had a rapid-response team, and that I was on it. Here are some of the hard-hitting lines I should have gotten to you sooner:
* I love the American flag and anyone who suggests otherwise will get a punch in the nose!
* Hey, wait a minute, Bernie Shaw -- that's my wife you are talking about!
* Willie Horton? Trent Lott!
Governor Dukakis, I strongly believe that you have a second date with destiny and urge you to run. Al Gore was wise to get out of the way. You are the guy with the grudge to settle against George Bush.

HEADLINE: The World: Juggler in Chief; 
Crises, Crises Everywhere. What Is A President To Do?

BYLINE:  By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
IRAQ. North Korea. Terrorism. Tax cuts. The stock market. The shuttle. The president? 
 Busy! 
 If, as F. Scott Fitzgerald wrote, "the test of a first-rate intelligence is the ability to hold two opposed ideas in mind at the same time and still retain the ability to function," the test of a successful presidency may be the ability to multitask in crises. In fact, it's more or less the definition of the job. 
Sure, President Bush had a full week: a space disaster and a wrenching memorial service, a $2.23 trillion budget proposal to Congress, a North Korean threat of "total war," a dramatic showdown at the United Nations over Iraqi defiance of weapons inspections, a stepped-up orange-level terrorism alert based on ominous intelligence rumblings. 
But the current confluence of challenging events is hardly new. Harry S. Truman faced almost nonstop crises from the moment he took office after Franklin D. Roosevelt's death in 1945. Roosevelt himself managed the Depression, then a global war, not to mention paralysis.
In 1957, Dwight D. Eisenhower was in the middle of a crisis over desegregation of Central High School in Little Rock, Ark., when the Soviet Union launched Sputnik, a silver satellite the size of a beachball, setting off a panic about preparedness in the cold war. By his own account, Richard M. Nixon managed "Six Crises" before he ever reached the White House, then created a doozy of his own in Watergate. Bill Clinton complained that it was his bad luck to be president in placid times of plenty, when greatness cannot easily emerge, then managed to become the second president in history to be impeached.
"This is what a president is -- a crisis manager," said the historian Robert Dallek, who wrote a two-volume biography of Johnson and has just finished another on Kennedy. "Of course, what suffers in all of this is any domestic agenda a president has. A standard reality is that war kills reform. The Spanish-American war killed populism, World War I killed Progressivism, World War II killed the New Deal, Korea killed the Fair Deal, Vietnam the Great Society."
Mr. Bush is not the first president to govern in a 24-hour news cycle, but the endless drumbeat no doubt worsens the sense of perpetual crisis. The media, and sometimes the politicians themselves, have a tendency to inflate every event, from a school shooting to a sniper on the loose to the prospect of nuclear war, into a round-the-clock happening.
"It plays into the story line that we are now living in this immensely more dangerous, unpredictable world," said Richard Norton Smith, a presidential historian who leads the Dole Institute of Politics at the University of Kansas. "I don't mean to make light of what we're going through now, but I do suspect that in ways difficult to quantify but impossible to ignore, that the media echo chamber is at least partially responsible for inflating a more or less permanent sense of crisis. History has gone the way of politics in becoming theater. It's the 'Oscarization' of history, overly produced, overly packaged."
To hear television anchors most days is to think that disaster is perpetually at hand. 
"It is certainly a challenge for the president, balancing the exigencies of the day," Peter Jennings intoned on ABC last week. "Two critical situations, in Iraq and North Korea, and an epic battle over financing the activities of the federal government, with the very real need to provide leadership at a time of national mourning."
Daniel Schorr, the veteran broadcast journalist, acknowledged on NPR last week that Washington has a hard time managing multiple problems and tends to be a "one-thing-at-a-time type of town." Attention spans are short, politicians rise and fall, issues come and go.
Professor Smith said, "Buried deep within it all is a continuing, albeit discreet, concern on the part of opinion leaders, real or imagined, about Bush's capacity."
To all appearances, Mr. Bush often seems the calmest one in the storm. For months, he has remained steadily determined to disarm Saddam Hussein, first in the face of warnings that doing so without a Middle East peace risked Arab rage, and now despite worries that North Korea is the more volatile threat.
"The old saying in F.D.R.'s Washington was 'Keep all the balls in the air without losing your own,' " said the historian Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr. "As Kennedy said after the Cuban missile crisis, 'I earned my pay last week.' You know, it's your job. Hysteria is the last thing to be recommended."
Ronald Reagan survived an assassination attempt after just weeks in office, then went on to face recession, survive the Iran-contra scandal and help end the cold war. Lyndon B. Johnson fared less well waging the Vietnam War while trying to build a Great Society, and was ultimately consumed by wrenching public division.
Harry C. McPherson Jr., who was Johnson's special counsel, said he marked the toll of White House crises in the annual albums of photographs that the Johnsons gave the senior staff at Christmas. "I got there in '65, and by '67 I looked pale and overtaxed and Johnson looked very gray." 
He remembered a lunch on the White House lawn in March 1968, just a couple of weeks before Johnson's surprise announcement that he would not run again. "You could hear the chants from the other side of the building from the demonstrators," Mr. McPherson recalled. "At one point, Johnson said, 'Why should I run?' I said, 'Well if I were you, I wouldn't, because there's so much grief in the air.' It was a moment in which the mistrust, the antiwar sentiment, the anti-civil rights sentiment in the South, the sum of it just seemed enormous."
There are costs and casualties for failing to keep up with events. The first President Bush soared to stratospheric approval ratings after the Persian Gulf war, but was seen as out of touch with a faltering economy and unemployed Americans. Jimmy Carter micromanaged the White House tennis courts but could not manage to confront a national malaise and the failure to rescue American hostages in Iran.
Sometimes the price is more personal. Everyone remembers Truman's acid letter to Paul Hume, The Washington Post music critic who panned the singing of his daughter, Margaret. Less well remembered is the week that led up to Truman's outburst.
On Nov. 28, 1950, Truman received word that the Chinese had plunged into the Korean War, with a quarter-million troops in a furious assault. Two days later, Truman set off a worldwide firestorm by suggesting at a news conference that the United States was prepared to use the atomic bomb in Korea. The man responsible for trying to calm that crisis was the president's press secretary, Charlie Ross, who was also his longtime friend.
On Tuesday, Dec. 5, Ross dropped dead of a heart attack, hours before Miss Truman's concert at Constitution Hall. The president kept the news from her until afterward. The next morning, when the president read Hume's assessment that Miss Truman "is flat a good deal of the time," he reached for paper and pen.
"Some day I hope to meet you," Truman wrote. "When that happens you'll need a new nose, a lot of beefsteak for black eyes, and perhaps a supporter below!"

HEADLINE: The Nation; 
For Republicans, Deficits Are Nothing to Be Ashamed of

BYLINE:  By ROBIN TONER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
THE idea of a balanced budget ranks high in the hierarchy of American political virtues. Thomas Jefferson proposed a balanced budget amendment to the Constitution in 1798, and Franklin D. Roosevelt ran with the promise of a balanced budget in 1932.
 President Bill Clinton, ever eager to shed the tax-and-spend image of the Democratic Party, embraced the cause of deficit reduction in his 1993 economic plan, and Newt Gingrich's revolutionary Contract With America promised, first and foremost, a balanced budget. By the late 1990's, both parties had managed to declare a victory over the demon deficit and were promising surpluses as far as the eye could see. 
 So how did it happen that a conservative president submitted a budget last week that included a substantial $304 billion deficit? And that his budget director, Mitchell E. Daniels Jr., described a balanced budget as a "high priority" for this administration, but quickly added, "It is not the top, let alone the only priority"? And that Mr. Daniels scoffed at the idea that these deficits would hurt the economy?
It was an Alice-through-the-looking-glass moment that revealed how much the debate over the deficit in recent years was not, really, about the deficit. Then and now, the debate is as much about politics as economics, about the two parties' vision of government and what it should -- and should not -- do.
For many conservatives, the deficit is simply not as important as cutting taxes, letting Americans keep "more of their own money" and limiting the size of the government. In general, spending on national security and the military is considered appropriate, spending on new social welfare entitlements is not -- with a few exceptions for popular items like prescription drugs.
Whatever the ultimate reality, after the gritty process of appropriations occurs, an article of faith is that less government is better. As the conservative strategist Grover Norquist put it: "If we had a little teeny government and a big deficit, I wouldn't care. It's the size of the government we're focused on. It's also the size of the government the left is focused on."
Indeed, for many liberals, eliminating the deficit is simply a counterintuitive means to an end: protecting the grand old entitlement programs of Medicare and Social Security and restoring the government's credibility so it could plausibly do (and spend) even more. 
Michael Waldman, a former speechwriter for Mr. Clinton, recalls Mr. Clinton telling him one night in 1998, when they were writing his State of the Union address, "Our mission is to save government from its own excesses so it can again be a progressive force."
All this helps explain why Republicans were defending deficits last week, though some did so through gritted teeth, while the supposedly free-spending Democrats were deploring said deficits at every turn.
"It's like a parallel world -- that a deficit doesn't matter and that it's coming from a conservative president," said Stanley E. Collender, a budget expert with Fleishman-Hillard, a public relations firm.
Former Senator Warren B. Rudman, the New Hampshire Republican who engineered a signature deficit reduction act of the 1980's, the Gramm-Rudman Act, said: "I don't understand it. It reminded me of the movie, 'Trading Places.' Everybody's had a role reversal."
For Mr. Norquist, it is simply a more honest debate. "In the 80's and 90's, the Democrats said, 'We're against deficits,' meaning, 'We're against tax cuts,' " he said. "And the Republicans said, 'We're against deficits,' meaning 'We're against spending increases.' " 
The deficit, in other words, was simply a useful proxy. When the surplus appeared, the real struggle was clear.
But what about the voters, warned unrelentingly through the years that deficits are dangerous and bad? 
"Having headlines from coast to coast that the Bush budget brings record deficits is still a bad day for the president," said Geoffrey Garin, a Democratic pollster. 
But Mr. Garin and others agree that the deficit is an abstraction that acquires political power only when linked with the concrete: bad economic fallout, threats to Social Security and a heavier burden of debt for future generations.
This is exactly the argument that Senator Kent Conrad of North Dakota, a longtime deficit hawk and ranking Democrat on the Senate Budget Committee, is making. "The president said in his State of the Union that we shouldn't pass the problems of today onto future generations, but that's precisely what he's doing," he said. 
Democrats are particularly scathing about the role of the administration's tax cuts in creating these budgetary strains.
On the other hand, Mr. Bush's budget, which reflects increases for the Pentagon, can be defended as the necessary response to the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks (though it does not include a projection of the cost of any war with Iraq). 
"The question is, What would you not do?" Mr. Daniels demanded last week. "Would you not try to spur economic growth? Would you not continue the strengthening of our defenses and the prosecution of the war on terror and the strengthening of homeland security?"
Many Democrats have a ready answer for what they would not do: create sweeping new tax cuts.
By week's end, Democrats were circulating the 1996 Republican platform that declared the budget deficit was "a stealth tax" that "pushes up interest rates" and would "mortgage our children's future."
Scholars note that while a reverence for balanced budgets runs deep in American history, so does the acceptance of deficit spending when necessary to pursue other goals. James D. Savage, professor of politics at the University of Virginia and author of "Balanced Budgets and American Politics," said the first deficit spending in the American colonies was in 1690 in -- of course -- Massachusetts.
The struggle to explain and defend deficit spending has a proud history as well. Franklin Roosevelt instructed his speechwriter in 1936 to "give a good and convincing explanation" of what he had meant four years earlier, when he had promised a balanced budget, given that he had subsequently incurred substantial deficits. 
His speechwriter replied that there was only one possible explanation. "Mr. President, the only thing you can say about the 1932 speech is to deny categorically that you ever made it."

HEADLINE: Venezuelan Oilman: Rebel With a New Cause 

BYLINE:  By JUAN FORERO 

DATELINE: CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 8 

 BODY:
He wears pastel-colored suits and wire-rimmed glasses. His thinning hair is neatly combed. Restrained and a little stiff, he speaks in the dry tones and jargon-filled language of a technocrat on such obscure topics as 1958 American oil regulations or 1930's energy policies in Venezuela.
 In short, he looks and sounds every bit the oil executive he is -- the president of one of the largest, most complicated and, these days, most embattled companies in the world, Petroleos de Venezuela. 
 But make no mistake, Ali Rodriguez still sees himself as a revolutionary. His boss, after all, is President Hugo Chavez, whose sharp tongue and efforts to remake Venezuelan society have left the country deeply divided and on the edge of economic collapse. 
Though his resume makes no mention of it, Mr. Rodriguez has leftist, some would say radical, credentials. For 20 years, he was a clandestine agitator and a fighter in a Cuban-inspired rebel movement, where he specialized in political proselytizing and making bombs, according to former guerrilla comrades.
"I am still a revolutionary, of course," said Mr. Rodriguez, 64, who remains a member of a party, Fatherland for All, on the left fringe of the government's coalition. "But it is under different conditions, in accordance with the realities of the day."
The irony of how the son of a humble Andean farmer became an idealistic guerrilla and, years later, rose to the upper echelon of a widely hailed company makes Mr. Rodriguez shake his head and smile. To be sure, he does not seem entirely comfortable poring through planning documents, but though he does not carry a rifle anymore, he still says he is fighting to shake up the system for the betterment of the poor. 
Still, the reality is that today's rebels are his former oil executives. For more than two months they have been out in the streets protesting against Mr. Chavez and, by extension, Mr. Rodriguez's management of Petroleos de Venezuela S.A.
Indeed, thousands of Petroleos workers helped to topple Mr. Chavez for a few days in April, and then gave backbone to a national strike of several weeks that strangled oil exports to Venezuela's main customer, the United States.
Mr. Rodriguez may have once believed in hemispherewide revolution. But these days, as he looks out from his penthouse office, he sounds more like an unforgiving capitalist. He vows that the thousands of dissident workers who went on strike -- and continue to strike -- will never return to their jobs.
"Their movement seriously damaged the company and the country," Mr. Rodriguez said, his ire just slightly shaking his calm demeanor. "That is why I am indignant at what happened, because it makes our work so much harder. We have to reduce investments, and that means a loss of possibilities, a retreat for the country."
"There is no possibility of an amnesty whatsoever," he added.
Petroleos de Venezuela, once valued at $110 billion, is producing just half what it did before the strike, which ended in the non-oil sector last week after 63 days. Moribund oil fields are sanding up, losing the ability to produce oil; the company's reputation is in shambles; and the 9,000 workers Mr. Rodriguez has fired represent a loss of experience and skill.
Whether to take back striking workers is one of the critical decisions Mr. Rodriguez has made as he tries to guide Petroleos de Venezuela through venomous political waters into uncharted territory.
To his left are hard-liners in the governing party who believe Mr. Rodriguez was too lax in purging dissenters and too close to the global oil industry to be of much use to Mr. Chavez's reforms. 
To his right are those who accuse him of allowing ideology to cloud logic, resulting in a scaled-down company that will generate far less wealth than before.
Those who know him see Mr. Rodriguez as independent, decisive and clear on how to reshape the company. He has a plan to break the company into eastern and western divisions, making the Caracas headquarters, where dissidents planned antigovernment walkouts, obsolete. He proposes reducing the company's scope, possibly selling off refineries and other assets overseas.
Mr. Rodriguez insisted that Venezuela would soon export as much petroleum as before the strike, about 2.7 million barrels a day, most to the United States. He suggested that as demand grows in the years to come, so would Venezuelan supply.
But the company he envisions would also conform more to Mr. Chavez's vision, to generate a steady stream of revenues for social programs. It would also continue forging ties with the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries.
"I think that effectively, at least culturally, the true nationalization of petroleum is coming," Mr. Rodriguez said recently, though he emphasized that foreign companies would continue to operate here. The role of a company that controls such riches, he said in an interview, is to "incorporate that value of the natural resource for the maximum benefit."
But getting the company back to where it once was will be difficult -- some say impossible -- even for a longtime oilman who served as president and general secretary of OPEC before taking over the Venezuelan company last April.
"It is hard to see the company overcome this quantitative and qualitative setback," said Mazhar al-Shereidah, an oil economist who helped write oil regulations for the Chavez government. "He is not in charge of a healthy company. They are giving him a company, a body, that is in intensive care."
The company's 2003 budget is being cut by $2.7 billion, to about $6 billion, to offset the slide in revenue. Mr. Rodriguez acknowledges that investments that are crucial for exploration are being cut by 30 percent.
If he is strained by the Herculean task ahead, Mr. Rodriguez does not seem to show it. He has learned to be resilient. 
"As I have said, everything you do as human beings, is a step forward," he explained. "You learn from the hard knocks, while someone who does not go through it might not find it so easy." 
The hard knocks came in the 1950's when Mr. Rodriguez was a student agitator fighting against the strongman Marcos Perez Jimenez. Even after Perez Jimenez was overthrown in 1958, Mr. Rodriguez said he continued in the Venezuelan underground, pressing for change.
Accused of having detonated a fatal bomb blast, which he denies, Mr. Rodriguez fled into the mountains in 1964 and joined others intent on toppling the government. Former fellow fighters remembered Comandante Fausto, as he was known, as shrewd and tireless, excelling in combat and political work and spending his free time listening to classical music.
"He could move in any scenario," said Alberto Tirso, 61, a former comrade who now opposes the Chavez government. "He was a man of valor, very serene, a great reader. I remember he always carried four or five books in his knapsack."
But the revolution never caught on, and in 1979 Mr. Rodriguez was one of the last rebels to demobilize under a government amnesty. He became a lawyer and won a seat in the lower house of Congress where his interest in oil blossomed, leading to the chairmanship of the energy committee. When Mr. Chavez was elected president in 1998, he became minister of mines and energy.
"I have had the good fortune of being in different situations that have to do with petroleum," he said. "And now it is as an entrepreneur, a role I had never thought I would play in my life."

3.1 million barrels a day before the strike.
1.3 million now, say dissidents. The government says the figure is 1.9 million.

HEADLINE: THREATS AND RESPONSES: THE DRAFT; 
A New Tactic Against War: Renew Talk About Draft

BYLINE:  By CARL HULSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 

 BODY:
Back in the late 1960's, Pete Stark was known as the hippie banker for installing a huge peace sign on his bank in the East Bayand counseling draftees on whether to flee to Canada.
 Now, Mr. Stark, a pugnacious liberal House member from Northern California, is back in the antiwar movement. But he and some of his fellow Democrats are trying a new approach -- advocating a return of the draft. 
 "My constituents at home think I have lost my mind," Mr. Stark said. "They say, 'Why do you want to give the military more soldiers?' I am supporting the draft as a way to oppose the war."
Mr. Stark, a veteran who said the chief danger he faced in the military was getting his tie caught in a typewriter, is co-sponsoring a proposal by Representatives Charles B. Rangel of New York and John Conyers Jr. of Michigan, both Democrats. 
Those two lawmakers, veterans and senior members of the Congressional Black Caucus, say the risks of combat losses should be spread more equitably among Americans. They have a Senate ally, Ernest F. Hollings, Democrat of South Carolina, who says he wants to give advocates of American military action in Iraq and elsewhere a little something to chew over.
"One way to avoid a lot more wars to come is institute the draft," Mr. Hollings said. "You will find that this country will sober up, and its leadership, too."
While Democrats are climbing aboard the induction bandwagon, Republicans are dropping off. Representative Nick Smith of Michigan, who in the past had his own draft proposal, has no interest in helping Democrats with theirs, an aide said. Republicans generally view the Rangel plan as a cynical effort to rouse antiwar sentiment.
"There is no serious discussion of it," Representative John A. Boehner, the Ohio Republican who is chairman of the Committee on Education and the Workforce, said about bringing back the draft.
Mr. Rangel, who was wounded in Korea and decorated for his efforts to evacuate the injured during a battle, makes no apologies for trying to score a political point. "I hope I am saying that war is hell and if indeed our country's security is in jeopardy, then we must as a country be prepared to make sacrifice," Mr. Rangel said. 
While few in Congress give the legislation any chance, it is reminding some of the days when the lottery they followed most closely was not Powerball but the one conducted by the Selective Service. Mr. Rangel is scheduled to address students at Harvard on Monday, a meeting that could illustrate whether the draft still has the capacity to stir crowds on college campuses.
It is already clear that the subject continues to elicit raw emotions. Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld was forced to apologize last month for saying Vietnam draftees had added "no value" to the military, a comment that infuriated veterans groups.
Though Mr. Rumsfeld might have had to back down from his choice of words, the Pentagon is adamantly opposed to a return to the draft, saying its all-volunteer military is a superior fighting force. 
"The all-volunteer force has served the nation for more than a quarter-century, providing a military that is experienced, smart, disciplined, and representative of America," a recently circulated Pentagon position paper said.
The draft has had a long and troubled place in United States military history, from colonial conscripts through the riots of the Civil War to the draft-card burning of Vietnam. That was the last war in which some young American men were forced to serve. Faced with protests, President Richard M. Nixon abolished the draft in 1973.
Those advocating a return of the draft do not quarrel with the capabilities of the modern American military. They argue that it is more of a fairness issue, that the weight of combat should not fall just on those who signed up, often to get ahead economically or educationally.
"In the event that we do find ourselves in a war," Mr. Rangel said, "those that have to go to fight should not be selected from those who volunteered because of economic circumstances."
Mr. Hollings said bringing back the draft might also ease the burden on National Guard and reserve personnel whose lives are disrupted by frequent deployments. 
Were the draft in place today, Mr. Rangel said, President Bush would be required to make a more forceful and detailed case about why intervention in Iraq is necessary. The draft, he said, "means that when you are selling war, you have to be good about it."
