HEADLINE: BUSINESS TRAVEL; 
Sao Paulo's Fancy Hotels Feature Bargain Rates

BYLINE:  By TONY SMITH 

DATELINE: SAO PAULO, Brazil, Feb. 10 

 BODY:
Rogerio Fasano, scion of Sao Paulo's most celebrated dynasty of restaurateurs, sidesteps sacks of cement as he paces back and forth across what soon will be the lobby of his new luxury hotel, bearing -- of course -- the family name.
 "I find lobbies in most hotels lifeless, devoid of activity," Mr. Fasano said. "But here I want to give the entrance a bit of human warmth." 
 So he will give it soft lighting and antique club armchairs that he brought from London and Paris. He will place the reception desk discreetly at the back, behind the elevators. And he will put the family's flagship restaurant, Fasano, and jazz bar, Barreto, both Sao Paulo institutions, off to the side. 
In April, the 68-room Fasano will be the latest in a string of luxury hotels to open in Sao Paulo over the last 18 months, revolutionizing businesstravel to one of the primary Latin American destinations for United States business travelers.
For years, visitors complained about the shortage of first-rate accommodations and the inflated prices of the lodgings that were available.
Suddenly, all that has changed.
In June 2001, the Emiliano, just around the corner from the Fasano in the fashionable Jardins district, opened its 19 suites and 38 apartments. Last year, the Hyatt and Hilton chains both opened 450-plus-room hotels in a new business district by the Pinheiros River, closely followed by the Unique, an ultramodern hotel that hangs between giant concrete pillars like a huge slice of watermelon and is near Ibirapuera, Sao Paulo's equivalent of Central Park.
Corporate executives who are hitting town for the first time in a year or so are remarking on the difference.
"When I first came to Sao Paulo, you only had the usual big chain hotels to choose from; it was a bit boring," said Manfred Ferber, a mergers and acquisitions specialist with Dr. Ferber & Partners in Munich, who has traveled to Sao Paulo at least five times over the last year. "Now, with these new places, you get a feeling of a mixture of the best hotels from around the world -- the Costes in Paris, the Delano in Miami, the Mondrian in L.A. I've told all my friends about the Unique."
The flurry of five-star inaugurations, the construction of lower-priced corporate apartments known as aparthotels and the faltering world economy have together created an oversupply of rooms, according to Luiz Carlos Nunes, president of the Brazilian Hotel Industry Association. Mr. Nunes says Sao Paulo will have 57,000 hotel beds by the end of this year to accommodate an annual market of five million visitors. By contrast, he says, New York City had 60,000 beds for a market of 35 million visitors in 2001.
The glut of rooms is bad news for established hotels. Even high-end hotels around the Avenida Paulista, a main banking district, have seen occupancy rates drop to levels as low as 30 percent and are lowering their prices drastically.
"It's not just us; everybody's hurting," said Paulo Patullo, commercial director at the Maksoud Plaza, a classic five-star hotel near Paulista. Most hotels in the city are less than one-third full, he says, and he blames the aparthotels which he says are cheaper to build and run than traditional hotels.
Whatever the reason for the price slump, the fresh competition is good news for bargain-hunting business travelers. "Today, in Sao Paulo, you can stay at a five-star hotel for what you would pay for a three-star in Rio de Janeiro," said Flavio Vieira of Grife Turismo, a Sao Paulo travel agency specializing in business events. "Hotels are willing to negotiate prices, even in the luxury sector."
And what luxury. Here is what you get at the Emiliano for about $250 a night: a massage on your arrival; a luxury apartment with remote control television, DVD player, telephone and air-conditioning all run from a high-technology console in the living and sleeping area; a home theater; Eames chairs; art books; and the choice of eight types of pillows atop a huge bed decked out in 300-count Egyptian cotton and a Hungarian goose-down comforter. A butler service sends two staff members to your room to pamper you by unpacking your suitcase and even checking what wine vintage you prefer. And, oh yes, there are heated toilet seats.
For an extra $140, travelers can be whisked by helicopter from Sao Paulo's airport to Emiliano's rooftop landing pad, avoiding what is normally a grueling hourlong road trip.
"When Idecided to build this hotel, my idea was for a place where guests would be treated in the way I always would like to be served and received while traveling," said Carlos Alberto Filgueiras, Emiliano's owner.
Although he says at least one major American hotelier has inquired about a possible alliance, Mr. Filgueiras says he prefers to stay independent. "The big chains don't know your name, who you are, what paper you read, whether you like popcorn, coconut milk or Bordeaux," he said, stressing that the Emiliano even keeps records on the temperatures that guests set for their air-conditioning and showers. On subsequent visits, he said, the apartments are made ready to fit clients' tastes.
Such an eye for detail is just what makes people want to stay in smaller luxury hotels instead of the chains, said Jonas Siaulys, owner of the Unique, which cost $30 million.
"Our guests are attracted by things like the red illuminated swimming pool, by the round windows, by the fact that the bedroom and bathroom can be combined into one open space so you can watch a movie while you're in the bathtub and your partner is reading on the bed," Mr. Siaulys said.
Modern design is crucial to the image of the Emiliano and Unique -- Unique was designed by the iconoclastic Sao Paulo architect Ruy Ohtake, while the Emiliano's lobby is dotted with chairs made from golden rope created by the well-known Brazilian designers Fernando and Umberto Campana. However, some business travelers might find them simply too chic.
"When traveling alone, I'd stay at the Unique, but with more conservative colleagues, I think I'd go for the Inter-Conti," said Mr. Ferber, the German investment banker. "First, design hotels don't always have fully fledged business facilities. Second, even though it's cheap to stay there at the moment, they look expensive and that might be interpreted as extravagance by some clients."
Mr. Fasano, however, says his clients will not be put off by extravagance. After all, his Fasano restaurant sells more white truffles than any other establishment in Brazil.
But he has shied away from ostentation.
The Fasano is a 25-floor, English red brick structure designed by the Brazilian architects Isay Weinfeld and Marcio Kogan in a style that recalls Sao Paulo's first Art Deco skyscrapers of the 1940's.
The interior decoration is subdued and comfortable, rather than outright opulent. But it is no less glamorous for that.
"We want to give an extra dose of charm and glamor to staying in a hotel," Mr. Fasano said. "Wherever I go, I always prefer to stay in the worst room of the best hotel, rather than the best room in a so-so hotel."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Unique, an ultramodern hotel in Sao Paulo designed by the iconoclastic architect Ruy Ohtake, is near the city's equivalent of Central Park. "I've told all my friends about the Unique," one traveler from Germany said. (Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Moody's Cuts Bond Rating For California 

BYLINE:  By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The bond rating for California was cut yesterday by Moody's Investors Service because of a record $34.6 billion budget shortfall expected in the next two years.
 The downgrade occurred four days after California's top two finance officers met with Moody's and Standard & Poor's in New York to make their case for not cutting the state's rating, citing Gov. Gray Davis's plan for closing the gap. 
 Investors are "looking for significant action to be taken," said Joseph Deane, who oversees $7 billion of municipal bonds at Citigroup Asset Management in New York, including about $1.25 billion of California state and local debt. The Moody's downgrade is more proof "everybody's watching" whether the state can take steps needed to close the deficit.
Moody's lowered California's $21.9 billion in general obligation debt to A2 from A1, bringing California's assessment in line with ratings assigned by S.&P. and Fitch Ratings after downgrades in December. California is tied with Louisiana and New York for the lowest state credit grade from Moody's. Moody's rating has now dropped one level lower than the worst grade during the state's recession a decade ago.
Lower ratings can cut the value of existing bonds and raise future borrowing costs. The impact of Moody's downgrade may be muted because the state's bond prices have already tumbled on concern over the growing deficit, investors said. The state plans to sell $900 million in general obligation debt on Thursday.
The downgrade reflects "an expectation the state will not be able to sufficiently address the imbalance in the upcoming fiscal year" that begins July 1, a Moody's statement said. The rating company expects deficits "to persist beyond fiscal 2004."
Ten-year California bonds yield 4.33 percent, or 0.46 of a percentage point more than bonds with the highest Aaa rating, according to Bloomberg data.

HEADLINE: A Glimpse Of a Future In a New Kind Of Light 

BYLINE:  By BARNABY J. FEDER 

 BODY:
How many scientists does it take to change the light bulb?
 It's not a joke. The ubiquitous light bulb is quietly on its way to becoming as quaint a relic as the gas lanterns it replaced more than a century ago. Incandescent bulbs, neon tubes and fluorescent lamps are starting to give way to light-emitting microchips that work longer, use less power and allow designers to use light in ways they never have before. 
 The chips -- 18 million of them -- are already on display in the $37 million Nasdaq sign in Times Square. They are in the vibrant facade of the Goodman Theater in Chicago and adorned last year's White House Christmas tree. More notable, the chips are penetrating blue-collar tasks like illuminating traffic lights, brake lights and exit signs. 
Lighting experts expect the pace of change to pick up as researchers continue their relentless efforts to shrink the chips to microscopic size, improve their already impressive energy efficiency and increase their brightness. The chips are expected to move into the general home and office lighting market as early as 2007.
The eventual result, the experts say, will be savings of billions of dollars annually in energy and maintenance costs and a revolution in how people use lighting in homes and offices to influence their moods.
"We are not talking about replacing light bulbs," said Arpad Bergh, a former Bell Labs researcher who is president of an industry trade group working with the government to promote the new technology. "We are talking about a totally new lighting industry."
The vision of revolutionary new uses of light reflects the ability of such lighting, also known as solid-state lighting, to switch virtually instantaneously among more than a million shades of color at the command of a computer. Researchers talk about using the technology to coordinate lighting effects in a theater with film scenes, which might make a battle sequence appear to leap off the screen, or to alter the color and brightness of lighting in nursing homes at appropriate times, which could help stimulate or soothe residents. 
The chips, which are known as light-emitting diodes, or L.E.D.'s, have huge performance advantages in many mundane tasks. In devices like traffic lights, for example, they consume 80 percent less electricity than do the bulbs they replace and last up to 10 times as long. Moreover, they have the safety advantage of gradually fading instead of unpredictably burning out.
Beyond such obvious benefits, though, it is the ease of mating the chips to computers that is driving interest. Programs simple enough to run on a hand-held personal digital assistant can alter the intensity, pattern and colors produced by solid-state lights. Color Kinetics, a five-year-old lighting company based in Boston, calculates that the various chips it packages with computer controls can generate up to 16.7 million colors.
That flexibility is already used in advertising and entertainment. Solid-state lights are featured in numerous Times Square signs and Broadway shows like "Hairspray." Mad Doc Software, based in Lawrence, Mass., has designed tools to link video games to room lighting so that a player in a Star Trek game who is passing a red nebula would have one side of a room shift in color. 
"It's fantastic how much more immersive the game becomes," said Ian Davis, founder of Mad Doc.
Architects and building designers have far more ambitious possibilities in mind, including mimicking indoors the variability of natural lighting as the day progresses. Lighting experts predict that once costs come down, such flexibility will greatly increase the attention paid to the role of light in people's moods and health.
"L.E.D.'s are only limited by what we put in the computer," said Fred Oberkircher, director of the Center for Lighting Education at Texas Christian University. "I'm waiting for the day when clouds of light float across my ceiling."
It may sound whimsical, but Mr. Oberkircher's vision is rooted in research suggesting that people find the rigid lighting environments they normally work and dwell in boring and, in some cases, unhealthy. While most market projections are based on assessing the progress of solid-state lights toward matching the cost and performance of traditional incandescent and fluorescent white lights, some experts say that such comparisons miss the point.
"The ability to do things you couldn't do before is what will trigger mass adoption," said Michael Holt, president of LumiLeds, a leading diode producer that is a joint venture of Agilent Technologies and Philips Lighting. "People will become much more attuned to the mental and health aspects of light in the next 5 to 10 years."
The chips driving the revolution currently cost too much to use in general lighting. The cost of white-light diodes for standard electrical sockets is anywhere from 40 to 100 times that of comparably bright incandescent bulbs, according to various industry estimates.
But like their cousins the microprocessors, the diode chips are continually improving in performance and plunging in price. They could become cheap and luminous enough to break into the general lighting market as early as 2007, according to a technology road map developed by the Optoelectronics Industry Development Association, the trade group Mr. Bergh heads.
By then, the chips are likely to be facing competition in many specialty applications from a newer form of solid-state lighting known as organic light-emitting diodes, or O.L.E.D's. These light-emitting plastics are not nearly as bright or durable as the chips but may prove to be more economic for many uses. Like other polymers, they would be manufactured in continuous processes instead of batch by batch the way microchips are made. They are already being used to light small displays, like the battery-life monitor in the Norelco Spectra razor.
Whatever the progress, experts like Mr. Holt and Charles A. Becker, head of the L.E.D. for lighting project at General Electric's research laboratory, say incandescent bulbs are likely to remain so cheap that they will be widely used for years to come as white-light sources, even though they are quite inefficient and fragile.
Light bulbs, which lighting experts deride as heaters that happen to give off visible light, work by forcing electricity through a metal filament in a vacuum. About 6 percent of the energy ends up as light. Today's light chips are up to five times as efficient. 
Researchers say that further development could double the chips' efficiency advantage. If achievable, these gains would allow solid-state lighting to surpass the efficiency of fluorescent lamps.
The first practical diode, which emitted low intensity red light, was invented in 1962 at General Electric. Red and amber L.E.D.'s came to market in the 1970's as on-off signals and other indicators for electronics and machinery. Using diodes for general lighting seemed laughable until researchers at companies like Cree, Nichia Chemical, Toshiba and Hewlett-Packard discovered much brighter materials and relatively inexpensive emitters of blue and green light in the early 1990's.
Blue diodes were crucial to generating white light, which could be produced by blending the blue, red and green or by shining the blue light through a coating of yellow phosphor. By last year, products built around the new generation of higher-intensity colors and white light had become a $1.2 billion market, according to Dr. Robert V. Steele, director of optoelectronics research at Strategies Unlimited, a market research company in Mountain View, Calif.
The biggest market at the moment is in outdoor signs and in lighting the contours of buildings like fast food restaurants, where the diodes are displacing neon. The nation's four million or so traffic signals represent a smaller market, but diodes have taken over a third of it and continue to spread rapidly, according to Gary R. Durgin, vice president for business development for Dialight, a solid-state lighting supplier based in Farmingdale, N.J.
Buses, trucks and autos have diodes in brake lights and interior lighting. Styling and maintenance benefits are driving the trend, but there are safety benefits, too. Because the diodes light up fractions of a second faster than do incandescent lights when a driver hits the brakes, anyone trailing a vehicle at 65 miles an hour is able to stop about 19 feet sooner, according to a study at the University of Michigan Transportation Research Institute.
New research fields like nanotechnology are spurring innovation. In July, for instance, Kopin, a manufacturer of semiconductors and electronics displays based in Taunton, Mass., disclosed that it had discovered a way to make millions of pockets just two nanometers thick -- the width of just 10 hydrogen atoms -- in the dust-size light-emitting chips. The nanopockets, as Kopin calls them, help light escape the chip without being obstructed by microscopic defects in the chip's crystal structure. The new design cut the voltage needed to get light out of the chips enough to grab the attention of makers of battery-operated electronics.
As a result, Kopin, which was once unknown in the industry, is gearing up to ship 100 million light chips this year to contractors who will package them with power and optical components for use by device manufacturers.
The first applications, according to John Fan, Kopin's chief executive, are likely to be back-lighting for liquid-crystal displays on portable electronics and night-lighting for keys on devices like cellphones. The chips are so small that the entire year's production could be easily enclosed in a golf ball.
Mr. Fan and other entrepreneurs have been attracted by the potentially huge environmental and energy returns from replacing traditional lights with solid-state devices. One widely cited study for the Energy Department concluded that the widespread use of solid-state lighting by 2025 could cut electricity demand 10 percent and save consumers $100 billion.
Getting there is not a trivial challenge, though. Researchers say there are numerous hurdles to overcome in fields like manufacturing technology, chip design and extraction of the light created in the chips. 
The new technology also requires changes in regulations and standards. For instance, the advertised life of a product line of light bulbs is set as the length of time until half of them fail in tests. But solid-state lighting slowly degrades rather than burning out so the industry is struggling to come up with an agreed standard for "useful life."
While many in the industry are confident about where their markets will end up, the hurdles make it hard to project how they will get there.
"It's easier to know what will happen 10 years from now than 2," said Mr. Durgin of Dialight.

HEADLINE: Washington Talk; 
Conservatives Now See Deficits as a Tool to Fight Spending

BYLINE:  By DAVID FIRESTONE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 

 BODY:
Seven years ago, before the political ground shifted in Washington, freshman Representative Sue Myrick won the "deficit hawk" award of the Concord Coalition, a group dedicated to eradicating red ink in all its federal forms.
 Four terms later, Ms. Myrick is now an elder in the House and the chairwoman of the Republican Study Committee, a group of the most fiscally conservative House members. But after terrorist attacks and the Republican takeover of Congress and the White House, Ms. Myrick, and the group she leads, have adopted a new attitude toward the deficit they once abhorred. They are not fond of it, and they hope it goes away someday, but for now they say it plays a useful role in fighting off something they like even less -- government spending. 
 "Anything that will help us stop spending money, I'm in favor of," Ms. Myrick, of North Carolina, said in an interview last week. "This place is set up to spend money; you know it's just the nature of the beast. And we've tried to say, hey, we don't have to spend so much of it. And if there's a deficit, that may help us."
Many of the 70 members of the study committee, which is growing in influence, have praised President Bush for proposing a budget that deeply cuts a wide variety of taxes and carries a record budget deficit. In the next week or so, the group will issue its own budget proposal that adds even more tax cuts to the administration's, including cuts in the capital gains and alternative minimum taxes.
Being half in love with deficits represents a remarkable shift in thinking from the group's early days, which were consumed with balancing the budget. Members of the group, still known on Capitol Hill as the Cats from their former name, the Conservative Action Team, were among the strongest advocates for a balanced budget amendment to the Constitution. Representative Tom DeLay of Texas, the committee's chairman in the early 1990's, called it a higher priority than cutting taxes.
"Jack Kemp worships at the altar of tax cuts," Mr. DeLay, now the House majority leader, said derisively in 1997 of the party's best-known supply-side theorist. "Jack has always said that deficits don't matter. We think that deficits do matter."
But now Mr. DeLay supports the president's budget, which has a $307 billion deficit. Several of the Cats cite an essay in The Wall Street Journal last month by Milton Friedman, the Nobel-prize winning economist, which sets out the new theory on the utility of deficits that result from tax cuts.
"Deficits will be an effective -- I would go so far as to say, the only effective -- restraint on the spending propensities of the executive branch and the legislature," wrote Mr. Friedman, who compared government spenders to spendthrift children. On Friday, R. Glenn Hubbard, chairman of the White House Council of Economic Advisers, acknowledged that reducing the size of government was a goal of the deficit plan.
Less than a decade ago, that notion would have been anathema to the ambitious Republicans who seized the House from the Democrats. In 1995, the Republican-led House passed a budget resolution accompanied by extensive documentation about the virtues of a balanced budget, saying the benefits included "lower interest rates, a faster rate of economic growth, increased national wealth, increased rate of saving and investment, faster growth in the capital stock, higher productivity and improved trade balances." But now White House economists say there is no evidence for any of that, and many House conservatives agree.
"I think it's clear now that there's no correlation between the size of the deficit and interest rates," said Representative Patrick J. Toomey of Pennsylvania, who leads the study committee's budget task force. "There's a much better case to be made that the deficit will force spending down." 
All of this has produced considerableridicule from the Democrats, who now sound more avid about balancing the budget than the Republicans ever were.
"Where have all the Republican budget hawks gone?" Representative Nancy Pelosi of California, the House Democratic leader, asked a few days ago. "They have become the endangered species."
There are, actually, a few left. Representative Gil Gutknecht of Minnesota, a member of the study committee, said he would have a hard time justifying tax cuts while fighting terrorism, improving domestic security and paying for prescription drugs.
"This is a tough pill to swallow," Mr. Gutknecht told the White House budget director at a Budget Committee hearing last week. 
But a far larger number of Cats are convinced that the tax cuts will eventually produce a robust economic growth that will bleach away the red. Given their success last year in forcing significant changes in the House appropriations process, they will probably get their way in the House, at least until the far less ideological Senate gets its hands on the budget. 
"We're not playing games here," said Representative Paul D. Ryan of Wisconsin. "We are going to have an impact on this budget."

HEADLINE: ON HOCKEY; 
Sather Makes a Move To Right a Wrong

BYLINE:  By Joe Lapointe 

 BODY:
The trade of Aleksei Kovalev from Pittsburgh to the Rangers yesterday was good for New York, bad for the Penguins and a mixed blessing for the N.H.L. Kovalev is a dynamic attacker who learned his craft with Dynamo Moscow in the Soviet Union and began his North American career with the Rangers. His return to Manhattan helps them correct one of the great mistakes of their long decline since their Stanley Cup championship in 1994.
 The deal was an obvious move for Glen Sather, who has been a blithe failure thus far in almost three seasons as the Rangers' president and general manager. Having replaced Bryan Trottier as coach two weeks ago, Sather used the financial power of Madison Square Garden to acquire an expensive player who might help put the Rangers in the playoffs for the first time in six seasons. Kovalev might even help save Sather's three jobs. 
 Sather refused to confirm reports that the Rangers sent $4 million to the Penguins to sweeten the eight-player deal. He even refused to reveal the Rangers' payroll, which, at about $80 million, is the highest in the league.
Sather's silence said plenty. With the Ottawa Senators and the Buffalo Sabres in bankruptcy protection and the Penguins having emerged from it only four years ago, the N.H.L. has reached a state of financial crisis in the 11th year of Commissioner Gary Bettman's tenure. Few teams can afford a player like Kovalev, who will probably receive a $7 million salary next season through arbitration or negotiation.
As much as Bettman has tried to blame the N.H.L. Players Association for the current crisis, it is Bettman's business plan that has expanded the league market to 30 teams and increased the bidding for good players. It is Bettman who has twice agreed to extend the collective bargaining agreement that he gained after a 15-week lockout in 1994-95. It is Bettman who must explain why N.H.L. owners are occasionally underfinanced and sometimes even in trouble with the law.
Bettman should also explain the league policy regarding money and trades. The Islanders were stopped a few years ago from trading Ziggy Palffy to the Rangers because the deal included the transfer of several million dollars from the Rangers to the Islanders. Mike Milbury, general manager of the Islanders, said yesterday that the different treatment of that proposed deal and the Kovalev trade "does raise some questions about how we do business as a league."
So why was the Islanders' deal forbidden then but the Penguins' deal allowed now? Bettman was not available for comment yesterday, but Bill Daly, the N.H.L.'s executive vice president, said: "The league does have limits. They are not hard and fast limits. Each situation is assessed on a case-by-case basis."
Daly said the proposed Palffy trade in 1999 depended on money and that yesterday's Kovalev trade did not. "The financial issue is important," Daly said. "The bottom line is the Penguins were determined to move this player. They were going to cut the best deal they could possibly get.
"At this time, there is a financial reality to all player transactions. Under the circumstances as we know them, we were not comfortable disapproving this trade."
From a competitive standpoint, the trade is disheartening for Pittsburgh. Now 10th in the race for eight playoff berths in the Eastern Conference, the Penguins have traded their second-best player to an Atlantic Division rival that trails them by 2 points. This tells the ticket buyers in Pittsburgh that salary dumps are more important than winning games. Craig Patrick, the Penguins' general manager, who has made many bold and good trades, got little in this one besides money and fringe players -- no first-round draft choices, no front-line players.
Kovalev, who will turn 30 on Feb. 24, has matured since his days as a confused young Ranger. He shoots the puck more and has learned to taper his skills to the narrower North American rinks. Kovalev still plays with enthusiasm and with gifts that are appreciated by teammates and opponents. From a Penguins' standpoint, this makes the deal worse than the 2001 trade in which Pittsburgh sent a disgruntled Jaromir Jagr to the Washington Capitals.
The Rangers' championship team in 1994 was animated by four Russian players. Along with Kovalev, the other great young one was defenseman Sergei Zubov. But both fell out of favor when Colin Campbell took over as coach for Mike Keenan. Campbell had little patience with them and there were personality conflicts.
Now if Pavel Bure returns from knee surgery, the Rangers will have five players from the recent Russian Olympic team. At forward, they are bigger, tougher and more talented than they have been in years. Despite four games without a victory under Sather, they have played acceptably and have shown signs that their whole might someday blend into something equal to or better than the sum of their parts.
In the larger perspective, Kovalev could help this happen and enhance the league at the same time. With interest flagging and its television picture growing faint, the N.H.L. needs some excitement in its largest market, the one located a few blocks from league headquarters.
While a surge into the playoffs remains unlikely for the Rangers, even the quest for a postseason spot could spice up local rivalries and general hockey interest. Ten of the Rangers' final 24 games are against the Penguins, the Flyers, the Devils and the Islanders. Kovalev is usually at his best in big games against top rivals.
Despite all Sather's mistakes so far, and despite troubling implications for the league over all, the return of Kovalev to Manhattan is the best move by this franchise since the firing of Neil Smith as president and general manager in 2000. As this long, dreary winter slogs toward distant spring, hockey here has a heartbeat.

HEADLINE: Silver Is an Albany Strongman, And It's Not Because He's Flashy 

BYLINE:  By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

 BODY:
Speaker Sheldon Silver, the most powerful Democrat in Albany, is having lunch at a tiny kosher pizza parlor on the Lower East Side, the center of his universe, when some local residents approach to ask why they have not yet received their share of grants for staying put after 9/11.
 "The governor has your checks," Mr. Silver says in his gravelly voice, subtly shifting the blame to his political nemesis. 
 Fischer Fisch, an elderly fixture in the neighborhood who has known Mr. Silver since he was a boy, begins to razz him. "When are you going to be governor?" Mr. Fisch asks. 
Mr. Silver looks up calmly from his falafel sandwich. "I thought you were my friend," he says. "Why would you wish a job like that on me?"
The joke has an element of truth. Mr. Silver, who will turn 59 this week, already holds a job he loves, and it makes him a very powerful man. He has ruled the State Assembly for nine years, longer than any other speaker in the last three decades, and has become the de facto leader of a state Democratic party some members think is adrift after losing the governor's race in the last election.
For eight years, Mr. Silver has been the main counterweight to a Republican governor and a Republican Senate majority, the strongest liberal voice in Albany's ruling triumvirate, a guardian of school spending and programs for the poor.
The entire time he has played defense, delaying the passage of budgets and holding Republican bills hostage in a fight to protect his party's agenda.
Some critics say Mr. Silver's stubbornness at the negotiating table is a major reason for the gridlock and paralysis that characterizes the Legislature. He sees holding out for the Democrats' priorities as his duty.
Yet never has Mr. Silver faced such a tough test of his abilities and principles as he does this year, when he must negotiate a way to close an $11.5 billion budget shortfall with a governor who has vowed to cut spending deeply on schools and health care rather than raise taxes.
The negotiations are likely to go far past the April 1 deadline and well into August, according to many lawmakers, among them the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno. Mr. Silver has already set the tone of the battle, declaring that Gov. George E. Pataki is balancing the budget on the backs of students and the working poor.
Mr. Silver lacks the flashy bravado one usually associates with long-serving legislative leaders. He almost never swears, even in heated negotiations, his aides say. He can be prone to droning on in his diesel-engine baritone about the intricacies of public policy. Yet he is not without charisma. He projects warmth when speaking to an audience and he often displays a deadpan sense of humor.
The usual competitive pride that marks most politicians flares up in his voice when he talks about having surpassed Stanley Fink as the longest-serving speaker and having built the Democratic majority in his chamber to 103 seats, its largest majority ever.
Much of the time, however, Mr. Silver can be self-effacing, as if he cannot believe an Orthodox Jewish boy from Grand Street has risen so far in the world. When President Bush shook his hand at a ceremony commemorating the Sept. 11 attack and said he had heard of Mr. Silver, the Assembly speaker responded with an incredulous "You have?"
His acquaintances say he is a wary man, hard to befriend, but very loyal once he has decided to trust someone. Two years ago, for instance, he stood unflinchingly by a top aide accused of rape, when many other politicians might have cut their ties right away. Charges were never filed.
"He has a huge sense of personal loyalty," said Fred Jacobs, Mr. Silver's former legislative counsel. "Some would say he's loyal to a fault."
No one in the Legislature doubts Mr. Silver's intelligence and political smarts. He is a maddening negotiator, willing to use delay as a tactic, brilliant at finding what his opponents need and then blocking it to get what he wants. It is a skill, he says, he learned watching his father do business as a hardware dealer and that he later honed in Manhattan's courtrooms as a litigator.
"There is an art to it," he said. "You have to find your strengths, protect your weaknesses, and find your opponent's weaknesses."
But his critics say Mr. Silver is so focused on the inside game of running the Assembly and winning victories at the bargaining table that he sometimes loses sight of the larger political struggle.
A year ago, for instance, he agreed to pass a health care package Mr. Pataki wanted, even though the governor got the endorsement of a powerful union in return. The deal helped Mr. Pataki at the expense of his Democratic opponent in last year's governor's race, but Mr. Silver was proud of it, because he forced the governor to accept some changes to health programs the Assembly had sought for years.
"He's a true legislative insider," said one legislator who is close to him. "He loves the game. He loves being one of the three men in the room."
Some Democrats complain that Mr. Silver is so concerned about increasing his majority in the Assembly that he sometimes undercuts the interests of his New York City colleagues. In 1999, for example, he allowed the repeal of a commuter tax that was dear to the city in order to help suburban members facing tough races. City officials now face an uphill battle to restore the tax and the hundreds of millions of dollars it brought in each year.
Aides say Mr. Silver cares little about wresting the Senate from the Republicans. Some Democrats gripe that he has never thrown his full energy and resources into dislodging Mr. Pataki from office, either.
"Shelly is very content to be the one Democrat in the triumvirate," said one former staff member.
The speaker denies the charge. "Obviously Governor Pataki thinks I tried," he said. "He's tried to emasculate every program I put forward."
Mr. Silver can trace much of the long track of his life without leaving a four-block circle around the corner of Grand and Henry Streets on the Lower East Side.
He and his wife, Rosa, a schoolteacher, live in an apartment in Co-op Village only three blocks from where he was raised as a boy and where his son's family now lives. Her parents still live nearby. The Bialystoker Synagogue, where he has worshiped all his life, with its dreamlike frescoes and stained-glass light, is a stone's throw from his home. So is the former site of Rabbi Jacob Joseph School, a parochial school where he was a teenage basketball star, and the Henry Street Settlement, where he was a piano student dropout.
"I can stand on one street corner and show you my whole life," he says.
Mr. Silver was born at Beth Israel Hospital on Feb. 13, 1944, the youngest of four children of Nathan and Frieda Silver. He was raised in a five-story walk-up on Henry Street. His father, a Russian immigrant from Minsk, went to night school to learn English and built a successful hardware business from scratch on Ludlow Street. Nathan Silver dedicated his life to educating his children.
"He took care of all expenses. He had only one condition. All the original diplomas he got," Mr. Silver recalled. "He'd point to the diplomas and say, 'Do you like my $20,000 wallpaper?' "
Through the middle of his freshman year at Yeshiva University, Mr. Silver intended to become a professional basketball player. But when he discovered he was having trouble keeping up with his studies, he instead took a job covering the basketball games for several newspapers for $25 a week. He remains an avid sports fan and says he still sometimes regrets not being a sportswriter.
He avoided the path to medical school that an older brother took, graduated from Brooklyn Law School, and became a trial lawyer.
"A Jewish boy who couldn't stand blood," he said. "That's the definition of a lawyer."
Mr. Silver ran for City Council in 1974 while working as a clerk for Manhattan Civil Court Judge Francis N. Pecora, coming in a close second to Miriam Friedlander. Two years later, he beat out five other Democrats to win an open Assembly seat he has held ever since.
His district is the polyglot tip of Manhattan, with its myriad housing projects, tenements, and its Jewish, Latino and Chinese quarters. He also represents the financial district, where the attack on the World Trade Center sucked the economic life out of the neighborhood.
Though he says he has never been poor, Mr. Silver leads a modest life. He usually makes his own travel arrangements and prides himself on getting the best air fares. He binds up his bills and credit cards with a rubber band, because he finds a leather billfold too bulky. He carries two cellphones because he can save money once the free minutes have run out on the first by switching to the second. "That's the business upbringing of my father," he said.
Mr. Silver's idea of a good time is a round of golf in the Catskills or having lunch with his grandchildren in Cedarhurst, on Long Island. On summer weekends, he retreats to his vacation home in Sullivan County, only a few miles from the Pioneer Country Club his family frequented when he was a boy. There he entertains old friends on the deck of his bungalow.
"He's the straw that mixes the drink," said Heshie Oberlander, the proprietor of Kosher Bagel Hole in Brooklyn and one of Mr. Silver's oldest friends. "We do a lot of reminiscing. About the Lower East Side. People. Situations. We try to get the fun out of things."
Mr. Silver seldom shows his fun-loving side in the capital, where he cuts a sober figure in a world of backslapping and instant friendships. His poker-faced reserve sometimes puzzles his colleagues. He is the sort of man, they say, with whom one can have a long conversation about a request and walk away feeling good but not knowing if he has said yes or no.
That quality landed him in trouble three years ago, when some members, led by Assemblyman Michael J. Bragman of the Syracuse area, tried to oust him as leader, complaining that he was too inaccessible and aloof. He beat back the coup with a deft campaign of intimidation and calling in old debts. Since then, he has opened up the internal workings of his operation and cemented his power.
Some of his associates chalk up Mr. Silver's reserved public style to his upbringing in a close-knit Orthodox community, where the legacy of oppression in Eastern Europe has shaped a culture of caution.
"He's basically shy," one former aide said. "There are so many things in the world that he hasn't experienced."

HEADLINE: THREATS AND RESPONSES: THE ALLIANCE; 
Fallout From Iraq Rift: NATO May Feel a Strain

BYLINE:  By STEVEN R. WEISMAN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 

 BODY:
The disagreement that split the United States and three European allies today was provoked by the issue of disarming Iraq. But the rift now threatens to undermine the unity of NATO itself at a time of widespread questions about the alliance's future after the cold war.
 It was an open question today how serious or permanent the potential breach at NATO will turn out to be. Despite the current tensions, Europe and the United States remain closely tied by culture, politics and economics. The alliance has weathered similar strains before. 
 Officials agreed that the action today had more political significance than military. "In terms of what we need to do militarily in Iraq, this fight is of almost no consequence," a senior administration official said. "We will be able to get 16 of 19 countries with us. But the symbolism is important. Just as we wanted the U.N. to step up to the plate, we needed NATO to send a signal to Iraq that we are serious."
The current crisis, as the American ambassador to NATO called it, resulted from the rejection by France, Germany and Belgium of an American request for defensive equipment for Turkey in anticipation of a possible war against Iraq. Coupled with the demand today by Germany, Russia and France for more time for inspections, the rebuff fractured longtime allies on the eve of an increasingly likely conflict in the Persian Gulf region. Moreover, as Russia has become an associate member of NATO, the prospect of Moscow, Berlin and Paris collectively opposing Washington seemed to hold ominous implications.
NATO -- founded in 1949 to oppose the threat of the Soviet Union -- has undertaken post-cold war cooperative ventures in the Balkans and Afghanistan and could still play a role in Iraq, particularly in peacekeeping if Saddam Hussein were ousted.
Diplomats and analysts say the division over aid to Turkey betrays deep feelings of unease on both sides of the Atlantic driven by many factors, not simply Iraq. Not least among them is the longtime French tendency dating from the de Gaulle era to chart a course independently of Washington, especially when Britain lines up with the United States.
Now there is a French-German alliance on many European issues in opposition to Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain, Europe's biggest supporter of America's war plans.
Those factors have created a level of distrust across the Atlantic that unsettles many longtime alliance veterans, who have seen crises come and go over the decades. 
"What we have is a messy situation but not a crisis, because it is still fixable," said Richard C. Holbrooke, former ambassador to the United Nations and to Germany in the Clinton administration. "But to fix it, Americans and Europeans will have to reach a new understanding that NATO has a vital role to play in the world today."
As the possibility of a war in Iraq comes ever closer, French and German leaders appear increasingly uneasy with what they see as President Bush's bullying, unilateralist approach to international affairs. In this instance, they felt that the administration was, in effect, forcing NATO to vote for or against war in Iraq -- precisely the vote they have worked hard to delay in the United Nations Security Council.
"Our position is coherent," a French official said. "If we are not yet deciding to go to war in the Security Council, we cannot decide to go to war at NATO. Once the Security Council authorizes force against Iraq, it will be very easy to send materiel to Turkey right away."
The Europeans also accuse the Bush administration of using NATO to provide political cover for Turkish leaders who have aligned their country with the United States despite strong domestic opposition.
American officials argued that the equipment that Turkey needs -- Patriot missiles, chemical and biological warfare defenses, and Awacs surveillance planes -- can be supplied by individual members of NATO. The Dutch have already committed themselves to sending the Patriots to Turkey, an administration official said.
Alternatively, there was hope in Washington that with Turkey formally requesting help under Article IV of the NATO Charter, which requires the alliance to assist any member against attack, Paris and Berlin might change their minds. The previous request for aid came from Washington, not Ankara.
But the French and Germans argue that the fact that Turkey can be supplied by other means shows that the United States was seeking a political gesture from NATO, not a real defensive action.
Over the decades, NATO has been plagued with divisions, all of which have ultimately proved ephemeral. 
There were disagreements over the Vietnam War and over American efforts to use NATO bases to help Israel during wars in the Middle East. A pivotal moment occurred in 1966, when de Gaulle took France out of NATO's integrated military command. In the 1980's, there were protracted strains over the basing of Pershing missiles in Europe.
Beyond these disagreements are philosophical differences between Europeans and Americans epitomized by the cooperative new economic relationship forged by the European Union, a political and economic entity in which disputes great and small are painstakingly negotiated by diplomats and bureaucrats.
Robert Kagan, the author of several books on current affairs, put it succinctly in the opening lines of a new book: "Americans are from Mars and Europeans are from Venus." Europeans, he says, feel they have evolved into a postmodern, literally postwar world. Americans, Mr. Kagan argues, understand that sometimes there is no alternative to force.
The current dispute in NATO is "qualitatively different" from past disputes, Mr. Kagan said in an interview.
"It goes to the level of world view," he added. "I don't subscribe to the view that the French are being petty. They believe sincerely that the only legitimacy for action is a legal institution like the United Nations -- a view that I don't think most Democrats in the United States fully agree with."
Today, however, American officials were not inclined to view the problem philosophically.
"There is no logic to the French position," a senior administration official said. "To say you can't agree to this quite limited military move is unacceptable. There is a pattern of behavior here by the French that undercuts NATO's effectiveness. They say we are trying to isolate them. But they are only isolating themselves."

HEADLINE: THREATS AND RESPONSES: KABUL; 
Terrorists Still a Threat, U.S. Official Tells Afghans

BYLINE:  By CARLOTTA GALL 

DATELINE: KABUL, Afghanistan, Feb. 10 

 BODY:
The American special envoy to Afghanistan said today that it was unacceptable that members of Al Qaeda and the Taliban were chased out of Afghanistan only to be given sanctuary in Pakistan's tribal areas, where Qaeda members are present.
 The envoy, Zalmay Khalilzad, was in the Afghan capital to reassure the Afghan government and people of continued American support "no matter what happens in Iraq." At a news conference in the heavily fortified American Embassy in Kabul, he said recent fighting in southern Afghanistan had shown that terrorists, whether from the Taliban or Al Qaeda, still posed a significant problem. 
 "There are some key Taliban figures in Pakistan, and I don't think all they are doing is having tea there and sitting in their homes," he said. "They are probably plotting and encouraging negative developments in Afghanistan. And it is also true there are some Al Qaeda people in the border areas." 
Mr. Khalilzad would not comment on the level of assistance or encouragement the groups were receiving from official Pakistani channels, but said the United States government's understanding with the Pakistani leadership was that the groups should not be given sanctuary.
"We regard the Pakistani government to be a partner, and we will work with them to deal with these problems," he said.
There has been an increase in recent weeks in cross-border activity from Pakistan by militants opposed to the American presence in Afghanistan. Hundreds of American soldiers battled with rebels in southern Afghanistan two weeks ago, and have spent days since sweeping the mountains and caves to clear the area.
Afghan officials complain that Pakistan is not only doing nothing to apprehend Qaeda and Taliban troublemakers, but also that it is actively encouraging them. American military officials have also expressed frustration at Pakistan's failure to contain the cross-border activity. 
Mr. Khalilzad also showed a rare sign of impatience with the Afghan government today, saying it needed to do "more and better" in its part in the reform and reconstruction of the country.
He reinforced the American commitment to assist Afghanistan even in the event of a war in Iraq. "The U.S. is capable of doing more than one thing at the same time," he said, "and resources required for Afghanistan, in its entirety, we are able to deliver on and we are committed to delivering on, no matter what happens in Iraq."
The United States has spent more than $840 million -- in aid money, State Department expenditures and some military expenditure -- since October 2001 in Afghanistan, Mr. Khalilzad said, and will continue the same level of spending through 2003. He added that President Bush would reinforce the American commitment in person when President Hamid Karzai visits Washington on Feb. 27.
But there was a new tone to this visit. His discussions over the last three days with Afghan officials have concentrated on the overhaul and reconstruction of Afghanistan's security, political and economic institutions, and he said the government was not doing enough.
"I would like to have seen more institution building, on the security track, the army, police and the justice system," he said. "There is a civil service commission that has to reform the bureaucracy; not much has been done. I hope and expect it will do more."
He added, "I do hear complaints about the quality of service that you still get from government departments."
An overhaul of the justice system has barely gotten under way, he said, and a United Nations program, supported by Japan, for disarmament, demobilization and reintegration of armed fighters into civilian life, was supposed to have happened this year but had not. The lack of progress on disarmament and demobilization, even in Kabul, had contributed to the unsatisfactorily slow pace of creating a new national army which the American government has responsibility for, he said.
Mr. Khalilzad also criticized the government for its failure to pay attention to the regions. He said the the United States was using its influence to make provincial leaders cooperate with the central government in paying taxes and cooperating on security. But he said the center needed to do its part.
"It should be looked at as a two-way street rather than a one-way street of the regions submitting to the center," he said. "The center needs to do better."

HEADLINE: Consumers in Europe Resist Gene-Altered Foods 

BYLINE:  By LIZETTE ALVAREZ 

DATELINE: TOTNES, England, Feb. 7 

 BODY:
At the Happy Apple greengrocer in this Elizabethan town in England's West Country, the roasted vegetable pasty is labeled, clearly and proudly, as GM-free. So is the hommity pie and a scattering of other products crammed onto shelves.
 In fact, all across Britain and most of the rest of Europe, shoppers would be hard pressed to find any genetically modified, or GM, products on grocery store shelves, and that is precisely how most people want it. 
 Tinkering with the genetic makeup of crops to make them faster-growing and more resilient, something done routinely in the United States with seldom a pang of consumer concern, is seen here as heretical, or at the very least unhealthy. 
In some countries, including France and Austria, there is an unofficial moratorium on the sale of genetically modified foods. Such foods simply cannot be found there.
"It's not the natural order of things, that's all," Heather Baddeley, who was picking up lettuce and avocados at the Happy Apple, said about GM foods. "It's a kind of corruption, not the right thing to do, you know?"
Robert B. Zoellick, the United States trade representative, does not agree. He recently called Europe's stance on genetically modified food "Luddite" and "immoral," saying that Europeans' fears about GM foods had persuaded some famine-ridden countries in Africa to reject genetically altered grains. Some Europeans believed that Mr. Zoellick was in effect blaming Europe for starvation in Africa.
David Byrne, the European Union's health and consumer protection commissioner, said: "The U.S. government, including Republican leaders in Congress, accuse Europe of using the issue of genetically modified food as a way of keeping out American exports." "What Bob Zoellick said over the last few weeks has been unhelpful, clearly. It was unfair. It was wrong."
The European Union finances nongovernmental organizations, but it is those groups themselves, not the European trading bloc, that have moved in some cases to steer Africans clear of genetically altered grains, Mr. Byrne insisted. 
"The E.U.'s position on genetically modified food," he added, "is that it is as safe as conventional food."
That may be the official line at European Union headquarters in Brussels. But public sentiment in much of Europe, successfully stoked by environmental groups, is now so fiercely opposed to genetically altered food that in Austria, for example, politicians have won elections by vowing to keep "Frankenfood" at bay.
Many supermarket chains across France, Britain, Italy and Austria, among others, yanked all genetically modified products from their shelves three years ago and are in no hurry to restock them. Most recently, hundreds of Europe's most respected chefs banded together to form a group called Euro-Toques to battle the biotechnology lobby.
American companies like Monsanto stand to make enormous profits if Europe allows the importing of more genetically modified foods. 
A decision by the European Parliament on stricter labeling of genetically modified foods could be made as early as summer, and European officials hope that may make the food more acceptable, by clarifying exactly how it is made. But there is concern in the United States that the labeling will only alarm European consumers more.
The proposed rules would trace genetically altered substances in corn, tomatoes, feed and oils and make it clear to consumers which products contained at least 0.9 percent of a genetically modified substance. Theproducts concerned include highly refined corn oil, soybean oil and glucose syrup produced from cornstarch.
In France and Italy, Europe's two food meccas, public revulsion at GM food runs especially deep.
"U.S. culture is different from European culture," said Lorenzo Consoli, a Greenpeace expert on genetic engineering. "Here, there is a very strong feeling that links culture and food. And here there is much more the idea that science is not church or a religion. It is not enough anymore for European consumers to have somebody with a white coat, a professional, say it's O.K."
A string of food scandals, including the outbreak of mad cow disease in 1996, severely undermined people's faith in the safety of their food and their confidence in scientists and public officials, many of whom asserted that consumers faced no health risk at the time. 
Other scandals -- H.I.V.-tainted blood in France, the spread of mad cow disease from Britain to other European nations, and dioxin-infested chickens in Belgium -- only added to the mistrust.
Although there is no compelling evidence so far that genetically altered food is harmful, anti-GM activists say it is unknown whether the food is harmful in the long term. The uncertainty is precisely what worries Europeans.
Europeans also tend to be more environmentally sensitive than Americans, and environmental groups like Greenpeace and Friends of the Earth carry much greater sway. 
One widespread fear is that genetically altered crops will pollinate and infest neighboring crops, affecting ecosystems in unpredictable, and perhaps irreversible, ways. Environmental groups have turned that concern into a successful campaign against genetically modified food.
Europeans also care more than Americans about how food tastes, as opposed to how long it can sit on a shelf. "For some member states it's nearly synonymous with sovereignty," said Mr. Byrne, referring to the quality of food. The fight against genetically modified food is being led by organization like Greenpeace, which is rooting for a legal confrontation over the issue in the World Trade Organization.
Pia Ahrenkild Hansen, the spokeswoman for the European Union environmental commissioner, said the industry had done a poor job of marketing the advantages of genetically modified foods in Europe. 
"The industry has been incredibly bad about demonstrating what's the benefit," Ms. Hansen said. "Why it would make food production more sustainable. Why it would require less resources. Those arguments are not known by the consumers. People say, 'Why should we buy it?' "
In this speck of a town in the county of Devon, it is almost impossible to find any supporters of genetically modified foods. Three weeks ago, the county council's executive board endorsed a decision to bar its schools and hospitals from using any genetically altered food.
Angry citizens held marches, set up booths and attended meetings on the issue. Residents were especially incensed when Britain began a set of trials of genetically modified foods on farms, one of which is near here. 
One district councilor, Anne Ward, is petitioning the South Ham district here to declare itself a "GM-free zone." Ms. Baddeley, and many other shoppers at the Happy Apple, would favor that without a second thought, they said.

Above, a label indicates food free of genetic modification. (Jonathan Player for The New York Times); Robert B. Zoellick, the United States trade representative. (Doug Mills/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: New York Arts Being Cut Back In Money Pinch 

BYLINE:  By ROBIN POGREBIN 

 BODY:
New York City has seen its rich cultural offerings seriously diminished by a weak economy, a drop in tourism, city budget cuts and a decline in private contributions following the terrorist attacks.
 Museums, theaters, concert halls, opera companies, public gardens and zoos throughout the five boroughs are cutting performances, exhibitions, days of operation and staff members. This is only the beginning, arts executives say. 
 "It's like a patient whose health is slipping," said Randall Bourscheidt, president of the Alliance for the Arts, an advocacy group. He said the city's cultural decline was growing increasingly urgent. "The strong will reduce what they do," he said, "and the weak will have to take more drastic measures." 
The impact is already widespread:
*The Metropolitan Museum of Art had a deficit of more than $5 million last year and is projecting a similar shortfall this year. As a result the Met has temporarily closed some galleries, raised its suggested admission by 20 percent to $12, reduced its staff by about 40 from its 2,300 and, to increase revenue, introduced a $50 admission to blockbuster shows for members on Mondays, when the museum is usually closed. Future exhibitions are being reviewed with an eye toward cost cutting. "Every stone is going to be turned," said Philippe de Montebello, the Met's director. "We will do what needs done."
*The Brooklyn Academy of Music has eliminated one opera for next season, laid off a senior executive and expects to cut its $27 million budget by nearly $3 million next year.
*The Brooklyn Museum of Art will have one special exhibition next fall instead of four and can no longer afford to pay for staff trips to view potential exhibitions.
*The Bronx Museum of the Arts canceled two exhibitions last year and has eliminated four management positions. "Last year we killed programs," said Jenny Dixon, the executive director. "This year we're killing people."
*The American Museum of Natural History has closed on Saturday nights, cut its $130 million budget by $14 million, reduced the number of entrances to two from seven; and through attrition reduced its 1,700-member staff by 200.
"There's a point where I don't know what will be cut next except programming," said Ellen V. Futter, president of the natural history museum. "And that's a very serious moment, not just for us but for the city."
Michael R. Bloomberg is considered by leaders of cultural organizations to be the most arts-friendly mayor in at least a decade. But he recently proposed an additional reduction of 6.2 percent in the cultural budget, bringing the total cutback to nearly 18 percent for fiscal year 2003.
Kate D. Levin, the cultural affairs commissioner, said the city's arts institutions had made out fairly well, considering the overall economic situation. 
On the state level Gov. George E. Pataki recently proposed cuts of 15 percent to the New York State Council on the Arts, and Gov. James E. McGreevey of New Jersey outlined a new budget that suspends all grants to arts groups. Some city experts said cultural institutions were merely coming down from the high of the flush 90's, when many of them ballooned in size.
"They're not facing Armageddon," said Mitchell L. Moss, director of the Taub Urban Research Center at New York University. "They went on an expansionary binge and now they have to be prudent."
But arts advocates say that there is no fat to cut and that the recent budget reductions bring cultural institutions close to the bone. "I've never seen it as scary as it is now," said Norma P. Munn, chairwoman of the New York City Arts Coalition, a citywide advocacy group. 
"We're losing money from every direction. Every source of income is down," Ms. Munn added.
"It's the tipping point now," said Karen Brooks Hopkins, chairwoman of the Cultural Institutions Group, which is made up of the 34 institutions owned by the municipal government or on city land. "We're at the moment when it's really going to start coming apart."
Arts executives argue that the city's cultural health affects its general health because the arts are an economic engine and provide jobs. Hiring and salaries are frozen at almost every arts institution. The Museum of the Moving Image in Queens, for example, recently eliminated its education director; those duties are now covered by the film curator. 
Tourism is also adversely affected at a time when New York City remains a tough sell because of the terrorist attacks. "If you read in your local paper that the city is cutting back on cultural institutions," Mr. Bourscheidt said, "you can quickly get the impression that the city is not healthy and not vital and not the place to visit next year."
Many cultural institutions have already learned to live without city money and rely much more heavily on donations from foundations, corporations and individuals. In the 1980's the Metropolitan Museum received 30 percent of its operating money from the city, for example; now it gets 10 percent. "They've become much less of a partner," said David E. McKinney, president of the museum. "So we're bearing more and more of the burden and have to pick it up and the private sector is unable to pick it up."
Gifts to the Met of $100,000 to $1 million, especially, are expected to diminish, Mr. McKinney said.
Because of the stock market decline, philanthropic giving is in a downward spiral. Real or not, said Ms. Levin, the cultural affairs commissioner, New Yorkers feel strapped. "The phrase people are using is 'psychic poverty,' " Ms. Levin said, "the sense that 'I feel poor,' even though that may not be the case."
Gifts to the Metropolitan Opera of less than $25,000 have fallen off, for example, although gifts of more than $25,000 -- from people whose finances are less closely tied to the vagaries of the market -- have made up for that softness.
"People are looking at their 401K's and feeling the pressure," said Joseph Volpe, general manager of the opera. "I am spending more time on fund-raising than I did two or three years ago."
Reynold Levy, the president of Lincoln Center, who faces a $1.2 billion fund-raising task for the complex's ambitious redevelopment, said he is urging donors to remember the good years. When they tell him how much less they are worth compared with three years ago, he reminds them how much more they are worth now compared with 10 years ago.
"They still have growth in net assets," Mr. Levy said. "There is still substantial wealth in this country." 
Arts executives describe a vicious cycle: cuts in funds force cuts in programming, which in turn makes it difficult to attract funds. "Exciting programs bring private support," said Ms. Hopkins, who is also the president of the Brooklyn Academy.
The mayor's proposed cut of 20 percent to 30 percent to the cultural capital budget means that many of the building projects begun in the boom years will have to be put off or scrapped.
The Department of Cultural Affairs is giving priority to plans that are already under way. "Anything that's in the ground we're holding harmless," Ms. Levin said.
The Museum of Modern Art's $800 million expansion, for example, is proceeding on schedule; the museum has raised $600 million for it so far.
Because smaller organizations receive greater percentages of their budgets from the city, have modest or nonexistent endowments and a limited donor base, they are cut slightly less than are the larger arts institutions. But they are still reeling. 
The New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx has reduced its staff size by 5 percent from 470 employees and is considering a 6 percent cut, 27 or 28 positions, in 2004. And the garden may go to opening five days a week instead of six or to closing large portions of its grounds to save money on security and maintenance. 
The Public Theater will perform one Shakespeare in the Park production for seven weeks this summer, as it did last summer, instead of two plays for four weeks each, as in the past.
The American Museum of the Moving Image usually raises $1 million at its annual gala; this year's gala, to be held tomorrow night, is expected to raise only $700,000.
The Staten Island Historical Society, an outdoor living history site, recently announced a 20 percent pay cut and reduction in work hours for its employees and is contemplating closing completely. "I'm holding off as long as I can," said John W. Guild, the executive director.
The picture is not without its bright spots. Membership is up at many cultural institutions, in large part because New Yorkers are staying closer to home. But European and Japanese tourists -- let alone residents of Connecticut and New Jersey -- have not returned in pre9/11 numbers.
"It's a mixed message," said Maxwell L. Anderson, director of the Whitney Museum of American Art. "The local universe is looking after us, but the tourism decline is still hitting us," he said."The question is whether we can weather this ebb of tourism without making any changes." 
Members' dues cannot compensate for the drop in big gifts, arts executives say. "It takes a lot of $60 members to make up for a $1 million loss," said Ms. Hopkins of the Brooklyn Academy.
While a few groups may buckle under the economic pressure, arts executives say, most will simply try to maintain their operations on a modified scale.
"Arts groups don't tend to go out of business," Mr. Bourscheidt said. "But they tend to become almost inactive. So a lot of the things people look for -- whether a positive experience in personal terms or a stimulus to the economy in collective terms -- just begin to be bled away." 

CORRECTION-DATE: February 13, 2003

 CORRECTION:
A front-page article on Tuesday about the way New York City arts institutions are coping with a reduction in income misstated the fiscal year for which the city has projected an 18 percent reduction in its cultural budget. It is 2004 (which starts on July 1), not 2003.

HEADLINE: THREATS AND RESPONSES: MADRID; 
Bush and Aznar New, if Unlikely, Allies

BYLINE:  By EMMA DALY 

DATELINE: MADRID, Feb. 10 

 BODY:
It seems an unlikely pairing the gregarious Texan and the reserved Castilian former tax inspector -- but a close friendship has formed between President Bush and Prime Minister Jose Maria Aznar of Spain.
 "From the first moment, there was a current of mutual understanding and liking, and an extraordinary ease in the relationship," Mr. Aznar said in an interview on Friday, describing his relationship with Mr. Bush. "And naturally that makes working together a lot easier." 
 This personal bond stands in striking contrast to Mr. Bush's frosty relations with some other European leaders, particularly Chancellor Gerhard Schroder of Germany. The president is often portrayed in Europe as an aggressive unilateralist who sees the world's problems in dangerously black-and-white terms.
Mr. Aznar shares with Mr. Bush free-market economic values and a no-nonsense view of the world. Although European leaders tend to a more nuanced sense of history, Mr. Aznar has no problem in seeing the Iraq crisis as a choice between Saddam Hussein and George Bush. 
Today, for example, Mr. Aznar lined up behind Mr. Bush on the American proposal that the North Atlantic Treaty Organization begin helping Turkey, a NATO member and Iraq neighbor, prepare for war. Germany, France and Belgium blocked that proposal.
"Spain's position is to heed the request of an ally, Turkey, which feels threatened and asks for help," Mr. Aznar said. "We must not transmit a message of weakness to the Iraqi regime."
He is also convinced, as is Mr. Bush, that terrorists will try to use weapons of mass destruction, and that the world community must act now to pre-empt them. "The combination of rogue states and terrorists capable of anything, of killing thousands of people in five minutes without firing a shot -- I don't want a world like that, and I won't accept a world like that," he said.
His stand has contributed to what appears to be a significant reordering of America's strategic priorities in Europe. Countries like Spain, once regarded as more peripheral than Germany and France, have moved to the center of the Bush administration's attention. Others, like Poland and Italy, that have been supportive of Mr. Bush have raised their standing in Washington.
Spain, now a member of the United Nations Security Council, will vote with the United States to support an attack on Iraq and, with Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain, is lobbying other European nations to support Mr. Bush.
Washington might expect such help from London, but Madrid has rarely been such an outspoken ally, and some of its support reflects the personal chemistry between the American and Spanish leaders.
At their initial meeting in June 2001, when Mr. Bush chose to start his first European tour by flying to Spain, he went far beyond what was expected by promising to help Mr. Aznar in the fight against terrorism, a priority of Spain for many years because of its violent Basque separatist movement.
Terrorism was discussed at all four summit meetings between the two leaders. "Cooperation on antiterrorism between the U.S. and Spain has never been closer," Mr. Aznar said in the interview.
On the streets of Madrid, noisy demonstrators have waved "Toxic Texan" banners, but in the Moncloa Palace complex where Mr. Aznar lives and works, the center-right Spanish government dominated by his Popular Party has always offered a warm welcome -- in the only foreign language spoken by Mr. Bush. There was even a Bush-style trip to a government ranch.
Mr. Aznar wrote the first draft of the article signed by eight European leaders and published last month in The Wall Street Journal that hailed "American bravery, generosity and farsightedness" in freeing Europe from Fascism and Communism.
"I'm in favor of a strong, solid relationship between Europe and the United States, and therefore between Spain and the U.S., because I think this relationship increases peace and security," Mr. Aznar said in the interview. "I believe that Europe needs the U.S. more than some think, and that the U.S. needs Europe more than some people think."
This does not always play well at home, especially in an atmosphere of prewar tension heightened by popular opposition to a war in Iraq. Opinion polls show that more than 70 percent of Spaniards oppose intervention in Iraq.
Asked about anti-Americanism in Spain, Mr. Aznar said: "There might be people who believe that to ensure peace and security in the world, we must distance ourselves from the U.S., but I don't see it like that. I believe that rifts between the U.S. and Europe have signaled bad times for global peace."
Mr. Aznar's arguments in support of force to disarm Mr. Hussein are dismissed by other Spanish political parties. Most scorn what they see as Mr. Aznar's willingness to fall into line with Washington.
The opposition Socialist leader, Jose Luis Rodriguez Zapatero, accused Mr. Aznar of seeking support for "whatever Mr. Bush says." Guillerme Vazquez of the Galician Nationalist Bloc told Mr. Aznar, "You are the voice of your master," while Gaspar Llamazares, leader of the United Left Party, called him "a vassal" of the United States. 
Mr. Aznar rejects this criticism, accusing the opposition of "doing anything for electoral gain." His party faces local elections in May, but he said "I'm not driven by electoral criteria, nor by short-termism."
He said nobody wanted war, but added: "Peace must be based on respect for law. We cannot invent a reality that does not exist. There is nothing more dangerous than a political leader who builds castles in the air, and I believe political leaders who raise false hopes, who don't look at the world as it is, are set to reap failure." 
Mr. Aznar will meet Chancellor Schroder on Tuesday on the Canary island of Lanzarote. Asked if that would be anopportunity to lobby the German leader, who opposes a war on Iraq, he said he hoped to achieve "a convergence of shades of opinion, more unity than before, on this issue in particular."
